speaker: Barroso
sentence:
President,

Honourable Members,

It is a great privilege to deliver the first State of the Union address before this House.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: From now on the State of the Union address will be the occasion when we will chart our work for the next 12 months.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Many of the decisions we will take this year will have long-term implications.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: They will define the kind of Europe we want.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: They will define a Europe of opportunity where those that aspire are elevated and those in need are not neglected.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: A Europe that is open to the world and open to its people.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: A Europe that delivers economic, social and territorial cohesion.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Over the last year, the economic and financial crisis has put our Union before one of its greatest challenge ever.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Our interdependence was highlighted and our solidarity was tested like never before.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: As I look back at how we have reacted, I believe that we have withstood the test.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We have provided many of the answers needed – on financial assistance to Member States facing exceptional circumstances, on economic governance, on financial regulation, on growth and jobs.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And we have been able to build a base camp from which to modernise our economies.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Europe has shown it will stand up and be counted.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Those who predicted the demise of the European Union were proved wrong.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The European institutions and the Member States have demonstrated leadership.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: My message to each and every European is that you can trust the European Union to do what it takes to secure your future.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The economic outlook in the European Union today is better than one year ago, not least as a result of our determined action.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The recovery is gathering pace, albeit unevenly within the Union.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Growth this year will be higher than initially forecast.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The unemployment rate, whilst still much too high, has stopped increasing.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Clearly, uncertainties and risks remain, not least outside the European Union.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We should be under no illusions.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Our work is far from finished.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: There is no room for complacency.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Budgetary expansion played its role to counter the decline in economic activity.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But it is now time to exit.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Without structural reforms, we will not create sustainable growth.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We must use the next 12 months to accelerate our reform agenda.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Now is the time to modernise our social market economy so that it can compete globally and respond to the challenge of demography.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Now is the time to make the right investments for our future.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This is Europe's moment of truth.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Europe must show it is more than 27 different national solutions.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We either swim together, or sink separately.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We will only succeed if, whether acting nationally, regionally or locally we think European.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Today, I will set out what I see as the priorities for our work together over the coming year.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I cannot now cover every issue of European policy or initiative we will take.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I am sending you through President Buzek a more complete programme document.

speaker: Barroso
Barroso
sentence: Let me start with the economic crisis and governance.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Earlier this year, we acted decisively when euro area members and the euro itself needed our help.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We have learned hard lessons.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Now we are making important progress on economic governance.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The Commission has put its ideas on the table in May and in June.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: They have been well received, in this Parliament, and in the Task Force chaired by President of the European Council.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: They are the basis around which a consensus is being developed.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We will present the most urgent legislative proposals on 29 September, so as not to lose the momentum.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Unsustainable budgets make us vulnerable.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Debt and deficit lead to boom and bust.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And they unravel the social safety net.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Money that's spent on servicing debt is money that cannot be spent on the social good.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Nor to prepare ourselves for the costs of an ageing population.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: A debt generation makes an unsustainable nation.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Our proposals will strengthen the Stability and Growth Pact through increased surveillance and enforcement.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And we need to tackle severe macro-economic imbalances, especially in the Euro area.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: That is why we have made proposals early on to detect asset bubbles, lack of competitiveness and other sources of imbalances.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I now see a willingness of governments to accept stronger monitoring, backed up by incentives for compliance and earlier sanctions.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The Commission will strengthen its role as independent referee and enforcer of the new rules.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We will match monetary union with true economic union.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: If implemented as we propose, these reforms will also guarantee the long-term stability of the euro.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It is key to our economic success.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: For the economy to grow, we also need a strong and sound financial sector.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: A sector that serves the real economy.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: A sector that prides itself on proper regulation and proper supervision.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We took action to increase bank transparency.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Today we are better than one year ago.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: With the publication of the stress test results, banks should now be able to lend to each other, so that credit can flow to Europe's citizens and companies.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We have proposed to protect people's savings up to €100,000.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We will propose to ban abusive naked short selling.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We will tackle credit default swaps.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The days of betting on someone else's house burning down are over.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We continue to insist that banks, not taxpayers, must pay up front to cover the costs of their own risks of failure.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We are legislating to outlaw bonuses for quick-wins today that become big losses tomorrow.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: As part of this approach, I am also defending taxes on financial activities and we will come with proposals this autumn.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The political deal on the financial supervision package just concluded is very good news.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The Commission proposals based on the de Larosière report will give us an effective European supervision system.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I want to thank the Parliament for the constructive role it has played and I hope it will give its final agreement this month.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We will also go further on regulation.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Initiatives on derivatives, further measures on credit rating agencies and a framework for bank resolution and crisis management will soon be before you.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Our goal is to have a reformed financial sector in place by the end of 2011.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Sound government finances and responsible financial markets give us the confidence and economic strength for sustainable growth.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We need to move beyond the debate between fiscal consolidation and growth.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We can have both.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
Honourable Members,

Sound public finances are a means to an end: growth for jobs.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Our goal is growth, sustainable growth, inclusive growth.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This is our overarching priority.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This is where we need to invest.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Europe 2020 starts now.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We must frontload and accelerate the most growth-promoting reforms of our agenda.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This could raise growth levels by over a third by 2020.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This means concentrating on three priorities: getting more people in jobs, boosting our companies' competitiveness and deepening the single market.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Let me start with people and jobs.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Over 6.3 million people have lost their jobs since 2008.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Each one of them should have the chance to get back into employment.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Europe's employment rates are at 69% on average for those aged between 20 and 64.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We have agreed these should rise to 75% by 2020, bringing in particular more women and older workers into the work force.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Most of the competences for employment policy remain with Member States.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But we won't stand on the sidelines.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I want a European Union that helps its people to seize new opportunities; and I want a Union that is social and inclusive.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This is the Europe we will build if Member States, the European institutions and the social partners move ahead on our common reform agenda.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It should be centred on skills and jobs and investment in life-long learning.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And it should focus on unlocking the growth potential of the single market, to build a stronger single market for jobs.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The opportunities exist.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We have very high levels of unemployment but Europe has now 4 million job vacancies.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The Commission will propose later this year a "European Vacancy Monitor".

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It will show people where the jobs are in Europe and which skills are needed.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We will also come forward with plans for a European skills passport.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We must also tackle problems of poverty and exclusion.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We must make sure that the most vulnerable are not left behind.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This is the focus of our "Platform Against Poverty".

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It will bring together European action for vulnerable groups such as children and old people.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: As more and more people travel, study or work abroad, we will also strengthen citizens' rights as they move across borders.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The Commission will address persisting obstacles as early as this autumn.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
Honourable Members,

Growth must be based on our companies' competitiveness.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We should continue to make life easier for our Small and Medium-Sized Enterprises.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: They provide two out of every three private sector jobs.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Among their main concerns are innovation and red tape.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We are working on both.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Just before the summer, the Commission has announced the biggest ever package from the Seventh Research Framework Programme, worth €6.4 billion.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This money will go to SMEs as well as to scientists.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Investing in innovation also means promoting world class universities in Europe.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I want to see them attracting the brightest and the best, from Europe and the rest of the world.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We will take an initiative on the modernisation of European universities.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I want to see a Europe that is strong in science, education and culture.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We need to improve Europe's innovation performance not only in universities.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Along the whole chain, from research to retail, notably through innovation partnerships.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We need an Innovation Union.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Next month, the Commission will set out how to achieve this.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Another key test will be whether Member States are ready to make a breakthrough on a patent valid across the whole European Union.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Our innovators are often paying ten times the price faced by their competitors in the United States or in Japan.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Our proposal is on the table.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It would reduce the cost fundamentally and double the coverage.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: After decades of discussion, it is time to decide.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We will also act further on red tape.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: SMEs are being strangled in regulatory knots.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: 71% of CEOs say that the biggest barrier to their success is bureaucracy.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The Commission has put proposals on the table to generate annual savings of €38 billion for European companies.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Stimulating innovation, cutting red tape and developing a highly-skilled workforce: these are ways to ensure that European manufacturing continues to be world class.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: A thriving industrial base in Europe is of paramount importance for our future.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Next month, the Commission will present a new industrial policy for the globalisation era.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We have the people, we have the companies.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: What they both need is an open and modern single market.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The internal market is Europe's greatest asset, and we are not using it enough.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We need to deepen it urgently.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Only 8% of Europe's 20 million SMEs engage in cross-border trade, still fewer in cross-border investment.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And even with the internet, over a third of consumers lack the confidence to make cross-border purchases.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: At my request, Mario Monti presented an expert report and has identified 150 missing links and bottlenecks in the internal market.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Next month we will set out how to deepen the Single Market in a comprehensive and ambitious Single Market Act.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Energy is a key driver for growth and a central priority for action: we need to complete the internal market of energy, build and interconnect energy grids, and ensure energy security and solidarity.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We need to do for energy what we have done for mobile phones: real choice for consumers in one European marketplace.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This will give us a real energy community in Europe.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We need to make frontiers irrelevant for pipelines or power cables.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: To have the infrastructure for solar and wind energy.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: To ensure that across the whole of Europe, we have a common standard so that charging electric car batteries becomes as natural as filling up the tank.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Over the next year, we will bring forward an energy action plan, an infrastructure package and an energy efficiency action plan to put this vision in place.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I myself will travel to the Caspian region later this year to promote the Southern Corridor as a means of enhancing our security of supply.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: To build a resource-efficient Europe, we need to look beyond energy.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: In the 20th century the world enjoyed phenomenal resource-intensive growth.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We saw in the 20th century globally a four-fold growth in population accompanied by a 40-fold growth in economic output.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But in the same period we also increased our use of fossil fuels 16 times, our fishing catches 35 times, our water use 9 times.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And our carbon emissions increased 17 times.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: That means we have to deliver on our climate and energy package, as a core driver for change.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This means integrating the different strands of policy on climate change, energy, transport and environment into a coherent approach on resource efficiency and a low carbon future.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: A forward-looking agricultural sector will play a major role in European measures to address some of the biggest challenges ahead, such as global food security, biodiversity loss and the sustainable management of natural resources.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: So will our maritime policy.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: All of this will not only strengthen our economy tomorrow: it will provide new openings today.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Jobs in the eco-industry have been increasing by 7% a year since 2000.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I want to see 3 million "green jobs" by 2020, 3 million green collar workers that complement our blue and white collar workers.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We need sustainable growth, and we need smart growth.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Half of European productivity growth over the last 15 years was driven by information and communication technologies.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This trend is set to intensify.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Our European Digital Agenda will deliver a single digital market worth 4% of EU GDP by 2020.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
Honourable Members,

Everything we do is for the citizens of Europe.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: A fundamental dimension of our European project is precisely building an area of freedom, security and justice.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We are working hard to implement the Stockholm action plan.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We will make a real push on asylum and migration.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Legal migrants will find in Europe a place where human values are respected and enforced.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: At the same time, we will crack down on the exploitation of illegal immigrants within Europe and at our borders.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The Commission will make new proposals on policing our external borders.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And we will bring forward an internal security strategy to tackle threats of organised crime and terrorism.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Europeans will find that their fundamental rights and obligations exist wherever they go.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Everyone in Europe must respect the law, and the governments must respect human rights, including those of minorities.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Racism and xenophobia have no place in Europe.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: On such sensitive issues, when a problem arises, we must all act with responsibility.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I make a strong appeal not to re-awaken the ghosts of Europe's past.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: An area of freedom, liberty and security, will create a place where Europeans can prosper.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
Honourable Members,

Another challenge is sorting out the future budget of the European Union.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Next month, we will come forward with the Commission's first ideas for the budget review.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It shall launch an open debate without taboos to prepare our legislative proposals that will be presented in the second quarter of next year.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We need to spend our money where we get most value for it.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And we should invest it where it leverages growth and delivers on our European agenda.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The quality of spending should be the yardstick for us all.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: So it is not only important to discuss the quantity, but also the quality of spending and investment.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I believe Europe offers real added value.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: That is why I will be pushing for an ambitious post-2013 budget for Europe.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I believe we should pool our means to back our policy priorities.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The issue is not about spending more or less, but spending more intelligently, by looking at European and national budgets together.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The EU budget is not for Brussels – it is for the people that you represent: for the unemployed workers being retrained by the Social Fund; for the students that participate in the Erasmus programme; for the regions that benefit from the Cohesion Fund.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Energy interconnections, research, and development aid are obvious examples where a Euro spent at European level gets you more than a Euro spent at national level.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Some Member States are seeing this logic even in areas of core national competence, like defence.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: They recognize that huge savings could be made if they pool some of their means and activities.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Pooling money at the European level allows Member States to cut their costs, avoid overlaps and get a better return on their investment.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: That's why we should also explore new sources of financing for major European infrastructure projects.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: For instance, I will propose the establishment of EU project bonds, together with the European Investment Bank.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We will also further develop Public Private Partnerships.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: As this Parliament has made clear, we must also address the issue of own resources.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The present system is stretched to its limits – propped up by a byzantine set of corrections.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Our citizens deserve a fairer and more efficient and transparent system.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Some will not agree with all the ideas we will raise; I find it extraordinary that some are already rejecting them, even before knowing what they will be.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I know that one issue of interest to this Parliament is the duration of the next budget.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Various options exist.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I would like to look at a 10-year framework, with a mid-term review of the financial dimension after five years – a "five plus five" option.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This will give us longer term planning and a clearer link with the mandates of both our institutions.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Of course, part of a credible European budget is the rigorous pursuit of savings.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I am looking at the administrative costs within the Commission and other Community bodies like Agencies.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We need to eliminate all pockets of inefficiency.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We will build on recommendations from the Court of Auditors to improve financial management.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
Honourable Members,

The final challenge I want to address today is how we pull our weight on the global stage.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: When we deal with our every day problems, we sometimes lose perspective and forget our achievements.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: A peaceful and successful transition to a European Union that has doubled in size and is negotiating further accessions.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: A sound currency, the euro, that is a major currency of the world.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: A strong partnership with our neighbourhood that strengthens us all.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: If we act decisively, then we have nothing to fear from the 21st century.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: As the strategic partnerships of the 21st century emerge, Europe should seize the chance to define its future.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I am impatient to see the Union play the role in global affairs that matches its economic weight.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Our partners are watching and are expecting us to engage as Europe, not just as 27 individual countries.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: If we don't act together, Europe will not be a force in the world, and they will move on without us: without the European Union but also without its Member States.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This is why, in my political guidelines, I called for Europe to be a global player, a global leader – a key task and test for our generation.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Together with High Representative and Vice-President Ashton, I will present our vision of how we can maximise Europe's role in the world.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: With the European External Action Service, we have the means to match our aspirations.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: In our globalized world, the relationships we build with strategic partners determine our prosperity.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: To be effective on the international stage, we need the weight of the European Union.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Size matters, now more than ever.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: A good example is the fight against climate change.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Copenhagen showed that, while others did not match our ambition, we did not help ourselves by not speaking with one voice.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Negotiations may have stalled but climate change has not.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I want us to intensify our engagement with international partners to turn their press releases into credible commitments to cut emissions and push forward with fast-start funding.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The next two months will see crucial Summits with strategic partners.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The more we are able to establish a common agenda with a clearly defined European interest, the more we will achieve.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: For example, I see huge potential in developing a transatlantic agenda for growth and jobs.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Where we are already punching our weight is the G20, the forum where the key economic global players address common challenges.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
When President Van Rompuy and I go to Seoul in November and represent the European Union, we want to see concrete results:

Further progress in global economic coordination.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: More stable and responsible financial markets and agreement on reform of international financial institutions.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: More effective global financial safety nets.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: More progress on a G20 development agenda.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We will continue to show leadership in this forum and work closely with the French G8/G20 Presidency next year.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We also want to see support for the Doha Round.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Trade boosts growth and prosperity.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We will also pursue bilateral and regional Free Trade Agreements.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: In October, the Commission will present a renewed trade policy to drive new benefits for Europe.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Being open to the world also means standing side by side with developing countries, especially with Africa.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: When I go to the Millennium Development Goals High-Level Event in New York in 2 weeks' time, I intend to commit, with your support and on behalf of the European Union, an extra €1 billion to the Millennium Development Goals.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Being a global player also means standing up for our values.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Human rights are not negotiable.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I am shocked about how the rights of women are being infringed in many countries.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I am appalled when I hear that Sakineh Mohammadi Ashtiani is sentenced to death by stoning.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This is barbaric beyond words.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: In Europe we condemn such acts which have no justification under any moral or religious code.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Our values also mean that we must come to the aid of those facing a crisis situation, anywhere around the world.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Our humanitarian aid to Pakistan is the latest example of Europe's solidarity in action.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It is a striking example of the need to present the different contributions of the Commission and the Member States as a truly European aid package.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The Member States have the helicopters; they have the civil protection teams.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We now need to pool them to create a real European crisis response capacity.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This is what the Commission will propose in October.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And I urge the Member States to show they are serious about the Union punching its weight in this area.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We are making progress on a common foreign policy.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But let's be under no illusions: we will not have the weight we need in the world without a common defence policy.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I believe now is the moment to address this challenge.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
Honourable Members,

We are still bedding down the new institutional set-up of Europe created by the Lisbon Treaty.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: What really matters is what the institutions deliver to the people.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: What matters is the difference Europe makes in their daily lives.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The secret of Europe's success is its unique Community model.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: More than ever, the Commission must drive the political agenda with its vision and proposals.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I have called for a special relationship between the Commission and Parliament, the two Community institutions par excellence.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I am intensifying my political cooperation with you.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Europe is not only Brussels or Strasbourg.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It is our regions.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It is the cities, towns and villages you come from.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: When you walk round your constituencies, you can point to the European projects that are so important for their prosperity.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: At the end of the day, we are all in the same boat, the European institutions, the Member states, the regions.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The Union will not achieve its objectives in Europe without the Member States.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And the Member States will not achieve their objectives in the world without the European Union.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
Honourable Members,

The citizens of Europe expect us to take the action needed to get out of this crisis.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We must show them that the common efforts we are making today will lead to new jobs, new investments, and a Europe fit for the future.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I am confident that Europe has what it takes.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We will get the results we are reaching for.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: One thing is certain, it is not with pessimism that we will win this battle.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It is with confidence, with a strong common will.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Today, I have outlined how I see the European Union doing that.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I have committed to deliver the proposals to build our economic union.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I have made the case to fast-track our reform agenda.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I have set out how to modernise our social market economy to deliver growth and jobs in a smart, sustainable and inclusive economy through our Europe 2020 flagship initiatives.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I have set out how to achieve a common energy policy in Europe.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I have defended the need for an area of freedom, security and justice, where Europeans will find that their fundamental rights and obligations exist wherever they go.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I have made clear that the Commission will strive for an ambitious budget.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I have proposed to develop EU project bonds to finance major European projects.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I have announced our reinforced commitment to the Millennium Development Goals.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I have made the case clear of why we need a common crisis response capacity and a also a common foreign and a common defence policy.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And I have urged European leaders to act together if they want Europe to be a global player and defend the European interest.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It is indeed a transformational, an ambitious and challenging agenda.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
For Europe to succeed, the Commission needs your support for a stronger, a fairer Europe for the benefits of our citizens

Thank you.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
Mr President,

Honourable Members,

Minister,

We must be honest and clear in our analysis of the state of the Union.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We are facing the biggest challenge in the history of our Union.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This crisis is financial, economic and social.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But it is also a crisis of confidence.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: A crisis of confidence in our leaders, in Europe itself, and in our capacity to find solutions.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The roots of the crisis are well-known.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Europe has not met the challenges of competitiveness.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Some of our Member States have lived beyond their means.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Some behaviours in the financial markets have been irresponsible and inadmissible.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We have allowed imbalances between our Member States to grow, particularly in the euro area.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Tectonic shifts in the world order and the pressures of globalisation, have made matters even worse.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The result is clear: concern in our societies.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Fear among our citizens for the future.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: A growing danger of a retreat into national, not to say nationalist, feeling.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Populist responses are calling into question the major successes of the European Union: the euro, the single market, even the free movement of persons.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Today we can say that the sovereign debt crisis today is, above all, a crisis of political confidence.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And our citizens, but also people in the outside world, are observing us and wondering – are we really a Union?

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Do we really have the will to sustain the single currency?

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Are the most vulnerable Member States really determined to carry out essential reforms?

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Are the most prosperous Member States really ready to show solidarity?

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Is Europe really capable of achieving growth and creating jobs?

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
I assert here today:

Yes, the situation is serious.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But there are solutions to the crisis.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Europe has a future, if we restore confidence.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And to restore confidence we need stability and growth.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But also political will, political leadership.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Together we must propose to our citizens a European renewal.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We must translate into deeds what was stated in the Berlin Declaration, signed by the Commission, by Parliament and by the European Council on the occasion of the 50th anniversary of the signature of the Rome Treaties.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It was said then: ‘Wir leben heute miteinander, wie es nie zuvor möglich war.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Wir Bürgerinnen und Bürger der Europäischen Union sind zu unserem Glück vereint.'

speaker: Barroso
sentence: - ‘Today we live together as was never possible before.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We, the citizens of the European Union, have united for the better.'

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It is a declaration.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And words count.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This expression of will must be translated into everyday courage.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Working with our institutions, and not working against them, we can succeed.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: For some, the main consideration is the need for stability.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: For others, it is growth.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I say we need both.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Some preach discipline.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Others, solidarity.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We need both.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The time for piecemeal solutions is over.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We need to set our minds on global solutions.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: A greater ambition for Europe.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Today we are at a turning point in our history.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: A moments when, if we do not integrate further, we risk fragmentation.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It is therefore a question of political will, a test for our whole generation.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And I say to you, yes, it is possible to emerge from this crisis.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It is not only possible, but it is necessary.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And political leadership is about making possible that which is necessary.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
Honourable members,

Let me start with Greece.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Greece is, and will remain, a member of the euro area.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Greece must implement its commitments in full and on time.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: In turn, the other euro area members have pledged to support Greece and each other.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: As stated at the euro area Summit on 21 July: "We are determined to continue to provide support to countries under programmes until they have regained market access, provided they successfully implement those programmes."

speaker: Barroso
sentence: That is why I created the Task Force for Greece.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
We have just launched an action plan based on two major pillars:

    Around 100 viable and high-quality projects, investing in all Greek regions, to make the best use of Greece's remaining allocation of the structural funds.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And a major drive to reduce bureaucratic procedures for European co-funded projects.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: € 15 billion remain to be spent in Greece from the structural funds.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This will support the Greek economy with an urgent programme of technical assistance to the Greek administration.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: A programme of € 500 million Euros to guarantee European Investment Bank loans to Greek SMEs is already under way.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The Commission is also considering a wider guarantee mechanism to help banks lend again to the real economy.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: All of this represents a huge support to Greece's fight back and Greece will have to deliver concrete results.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It must break with counter productive practices and resist vested interests.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But we have to be clear about this.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This is not a sprint, but a marathon.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The task of building a Union of stability and responsibility is not only about Greece.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The economic outlook that we face is very difficult.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We are confronted with the negative effects of an ongoing global re-assessment of risks.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It is therefore our responsibility to rebuild confidence and trust in the euro and our Union as a whole.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And we can do this by showing that we are able to take all the decisions needed to run a common currency and an integrated economy in a competitive, inclusive and resource-efficient way.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: For this we need to act in the short, in the medium and the long term.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The first step is to quickly fix the way we respond to the sovereign debt crisis.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This will require stronger mechanisms for crisis resolution.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We need credible firepower and effective firewalls for the euro.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We have to build on the EFSF and the upcoming European Stability Mechanism.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The EFSF must immediately be made both stronger and more flexible.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This is what the Commission proposed already in January.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This is what Heads of State and Government of the euro area agreed upon on 21 July.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
Only then, when you ratify this, will the EFSF be able to:

    deploy precautionary intervention;

    intervene to support the recapitalisation of banks,

    intervene in the secondary markets to help avoid contagion 

Once the EFSF is ratified, we should make the most efficient use of its financial envelope.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The Commission is working on options to this end.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Moreover we should do everything possible to accelerate the entry into force of the ESM.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And naturally we trust that the European Central Bank – in full respect of the Treaty – will do whatever is necessary to ensure the integrity of the euro area and to ensure its financial stability.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But we cannot stop there.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We must deepen economic coordination and integration, particularly in the euro area.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This is at least as big a political task as an economic one.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Today, you will vote on the so-called "six-pack" proposals that we put in front of you and the Council one year ago.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This "six-pack" reforms the Stability and Growth Pact and widens surveillance to macro-economic imbalances.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We are now back very close to what the Commission originally put on the table.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: You have played a decisive role in keeping the level of ambition of these proposals, and I really want to thank you and congratulate you for that.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This legislation will give us much stronger enforcement mechanisms.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We can now discuss Member States' budgetary plans before national decisions are taken.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This mix of discipline and integration holds the key to the future of the euro area.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Only with more integration and discipline we can have a really credible euro area.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
Honourable members,

These are indeed important steps forward, but we must go further.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We need to complete our monetary union with an economic union.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We need to achieve the tasks of Maastricht.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It was an illusion to think that we could have a common currency and a single market with national approaches to economic and budgetary policy.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Let's avoid another illusion that we can have a common currency and a single market with an intergovernmental approach.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: For the euro area to be credible – and this not only the message of the federalists, this is the message of the markets – we need a truly Community approach.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We need to really integrate the euro area, we need to complete the monetary union with real economic union.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And this truly Community approach can be built how?

speaker: Barroso
sentence: In the coming weeks, the Commission will build on the six-pack and present a proposal for a single, coherent framework to deepen economic coordination and integration, particularly in the euro area.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This will be done in a way that ensures the compatibility between the euro area and the Union as a whole.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We do not want the euro area to break of course the great acquis of the single market and all our four freedoms.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: At the same time, we can pool decision making to enhance our competitiveness.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This could be done by integrating the Euro Plus Pact into this framework, in full respect of the national implementation competences.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: For all of this to work, we need more than ever the independent authority of the Commission, to propose and assess the actions that the Member States should take.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Governments, let's be frank, cannot do this by themselves.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Nor can this be done by negotiations between governments.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Indeed, within the Community competences, the Commission is the economic government of the Union, we certainly do not need more institutions for this.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: For a reason the Treaties have created supra-national institutions.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: For a reason the European Commission, the European Central Bank, the European Court of Justice were created.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The Commission is the guarantor of fairness.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Moreover, the Commission, which naturally works in partnership with the Member States, is voted by and accountable to this House.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The directly elected Parliament both of the euro area and of the European Union as a whole.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
Honourable members,

It is also time to have unified external representation of the euro area.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: In accordance with the Treaty the Commission will make proposals for this purpose.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: A Union of stability and responsibility built on this basis and with common approach will also allow the Member States to seize fully the advantages of a bigger market for the issuance of sovereign debt.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Once the euro area is fully equipped with the instruments necessary to ensure both integration and discipline, the issuance of joint debt will be seen as a natural and advantageous step for all.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: On condition that such Eurobonds will be "Stability Bonds": bonds that are designed in a way that rewards those who play by the rules, and deters those who don't.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: As I already announced to this house, the Commission will present options for such "Stability Bonds" in the coming weeks.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Some of these options can be implemented within the current Treaty, whereas fully fledged 'Eurobonds' would require Treaty change.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And this is important because, Honourable Members, we can do a lot within the existing Treaty of Lisbon.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And there is no excuse for not doing it, and for not doing it now.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But it may be necessary to consider further changes to the Treaty.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I am also thinking particularly of the constraint of unanimity.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The pace of our joint endeavour cannot be dictated by the slowest.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And today we have a Union where it is the slowest member that dictates the speed of all the other Member States.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This is not credible also from the markets' point of view, this is why we need to solve this problem of decision making.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: A Member State has of course the right not to accept decisions.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: That is a question, as they say, of national sovereignty.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But a Member State does not have the right to block the moves of others, the others also have their national sovereignty and if they want to go further, they should go further.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Our willingness to envisage Treaty change should not be a way or an excuse to delay the reforms that are necessary today but I believe that this longer term perspective will reinforce the credibility of our decisions now.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: A Union of stability and responsibility means swiftly completing the work on a new system of regulation for the financial sector.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We need well-capitalised, responsible banks lending to the real economy.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Much has been said about the alleged vulnerability of some of our banks.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: European banks have substantially strengthened their capital positions over the past year.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: They are now raising capital to fill the remaining gaps identified by the stress tests in summer.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This is necessary to limit the damage to financial market turbulence on the real economy and on jobs.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Over the last three years, we have designed a new system of financial regulation.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Let's remember, we have already tabled 29 pieces of legislation.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: You have already adopted several of them, including the creation of independent supervising authorities, which are already working.

speaker: Barroso
Barroso
sentence: These propositions are there, they should be adopted by the Council and by the Parliament.

speaker: Barroso
Barroso
sentence: So we will be the first constituency in the G20 to have delivered on our commitment to global efforts for financial regulation.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
Honourable members,

In the last three years, Member States - I should say taxpayers - have granted aid and provided guarantees of € 4.6 trillion to the financial sector.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It is time for the financial sector to make a contribution back to society.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: That is why I am very proud to say that today, the Commission adopted a proposal for the Financial Transaction Tax.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Today I am putting before you a very important text that if implemented may generate a revenue of about € 55 billion per year.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Some people will ask "Why?".

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Why?

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It is a question of fairness.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: If our farmers, if our workers, if all the sectors of the economy from industry to agriculture to services, if they all pay a contribution to the society also the banking sector should make a contribution to the society.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And if we need – because we need – fiscal consolidation, if we need more revenues the question is where these revenues are coming from.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Are we going to tax labour more?

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Are we going to tax consumption more?

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I think it is fair to tax financial activities that in some of our Member States do not pay the proportionate contribution to the society.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It is not only financial institutions who should pay a fair share.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We cannot afford to turn a blind eye to tax evasion.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: So it is time to adopt our proposals on savings tax within the European Union.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And I call on the Member States to finally give the Commission the mandate we have asked for to negotiate tax agreements for the whole European Union with third countries.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
Honourable members,

Stability and responsibility are not enough on their own.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We need stability but we also need growth.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We need responsibility but we also need solidarity.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The economy can only remain strong if it delivers growth and jobs.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: That's why we must unleash the energy of our economy, especially the real economy.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The forecasts today point to a strong slowdown.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But significant growth in Europe is not an impossible dream.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It will not come magically tomorrow.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But we can create the conditions for growth to resume.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We have done it before.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We must and we can do it again.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It is true that we do not have much room for a new fiscal stimulus.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But that does not mean that we cannot do more to promote growth.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: First, those who have fiscal space available must explore it – but in a sustainable way.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Second, all member states need to promote structural reforms so that we can increase our competitiveness in the world and promote growth.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Together, we can and must tap the potential of the Single Market, exploit all the benefits of trade and mobilise investment at the Union level.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Let me start with the Single Market.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Full implementation of the Services Directive alone could, according to our estimates, deliver up to € 140 billion in economic gains.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But today, two years after the deadline for implementation, several Member States have still not adopted the necessary laws.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: So we are not benefiting from all the possible gains from having a true services liberalisation in Europe.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But we can also do more.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We must adopt what is on the table.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We have adopted the Single Market Act in the European Commission.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: A number of key initiatives are ready.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We are close to having a European patent which would cut the cost of protection to 20% of current costs.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I expect this is to be concluded by the end of this year.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Moreover, for the Single Market Act, we should consider a fast track legislative procedure.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: By the way, in many areas we should take a fast track legislative procedure because we are living in real emergency times.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This will allow us to respond to these extraordinary circumstances.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And growth in the future will depend more and more on harnessing information technology.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We need a digital single market, which will benefit each and every European by around €1500 per year – by using the possibilities of e-commerce to ending, for instance, mobile roaming charges.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: An extra 10 % in broadband penetration would bring us between 1 and 1.5 % of extra annual growth.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: In a competitive world we must be also well-educated with skills to face these new challenges.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We must innovate.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And we must act in a sustainable way.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We have already presented detailed proposals on innovation, resource-efficiency and how we can strengthen our industrial base.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Modern industrial policy is about investing in research and innovation.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We need to accelerate the adoption of our efforts to boost the use of venture capital to fund young, innovative companies across Europe.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Sustainable jobs will come if we focus on innovation and new technologies, including green technologies.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We must see that "green" and growth go together.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: For example, the renewables sector has already created 300,000 jobs in past 5 years in the European Union.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The global green technology market will triple over the next decade.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We must focus our action on where it makes a real impact.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Growth of the future means we must actively pursue also our smart regulation agenda, which will give a saving of € 38 billion for European companies, particularly for SMEs.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But Member States must also do their part in reducing the administrative burden.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But we also need investment.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: These reforms are important but we also need some kind of investment at European level.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: A Union of growth and solidarity needs modern, interconnected infrastructures.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We have proposed for the next Multi-Annual Financial Framework (MFF) to create a facility to connect Europe – in energy, in transport, in digital.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This innovative part of our MFF proposal has to be seen together with another very important innovative idea: the project bond.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: In the coming weeks the Commission will publish its proposals for EU project bonds.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We are also proposing pilot projects, so that we can fund that growth.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We can do it even before the MFF is adopted.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: In this way we can frontload some of the major infrastructure investments Europe needs.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The Union and its Member States should urgently consider how to allow our own policy-driven bank, the European Investment Bank to do more – and possibly much more – to finance long-term investment.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: To do so, we need to explore ways to reinforce the EIB's resources and capital base so that it can lend to the real economy.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: In the year 2000, there was € 22 billion of venture capital in Europe.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: In 2010 there was only € 3 billion.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: If we want to promote entrepreneurship we must reverse this decline and we need that support namely for SMEs.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We can also get more growth out of the Structural Funds, by increasing absorption capacity, using the Structural Funds to support macroeconomic performance.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: They are essential for innovation, for training and employment, and for SMEs.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I would also like to urge this House to adopt by the end of the year the proposals we made in August to increase cofinancing rates to those countries with assistance programmes.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This will inject essential funding into these economies, while reducing pressure on national budgets.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
Honourable members,

Reforms to our labour markets, public finances and pension systems require a major effort from all parts of society.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We all know these changes are necessary, so that we can reform our social market economy and keep our social model.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But it is imperative that we hold on to our values – values of fairness, of inclusiveness and of solidarity.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Right now we need to give concrete hope to the 1 in 5 of our young people who cannot find work.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: In some countries, the situation of our young people is simply dramatic.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I want to call on companies to make a special effort to provide internships and apprenticeships for young people.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: These can be supported by the European Social Fund.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: By getting businesses, the social partners, national authorities and the Union level working in a "Young Opportunities Initiative", we can make a difference.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This I believe is the most urgent social matter to respond to the anxiety of our young people that cannot find a job and it is much better to have an apprenticeship, a traineeship, than to be with that anxiety in the streets expressing that lack of confidence in the Union as a whole.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We must accelerate the most urgent parts of our Growth and Jobs Plan, Europe 2020.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The Commission will focus on the situation of young people in each and every Member State in its Country-specific recommendations for next year.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I believe we must give our future a real chance.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Right now we also need to act to help the 80 million Europeans at risk of poverty.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This means that the Council must finally approve our proposal to safeguard the programme for the supply of food for the most deprived persons.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I would like to thank this Parliament for the political support it has given to our proposed solution.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
Honourable Members,

Fifty years ago, 12 countries in Europe came together to sign the Social Charter.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It was exactly in October 50 years ago.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Today, that Charter has 47 signatories, including all our Member States.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: To guarantee these fundamental values in Europe, I believe we need to boost the quality of social dialogue at European level.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The renewal of Europe can only succeed with the input and the ownership of all the social partners – of trade unions, of workers, of businesses, civil society in general.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We should remember that our Europe is a Europe of citizens.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: As citizens, we all gain through Europe.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We gain a European identity and citizenship apart from our national citizenship.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: European citizenship adds a set of rights and opportunities.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The opportunity to freely cross borders, to study and work abroad.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Here again, we must all stand up and preserve and develop these rights and opportunities.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Just as the Commission is doing now with our proposals on Schengen.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We will not tolerate a rolling back of our citizens' rights.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We will defend the freedom of circulation and all the freedoms in our Union.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
Honourable Members,

The Commission's activities, as you well know, cover many other fields.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I cannot discuss them all here, but they are mentioned in the letter which I sent to the Parliament's President and which you have all received.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Before I conclude, however, let me speak about the European Union's external responsibilities.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I want to see an open Europe, a Europe engaging with the world.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: European action in the world is not only the best guarantee for our citizens and for the defence of our interests and our values: it is also indispensable to the world.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Today it is fashionable to talk of a G2.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I believe the world does not want a G2.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It is not in the interests of the Two themselves.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We know the tension that bipolarity created during the Cold War.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: If we want to have a just world and an open world, I believe that Europe is more necessary than ever.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The rapidly-changing world needs a Europe that assumes its responsibilities.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: An influential Europe, a Europe of 27 - with the accession of Croatia soon to be 28.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: A Europe that continues to show the way, whether in matters of trade or of climate change.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: At a time when major events await us, from Durban to Rio +20, Europe must retain its position of leadership on these questions.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Let us also turn our attention to our southern neighbours.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The Arab Spring is a profound transformation which will have lasting consequences not only for those peoples but also for Europe.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Europe should be proud.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We were the first to stand alongside those Tunisians, Egyptians and Libyans who wanted democracy and freedom.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Europe is supporting these legitimate aspirations, namely through our Partnership for Democracy and Shared Prosperity.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The Arab Spring should give hope for peace throughout the region.l Europe wishes to see a Palestinian State living in peace alongside the State of Israel.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Let us also turn our attention to our eastern neighbours.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: On Friday I shall take part in the Eastern Partnership Summit in Warsaw.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I shall go there with the ambition to forge a closer political relationship and tighter economic integration between us and our partners in the region.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The EU has extraordinary transformational power.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It is an inspiration for many people in the world, and if those countries embark on a thorough process of reform we can help them.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We can further political and economic ties.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Finally, let us not forget the most deprived of all and let us live up to our commitments in attaining the Millennium Development Goals.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We must also be realistic and recognise that, if Europe is to exert its influence fully, if Europe really wants to be a power, we must strengthen the Common Foreign and Security Policy.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It must be credible.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It must be based on a common security and defence dimension if we are really to count in the world.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Long gone is the time when people could oppose the idea of European defence for fear that it might harm the Transatlantic relationship.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: As you have noticed, today it is the Americans themselves who are asking us to do more as Europeans.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The world has changed, the world is still changing fundamentally.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Do we really want to count in the world?

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Hence, at a time when defence budgets are under pressure, we must do more together with the means at our disposal.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The Commission is assuming playing its part: we are working towards a single defence market.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We are using our under the Treaty with a view to developing a European defence industrial base.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
Honourable Members,

Let us not be naive: the world is changing and if Europe is to count in the world and defend its citizens' interests we need the political dimension and the defence dimension to give us weight and a say in the world's future.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
Honourable Members,

I conclude.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: At the end of our mandate, in 2014, it will be exactly a century since the Great War broke out on our continent.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: A dark period which was followed by the Second World War, one of the most dramatic pages in the history of Europe and the world.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Today such horrors are unimaginable in Europe, largely because we have the European Union.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Thanks to the European vision, we have built a guarantee of peace in our continent through economic and political integration.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: That is why we cannot allow this great work to be placed in jeopardy.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It was a gift from previous generations.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It will not be our generation that calls it into question.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And let us be clear: if we start to break up Europe, if we start to backtrack on Europe's major achievements, we will doubtless have to face the risk of fragmentation.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: As I said, the root of the crisis we are now facing is a political problem.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It is a test of our willingness to live together.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: That is why we have built common institutions.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: That is why we must safeguard the European interest.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The reality today is that intergovernmental cooperation is not enough to pull Europe out of this crisis, to give Europe a future.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: On the contrary, certain forms of intergovernmentalism could lead to renationalisation and fragmentation.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Certain forms of intergovernmentalism could be the death of the united Europe we wish for.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Let us not forget that the decisions we take now, or fail to take, are going to shape our future.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I feel hurt when I hear people in other parts of the world, with a certain condescension, telling us Europeans what we should do.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I think, frankly, we have problems, very serious problems, but I also think we do not have to apologise for our democracies.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We do not have to apologise for our social market economy.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We should ask our institutions, but also our Member States, Paris, Berlin, Athens, Lisbon and Dublin, to show a burst of pride in being European, a burst of dignity, and say to our partners: ‘Thanks for the advice, but we can overcome this crisis together'.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I feel that pride in being European.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And pride in being European is not just about our great culture, our great civilisation, everything to which we have given birth.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It is not pride only in the past, it is pride in our future.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: That is the confidence that we have to re-create among ourselves.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It is possible.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Some say it is very difficult, it is impossible.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I would remind them of the words of a great man, a great African, Nelson Mandela: ‘It always seems impossible until it is done'.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Let's do it.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We can do it with confidence.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We can do it, we can renew our Europe.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Thank you for your attention.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
Mr President,

Honourable Members,

1.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
Analysis of the situation

It is an honour to stand before you today to deliver this third State of the Union address.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: At a time when the European Union continues to be in crisis.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: A financial and economic crisis.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: A social crisis.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But also a political crisis, a crisis of confidence.

speaker: Barroso
Barroso
sentence: On top of that, the Euro faces structural problems of its own.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Its architecture has not been up to the job.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Imbalances have built up.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This is now being corrected.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But it is a painful, difficult, effort.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Citizens are frustrated.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: They are anxious.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: They feel their way of life is at risk.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The sense of fairness and equity between Member States is being eroded.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And without equity between Member States, how can there be equity between European citizens?

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Over the last four years, we have made many bold decisions to tackle this systemic crisis.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But despite all these efforts, our responses have not yet convinced citizens, markets or our international partners.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Why?

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Because time and again, we have allowed doubts to spread.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Doubts over whether some countries are really ready to reform and regain competitiveness.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Doubts over whether other countries are really willing to stand by each other so that the Euro and the European project are irreversible.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: On too many occasions, we have seen a vicious spiral.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: First, very important decisions for our future are taken at European summits.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But then, the next day, we see some of those very same people who took those decisions undermining them.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Saying that either they go too far, or that they don't go far enough.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And then we get a problem of credibility.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: A problem of confidence.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It is not acceptable to present these European meetings as if they were boxing events, claiming a knockout victory over a rival.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We cannot belong to the same Union and behave as if we don't.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We cannot put at risk nine good decisions with one action or statement that raises doubts about all we have achieved.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This, Honourable Members, reveals the essence of Europe's political crisis of confidence.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: If Europe's political actors do not abide by the rules and the decisions they have set themselves, how can they possibly convince others that they are determined to solve this crisis together?

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
Mr President,

Honourable Members,

2.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
The challenge – a new thinking for Europe

A crisis of confidence is a political crisis.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And, the good thing is that, in a democracy, there is no political problem for which we cannot find a political solution.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: That is why, here today, I want to debate with you the fundamental political questions - where we are now and how we must move forward.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I want to focus on the political direction and the vision that shall inspire our policy decisions.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I will of course not list all these individual decisions.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: You are receiving the letter I addressed to the President of the European Parliament, and that sets out the Commission's immediate priorities.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We will discuss them with you before adopting the Commission Work Programme later in the autumn.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: My message to you today is this: Europe needs a new direction.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And, that direction can not be based on old ideas.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Europe needs a new thinking.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: When we speak about the crisis, and we all speak about the crisis, have we really drawn all the consequences for our action?

speaker: Barroso
sentence: When we speak about globalisation, and we all speak a lot about globalisation, have we really considered its impact on the role of each of our Member States?

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The starting point for a new thinking for Europe is to really draw all the consequences of the challenges that we are facing and that are fundamentally changing our world.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The starting point is to stop trying to answer the questions of the future with the tools of the past.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Since the start of the crisis, we have seen time and again that interconnected global markets are quicker and therefore more powerful than fragmented national political systems.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This undermines the trust of citizens in political decision making.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And it is fuelling populism and extremism in Europe and elsewhere.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The reality is that in an interconnected world, Europe's Member States on their own are no longer able to effectively steer the course of events.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But at the same time, they have not yet equipped their Union - our Union —with the instruments needed to cope with this new reality.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We are now in a transition, in a defining moment.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This moment requires decisions and leadership.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Yes, globalisation demands more European unity.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: More unity demands more integration.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: More integration demands more democracy, European democracy.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: In Europe, this means first and foremost accepting that we are all in the same boat.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It means recognising the commonality of our European interests.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It means embracing the interdependence of our destinies.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And it means demanding a true sense of common responsibility and solidarity.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Because when you are on a boat in the middle of the storm, absolute loyalty is the minimum you demand from your fellow crew members.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This is the only way we will keep up with the pace of change.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It is the only way we will get the scale and efficiency we need to be a global player.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It is the only way to safeguard our values, because it is also a matter of values, in a changing world.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: In the 20th century, a country of just 10 or 15 million people could be a global power.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: In the 21st-century, even the biggest European countries run the risk of irrelevance in between the global giants like the US or China.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: History is accelerating.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It took 155 years for Britain to double its GDP per capita, 50 years for the US, and just 15 years for China.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But if you look at some of our new Member States, the economic transformation going on is no less impressive.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Europe has all the assets it takes.

speaker: Barroso
