sentence: In fact much more so than previous generations faced with similar or even greater challenges.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But we need to act accordingly and mobilize all these resources together.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It is time to match ambitions, decisions, and actions.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It is time to put a stop to piecemeal responses and muddling through.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It is time to learn the lessons from history and write a better future for our Europe.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
Mr President,

Honourable Members,

3.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
Response to the situation – the 'decisive deal for Europe'

What I demand and what I present to you today is a Decisive Deal for Europe.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: A decisive deal to project our values, our freedom and our prosperity into the future of a globalized world.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: A deal that combines the need to keep our social market economies on one hand and the need to reform them on the other.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: A deal that will stabilise the EMU, boost sustainable growth, and restore competitiveness.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: A deal that will establish a contract of confidence between our countries, between Member States and the European institutions, between social partners, and between the citizens and the European Union.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
The Decisive Deal for Europe means that:

We must leave no doubt about the integrity of the Union or the irreversibility of the Euro.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The more vulnerable countries must leave no doubts about their willingness to reform.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: About their sense of responsibility.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But the stronger countries must leave no doubts about their willingness to stick together.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: About their sense of solidarity.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We must all leave no doubts that we are determined to reform.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: To REFORM TOGETHER.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The idea that we can grow without reform, or that we can prosper alone is simply false.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We must recognise that we are in this together and must resolve it together.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This decisive deal requires the completion of a deep and genuine economic union, based on a political union.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
a) Economic union:

Let me start with Europe's economy.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Firstly, we need growth.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
Sustainable growth

Growth is the lifeblood of our European social market model: it creates jobs and supports our standard of living.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But we can only maintain growth if we are more competitive.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: At the national level it means undertaking structural reforms that have been postponed for decades.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Modernising public administration.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Reducing wasteful expenditure.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Tackling vested interests and privileges.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Reforming the labour market to balance security with flexibility.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And ensuring the sustainability of social systems.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: At the European level, we need to be more decisive about breaking down barriers, whether physical, economic or digital.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We need to complete the single market.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We need to reduce our energy dependence and tap the renewable energy potential.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Promoting competitiveness in sectors such as energy, transport or telecoms could open up fresh competition, promote innovation and drive down prices for consumers and businesses.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The Commission will shortly present a Single Market Act II.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: To enable the single market to prosper, the Commission will continue to be firm and intransigent in the defence of its competition and trade rules.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Let me tell you frankly, If it was left to the Member States, I can tell you they will not resist pressure from big corporations or large external powers.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We need to create a European labour market, and make it as easy for people to work in another country as it is as home.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We need to explore green growth and be much more efficient in our use of resources.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We have to be much more ambitious about education, research, innovation and science.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Europe is a world leader in key sectors such as aeronautics, automotives, pharmaceuticals and engineering, with global market shares above a third.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Industrial productivity increased by 35% over the last decade despite the economic slowdown.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And today, some 74 million jobs depend on manufacturing.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Every year start-up firms in the EU create over 4 million jobs.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We need to build on this by investing in our new industrial policy and creating a business environment that encourages entrepreneurship and supports small businesses.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This means making the taxation environment simpler for businesses and more attractive for investors.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Better tax coordination would benefit all Member States.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We also need a pro-active trade policy by opening up new markets.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This is the potential of Europe's economy.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This is the goldmine that is yet to be fully explored.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Fully implementing the Growth Compact agreed at the June European Council can take us a long way.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And we could go further, with a realistic but yet ambitious European Union budget dedicated to investment, growth and reform.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Let's be clear.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The European budget is the instrument for investment in Europe and growth in Europe.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The Commission and this Parliament, indeed all pro-European forces, because most member States support our proposal, must now stand together in support of the right multi-annual financial framework that will take us to 2020.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It will place little burden on Member States, especially with our proposed new own resources system.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But it would give a great boost to their economies, their regions, their researchers, their students, their young people who seek employment, or their SMEs.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It is a budget for growth, for economic, social and territorial cohesion between Member States and within Member States.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It is a budget that will help complete the single market by bridging gaps in our energy, transport and telecoms infrastructure through the Connecting Europe Facility.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It is a budget for a modern, growth-oriented agriculture capable of combining food security with sustainable rural development.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It is a budget that will promote a research intensive and innovative Europe through Horizon 2020.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
Because we need this European scale for research

This will be a real test of credibility for many of our some Member States.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I want to see if the same member States who are all the time talking about investment and growth will now support a budget for growth at the European level.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The budget is also the tool to support investment in our growth agenda, Europe 2020, which we need now more than ever before.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Europe 2020 is the way to modernise and preserve the European social market economy.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
Honourable Members,

Our agenda of structural reform requires a major adjustment effort.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It will only work if it is fair and equitable.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Because inequality is not sustainable.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: In some parts of Europe we are seeing a real social emergency.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Rising poverty and massive levels of unemployment, especially among our young people.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: That is why we must strengthen social cohesion.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It is a feature that distinguishes European society from alternative models.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Some say that, because of the crisis, the European Social model is dead.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I do not agree.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Yes, we need to reform our economies and modernise our social protection systems.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But an effective social protection system that helps those in need is not an obstacle to prosperity.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It is indeed an indispensable element of it.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Indeed, it is precisely those European countries with the most effective social protection systems and with the most developed social partnerships, that are among the most successful and competitive economies in the world.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Fairness and equity means giving a chance to our young people.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We are already doing a lot.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And before the end of the year, the Commission will launch a Youth Package that will establish a youth guarantee scheme and a quality framework to facilitate vocational training.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Fairness and equity also means creating better and fairer taxation systems.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Stopping tax fraud and tax evasion could put extra billions into the public purse across Europe.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This is why the Commission will fight for an agreement on the revised savings tax directive, and on mandates to negotiate stronger savings tax agreements with third countries.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Their completion would be a major source of legitimate tax revenues.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And the Commission will continue to fight for a fair and ambitious Financial Transactions Tax that would ensure that taxpayers benefit from the financial sector, not just that the financial sector benefits from taxpayers.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Now that it is clear that agreement on this can only happen through enhanced cooperation, the Commission will do all it can to move this forward rapidly and effectively with those Member States that are willing.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Because this is about fairness.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And fairness is an essential condition to make the necessary economic reforms socially and politically acceptable.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And above all fairness is a question of justice, social justice.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
Mr President,

Honourable Members,

In the face of the crisis, important decisions have been taken.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Across the European Union, reform and consolidation measures are being implemented.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Joint financial backstops are being put in place, and the European institutions have consistently shown that they stands by the Euro.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The Commission is very aware that in the Member States implementing the most intense reforms, there is hardship and there are – sometimes very painful – difficult adjustments.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But it is only through these reforms that we can come to a better future.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: They were long overdue.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Going back to the status quo ante is simply impossible.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The Commission will continue to do all it can to support these Member States and to help them boost growth and employment, for instance through the re-programming of structural funds.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Allow me to say a word on Greece.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I truly believe that we have a chance this autumn to come to the turning point.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: If Greece banishes all doubts about its commitment to reform.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But also if all other countries banish all doubts about their determination to keep Greece in the Euro area, we can do it.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I believe that if Greece stands by its commitments it should stay in the Euro area, as a member of the European family.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Securing the stability of the Euro area is our most urgent challenge.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This is the joint responsibility of the Member States and the Community Institutions.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The ECB cannot and will not finance governments.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But when monetary policy channels are not working properly, the Commission believes that it is within the mandate of the ECB to take the necessary actions, for instance in the secondary markets of sovereign debt.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Indeed, the ECB has not only the right but also the duty to restore the integrity of monetary policy.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It is of course for the ECB, as an independent institution, to determine what actions to carry out and under what conditions.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But all actors, and I really mean all actors, should respect the ECB's independence.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
Honourable Members,

I have spoken about the economic measures that we must implement as a matter of urgency.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This is indispensable.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But it is not sufficient.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We must go further.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We must complete the economic and monetary union.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We must create a banking union and a fiscal union and the corresponding institutional and political mechanisms.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Today, the Commission is presenting legislative proposals for a single European supervisory mechanism.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This is the stepping stone to a banking union.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The crisis has shown that while banks became transnational, rules and oversight remained national.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And when things went wrong, it was the taxpayers who had to pick up the bill.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Over the past four years the EU has overhauled the rulebook for banks, leading the world in implementing the G20 commitments.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But mere coordination is no longer adequate – we need to move to common supervisory decisions, namely within the Euro area.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The single supervisory mechanism proposed today will create a reinforced architecture, with a core role for the European Central Bank, and appropriate articulation with the European Banking Authority, which will restore confidence in the supervision of the banks in the Euro area.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It will be a supervision for all Euro area banks.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Supervision must be able to look everywhere because systemic risks can be anywhere, not just in so-called systemically relevant banks.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Of course, this in a system that fully engages the national supervisors.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The package comprises two legal texts, one on the ECB and the other on the EBA, which go together.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It is clear that this parliament will have a crucial role to play in the adoption of the new mechanism, and after that in its democratic oversight.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This is a crucial first step towards the banking union I proposed before this House in June.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Getting the European supervisor in place is the top priority for now, because it is the precondition for the better management of banking crises, from banking resolution to deposit insurance.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: In parallel the Commission will continue to work on the reform of the banking sector, to make sure it plays its role in the responsible financing of the real economy.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: That means improving long term financing for SMEs and other companies.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It means rules on reference indices, so we do not again see the manipulation of bank interest rates affecting companies and mortgage holders alike.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It means legislation to ensure that banks give a fair deal to consumers and another look at the structure of banking activities to eliminate inherent risks.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: In all of this, the role of this Parliament is essential.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The Commission endeavours to work in close partnership with you.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But there is a second element of a deeper economic union it is the move towards a fiscal union.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The case for it is clear: the economic decisions of one Member State impact the others.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: So we need stronger economic policy co-ordination.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We need a stronger and more binding framework for the national decision making for key economic policies, as the only way to prevent imbalances.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: While much has been done here, for instance through the six-pack and the Country-Specific Recommendations, further steps are crucial to combine specific conditions with specific incentives and to really make the economic and monetary union sustainable.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: To deliver lasting results, we need to develop a fully equipped Community economic governance together with a genuine, credible Community fiscal capacity.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We do not need to separate institutions or to create new institutions for that.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Quite the contrary: for this to be effective and quick, the best way is to work with and through the existing institutions: The European Commission as the independent European authority, and overseen by the European Parliament as the parliamentary representation at the European level.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And it is in such a framework that over time, steps for genuine mutualisation of debt redemption and debt issuance can take their place.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: So economic reform coupled with a genuine economic and monetary union: these are the engines to get our boat moving forward.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The Commission will publish a blueprint for deepening the economic and monetary union still this autumn.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This blueprint will be presented to this House.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
Because these questions must be discussed with and by the representatives of the people

At the same time, it will inform the debate at the December European Council that will be prepared by the report that the President of the European Council, myself and the Presidents of the European Central Bank and the Eurogroup have been asked to present.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Our blueprint will identify the tools and instruments, and present options for legal drafting that would give effect to them, from policy coordination to fiscal capacity to debt redemption.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And, where necessary – as in the case of jointly and severally guaranteed public debt – it would identify the treaty changes necessary, because some of these changes require modifications to the Treaty.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It will present a blue-print for what we need to accomplish not only in the next few weeks and months, but in the next years.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
Mr President,

Honourable Members,

b) Political union:

Ultimately, the credibility and sustainability of the Economic and Monetary Union depends on the institutions and the political construct behind it.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This is why the Economic and Monetary Union raises the question of a political union and the European democracy that must underpin it.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: If we want economic and monetary union to succeed, we need to combine ambition and proper sequencing.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We need to take concrete steps now, with a political union as a horizon.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I would like to see the development of a European public space, where European issues are discussed and debated from a European standpoint.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We cannot continue trying to solve European problems just with national solutions.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This debate has to take place in our societies and among our citizens.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But, today, I would like to make an appeal also to European thinkers.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: To men and women of culture, to join this debate on the future of Europe.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And I make this appeal to you.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This is the house of European democracy.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We must strengthen the role of the European Parliament at the European level.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And we need to promote a genuine complementarity and cooperation between the European and national parliaments.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This also cannot be done without strengthening European political parties.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Indeed, we have very often a real disconnect between political parties in the capitals and the European political parties here in Strasbourg.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This is why we have to recognise the political debate is cast all too often as if it were just between national parties.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Even in the European elections we do not see the name of the European political parties on the ballot box, we see a national debate between national political parties.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This is why we need a reinforced statute for European political parties.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I am proud to announce that the Commission has adopted a proposal for this today.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: An important means to deepen the pan-European political debate would be the presentation by European political parties of their candidate for the post of Commission President at the European Parliament elections already in 2014.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This can be done without Treaty change.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This would be a decisive step to make the possibility of a European choice offered by these elections even clearer.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I call on the political parties to commit to this step and thus to further Europeanise these European elections.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
Mr President,

Honourable Members,

A true political European Union means we must concentrate European action on the real issues that matter and must be dealt with at the European level.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Let's be frank about this not everything can be at the same time a priority.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
Here, some self-criticism can probably be applied

Proper integration is about taking a fresh look at where is the most appropriate level of action.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Subsidiarity is an essential democratic concept and should be practiced.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: A political union also means that we must strengthen the foundations on which our Union is built: the respect for our fundamental values, for the rule of law and democracy.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: In recent months we have seen threats to the legal and democratic fabric in some of our European states.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The European Parliament and the Commission were the first to raise the alarm and played the decisive role in seeing these worrying developments brought into check.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But these situations also revealed limits of our institutional arrangements.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We need a better developed set of instruments– not just the alternative between the "soft power" of political persuasion and the "nuclear option" of article 7 of the Treaty.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Our commitment to upholding the rule of law is also behind our intention to establish a European Public Prosecutor's Office, as foreseen by the Treaties.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We will come with a proposal soon.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
Mr President,

Honourable Members,

A political union also means doing more to fulfil our global role.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Sharing sovereignty in Europe means being more sovereign in a global world.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: In today's world, size matters.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And values make the difference.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: That is why Europe's message must be one of freedom, democracy, of rule of law and of solidarity.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: In short, our values European values.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: More than ever our citizens and the new world order need an active and influential Europe.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This is not just for us, for the rest of the world it is important that we succeed.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: A Europe that stands by its values.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
And a Europe that stands up for its belief that human rights are not a luxury for the developed world, they should be seen as universal values

The appalling situation in Syria reminds us that we can not afford to be by-standers.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: A new and democratic Syria must emerge.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We have a joint responsibility to make this happen.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
And to work with those in the global order who need to give also their co-operation to this goal

The world needs an EU that keeps its leadership at the forefront of development and humanitarian assistance.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: That stands by open economies and fights protectionism.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: That leads the fight against climate change.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The world needs a Europe that is capable of deploying military missions to help stabilize the situation in crisis areas.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We need to launch a comprehensive review of European capabilities and begin truly collective defense planning.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Yes, we need to reinforce our Common Foreign and Security Policy and a common approach to defense matters because together we have the power, and the scale to shape the world into a fairer, rules based and human rights' abiding place.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
Mr President,

Honourable Members

4.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
Treaty change, 17/27 dimension and expanding public debate

a) Federation of nation states - Treaty change

A deep and genuine economic and monetary union, a political union, with a coherent foreign and defence policy, means ultimately that the present European Union must evolve.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Let's not be afraid of the words: we will need to move towards a federation of nation states.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This is what we need.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This is our political horizon.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This is what must guide our work in the years to come.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Today, I call for a federation of nation states.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Not a superstate.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: A democratic federation of nation states that can tackle our common problems, through the sharing of sovereignty in a way that each country and each citizen are better equipped to control their own destiny.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This is about the Union with the Member States, not against the Member States.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: In the age of globalisation pooled sovereignty means more power, not less.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And, I said it on purpose a federation of nation states because in these turbulent times these times of anxiety, we should not leave the defence of the nation just to the nationalists and populists.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I believe in a Europe where people are proud of their nations but also proud to be European and proud of our European values.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Creating this federation of nation states will ultimately require a new Treaty.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I do not say this lightly.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We are all aware how difficult treaty change has become.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It has to be well prepared.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Discussions on treaty change must not distract or delay us from doing what can and must be done already today.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: A deep and genuine economic and monetary union can be started under the current Treaties, but can only be completed with changes in the treaties So let's start it now but let's have the horizon for the future present in our decisions of today.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We must not begin with treaty change.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We must identify the policies we need and the instruments to implement them.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Only then can we decide on the tools that we lack and the ways to remedy this.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And then there must be a broad debate all over Europe.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: A debate that must take place before a convention and an IGC is called.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: A debate of a truly European dimension.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The times of European integration by implicit consent of citizens are over.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Europe can not be technocratic, bureaucratic or even diplomatic.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Europe has to be ever more democratic.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The role of the European parliament is essential.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This is why the European elections of 2014 can be so decisive.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Before the next European Parliament elections in 2014, the Commission will present its outline for the shape of the future European Union.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And we will put forward explicit ideas for Treaty change in time for a debate.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We will set out the objectives to be pursued, the way the institutions that can make the European Union more open and democratic, the powers and instruments to make it more effective, and the model to make it a union for the peoples of Europe.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
I believe we need a real debate and in a democracy the best way to debate is precisely in elections at the European level on our future and our goals;

b) 17/27 dimension

Mr President, Honourable Memberss

This is not just a debate for the Euro area in its present membership.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: While deeper integration is indispensable for the Euro area and its members, this project should remain open to all Member States.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Let me be very clear: in Europe, we need no more walls dividing us!.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Because the European Union is stronger as a whole in keeping the integrity of its single market, its membership and in its institutions.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: No one will be forced to come along.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
And no one will be forced to stay outThe speed will not be dictated by the slowest or the most reluctant

This is why our proposals will be based on the existing Union and its institutions, On the Community method.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Let's be clear – there is only one European Union.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: One Commission.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: One European Parliament.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: More democracy, more transparency, more accountability, is not created by a proliferation of institutions that would render the EU more complicated, more difficult to read less coherent and less capable to act.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
c) Expanding public debate:

This is honourable members the magnitude of the decisions that we will need to make over time.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: That's why I believe we need a serious discussion between the citizens of Europe about the way forward.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: About the possible consequences of fragmentation.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Because what can happen some times is to have, through unintended consequences, to have fragmentation when we do not want it.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: About what we could achieve if leaders avoid national provincialism what we can achieve together.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We must use the 2014 election to mobilise all pro-European forces.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We must not allow the populists and the nationalists to set a negative agenda.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I expect all those who call themselves Europeans to stand up and to take the initiative in the debate.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Because even more dangerous than the scepticism of the anti-Europeans, is the indifference or the pessimism of the pro-Europeans.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
Mr President,

Honourable Members,

5.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Conclusion: is this realistic?

speaker: Barroso
sentence: To sum up, what we need is a decisive deal to complete the EMU, based on a political commitment to a stronger European Union.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The sequence I put before you today is clear.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We should start by doing all we can to stabilise the euro area and accelerate growth in the EU as a whole.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The Commission will present all the necessary proposals and we have started today with the single supervisor to create a banking union, in line with the current Treaty provisions.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
Secondly, we will present our blueprint on a deep and genuine economic and monetary union, including the political instruments, and this will be done still this autumn

We will present here again all proposals in line with the current Treaty provisions.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
And thirdly, where we cannot move forward under the existing treaties, we will present explicit proposals for the necessary Treaty changes ahead of the next European Parliamentary election in 2014, including elements for reinforced democracy and accountability

This is our project.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: A project which is step by step but with a big ambition for the future with a Federation as our horizon for Europe.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Many will say that this is too ambitious, that it is not realistic.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But let me ask you - is it realistic to go on like we have been doing?

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Is it realistic to see what we are seeing today in many European countries?

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Is it realistic to see taxpayers paying banks and afterwards being forced to give banks back the houses they have paid for because they can not pay their mortgages?

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Is it realistic to see more than 50% of our young people without jobs in some of our Member States?

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Is it realistic to go on trying to muddle through and just to accumulate mistakes with unconvincing responses?

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Is it realistic to think that we can win the confidence of the markets when we show so little confidence in each other?

speaker: Barroso
sentence: To me, it is this reality that is not realistic.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This reality cannot go on.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The realistic way forward is the way that makes us stronger and more united.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Realism is to put our ambition at the level of our challenges.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We can do it!

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Let's send our young people a message of hope.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: If there is a bias, let it be a bias for hope.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We should be proud to be Europeans.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Proud of our rich and diverse culture.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: In spite of our current problems, our societies are among the most human and free in the world.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We do not have to apologise for our democracy our social market economy and for our values.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: With high levels of social cohesion.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Respect for human rights and human dignity.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Equality between men and women and respect for our environment.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: These European societies, with all its problems, are among the most decent societies in human history and I think we should be proud of that.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: In our countries two or three girls do not go to prison because they sing and criticise the ruler of their country.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: In our countries people are free and are proud of that freedom and people understand what it means to have that freedom.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: In many of our countries, namely the most recent Member States, there is a recent memory of what was dictatorship and totalitarianism.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: So Previous generations have overcome bigger challenges.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Now it is for this generation to show they are up to the task.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Now is the moment for all pro-Europeans to leave business as usual behind and to embrace the business of the future.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The European Union was built to guarantee peace.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Today, this means making our Union fit to meet the challenges of globalization.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: That is why we need a new thinking for Europe, a decisive deal for Europe.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: That is why we need to guide ourselves by the values that are at the heart of the European Union.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Europe I believe has a soul.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This soul can give us the strength and the determination to do what we must do.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: You can count on the European Commission.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I count on you, the European Parliament.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Together, as Community institutions we will build a better, stronger and a more united Europe, a citizens' Union for the future of Europe but also the future of the world.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Thank you for your attention.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
Mr. President,

Presidency of the Council,

Honourable Members,

Ladies and gentlemen,

In 8 months' time, voters across Europe will judge what we have achieved together in the last 5 years.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: In these 5 years, Europe has been more present in the lives of citizens than ever before.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Europe has been discussed in the coffee houses and popular talk shows all over our continent.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Today, I want to look at what we have done together.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: At what we have yet to do.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And I want to present what I believe are the main ideas for a truly European political debate ahead of next year's elections.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
Honourable Members,

As we speak, exactly 5 years ago, the United States government took over Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, bailed out AIG, and Lehman Brothers filed for bankruptcy protection.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: These events triggered the global financial crisis.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It evolved into an unprecedented economic crisis.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And it became a social crisis with dramatic consequences for many of our citizens.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: These events have aggravated the debt problem that still distresses our governments.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: They have led to an alarming increase in unemployment, especially amongst young people.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And they are still holding back our households and our companies.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But Europe has fought back.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: In those 5 years, we have given a determined response.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We suffered the crisis together.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We realised we had to fight it together.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And we did, and we are doing it.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: If we look back and think about what we have done together to unite Europe throughout the crisis, I think it is fair to say that we would never have thought all of this possible 5 years ago.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We are fundamentally reforming the financial sector so that people's savings are safe.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We have improved the way governments work together, how they return to sound public finances and modernise their economies.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We have mobilised over 700 billion euro to pull crisis-struck countries back from the brink, the biggest effort ever in stabilisation between countries.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I still vividly remember my meeting last year with chief economists of many of our leading banks.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Most of them were expecting Greece to leave the euro.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: All of them feared the disintegration of the euro area.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Now, we can give a clear reply to those fears: no one has left or has been forced to leave the euro.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This year, the European Union enlarged from 27 to 28 member states.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Next year the euro area will grow from 17 to 18.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: What matters now is what we make of this progress.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Do we talk it up, or talk it down?

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Do we draw confidence from it to pursue what we have started, or do we belittle the results of our efforts?

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
Honourable members,

I just came back from the G20 in Saint Petersburg.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I can tell you: this year, contrary to recent years, we Europeans did not receive any lessons from other parts of the world on how to address the crisis.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We received appreciation and encouragement.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Not because the crisis is over, because it is not over.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The resilience of our Union will continue to be tested.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But what we are doing creates the confidence that we are overcoming the crisis – provided we are not complacent.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We are tackling our challenges together.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We have to tackle them together.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: In our world of geo-economic and geopolitical tectonic changes, I believe that only together, as the European Union, we can give our citizens what they aspire: that our values, our interests, our prosperity are protected and promoted in the age of globalisation.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: So now is the time to rise above purely national issues and parochial interests and to have real progress for Europe.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: To bring a truly European perspective to the debate with national constituencies.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Now is the time for all those who care about Europe, whatever their political or ideological position, wherever they come from, to speak up for Europe.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: If we ourselves don't do it, we cannot expect others to do it either.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
Honourable Members,

We have come a long way since the start of the crisis.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: In last year's State of the Union speech, I stated that 'despite all [our] efforts, our responses have not yet convinced citizens, markets or our international partners'.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: One year on, the facts tell us that our efforts have started to convince.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Overall spreads are coming down.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The most vulnerable countries are paying less to borrow.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Industrial output is increasing.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Market trust is returning.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Stock markets are performing well.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The business outlook is steadily improving.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Consumer confidence is sharply rising.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We see that the countries who are most vulnerable to the crisis and are now doing most to reform their economies, are starting to note positive results.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: In Spain, as a signal of the very important reforms and increased competitiveness, exports of goods and services now make up 33% of GDP, more than ever since the introduction of the euro.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Ireland has been able to draw money from capital markets since the summer of 2012, the economy is expected to grow for a third consecutive year in 2013 and Irish manufacturing companies are re-hiring staff.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: In Portugal, the external current account, which was structurally negative, is now expected to be broadly balanced, and growth is picking up after many quarters in the red.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Greece has completed, just in 3 years, a truly remarkable fiscal adjustment, is regaining competitiveness and is nearing for the first time in decades a primary surplus.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And Cyprus, that has started the programme later, is also implementing it as scheduled, which is the pre-condition for a return to growth.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: For Europe, recovery is within sight.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Of course, we need to be vigilant.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: 'One swallow does not make a summer, nor one fine day'.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Let us be realistic in the analysis.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Let us not overestimate, but let's also not underestimate what has been done.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Even one fine quarter doesn't mean we are out of the economic heavy weather.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But it does prove we are on the right track.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: On the basis of the figures and evolutions as we now see them, we have good reason to be confident.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This should push us to keep up our efforts.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We owe it to those for whom the recovery is not yet within reach, to those who do not yet profit from positive developments.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We owe it to our 26 million unemployed.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Especially to the young people who are looking to us to give them hope.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Hope and confidence are also part of the economic equation.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
Honourable members,

If we are where we are today, it is because we have shown the resolve to adapt both our politics and our policies to the lessons drawn from the crisis.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And when I say 'we', I really mean: 'we': it has really been a joint effort.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: At each and every step, you, the European Parliament, you have played a decisive role through one of the most impressive records of legislative work ever.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I personally believe this is not sufficiently known by the citizens of Europe, and you deserve more credit and recognition for this.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: So let us continue to work together to reform our economies, for growth and jobs, and to adapt our institutional architecture.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Only if we do so, we will leave this phase of the crisis behind us as well.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: There is a lot we can still deliver together, in this Parliament's and this Commission's mandate.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: What we can and must do, first and foremost, let's be concrete is delivering the banking union.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It is the first and most urgent phase on the way to deepen our economic and monetary union, as mapped out in the Commission's Blueprint presented last autumn.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The legislative process on the Single Supervisory Mechanism is almost completed.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The next step is the ECBs independent valuation of banks assets, before it takes up its supervisory role.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Our attention now must urgently turn to the Single Resolution Mechanism.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The Commission's proposal is on the table since July and, together, we must do the necessary to have it adopted still during this term.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It is the way to ensure that taxpayers are no longer the ones in the front line for paying the price of bank failure.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It is the way to make progress in decoupling bank from sovereign risk.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It is the way to remedy one of the most alarming and unacceptable results of the crisis: increased fragmentation of Europe's financial sector and credit markets - even an implicit re-nationalisation.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And it is also the way to help restoring normal lending to the economy, notably to SMEs.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Because in spite of the accommodating monetary policy, credit is not yet sufficiently flowing to the economy across the euro area.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This needs to be addressed resolutely.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Ultimately, this is about one thing: growth, which is necessary to remedy today's most pressing problem: unemployment.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The current level of unemployment is economically unsustainable, politically untenable, socially unacceptable.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: So all of us here in the Commission – and I'm happy to have all my Commissioners today here with me - all of us want to work intensively with you, and with the member states, to deliver as much of our growth agenda as we possibly can, we are mobilizing all instruments, but of course we have to be honest, not all are at European level, some are at national level.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I want to focus on implementation of the decisions on youth employment and financing of the real economy.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We need to avoid a jobless recovery.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Europe therefore must speed up the pace of structural reforms.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Our Country Specific Recommendations set out what the member states must do in this respect.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: At EU level - because there is what can be done at national level and what can be done at European level -, the focus should be on what matters most for the real economy: exploiting the full potential of the single market comes first.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We have a well-functioning single market for goods, and we see the economic benefits of that.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We need to extend the same formula to other areas: mobility, communications, energy, finance and e-commerce, to name but a few.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We have to remove the obstacles that hold back dynamic companies and people.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We have to complete connecting Europe.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I'd like to announce that, today, we will formally adopt a proposal that gives a push towards a single market for telecoms.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Citizens know that Europe has dramatically brought down their costs for roaming.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Our proposal will strengthen guarantees and lower prices for consumers, and present new opportunities for companies.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We know that in the future, trade will be more and more digital.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Isn't it a paradox that we have an internal market for goods but when it comes to digital market we have 28 national markets?

speaker: Barroso
sentence: How can we grab all the opportunities of the future that are opened by the digital economy if we don't conclude this internal market?

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The same logic applies to the broader digital agenda: it solves real problems and improves daily life for citizens.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The strength of Europe's future industrial base depends on how well people and businesses are interconnected.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And by properly combining the digital agenda with data protection and the defence of privacy, our European model strengthens the trust of the citizens.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Both with respect to internal and external developments, adopting the proposed legislation on data protection is of utmost importance to the European Commission.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The single market is a key lever for competitiveness and employment.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Adopting all remaining proposals under the Single Market Act I and II, and implementing the Connecting Europe Facility in the next few months, we lay the foundations for prosperity in the years to come.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We are also adapting to a dynamic transformation on a global scale, so we must encourage this innovative dynamism at a European scale.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: That is why we must also invest more in innovation, in technology and the role of science.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I have great faith in science, in the capacity of the human mind and a creative society to solve its problems.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The world is changing dramatically.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And I believe many of the solutions are going to come, in Europe and outside Europe, from new science studies, from new technologies.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And I would like Europe to be leading that effort globally.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This is why we - Parliament and Commission - have made such a priority of Horizon 2020 in the discussions on the EU budget.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: That is why we use the EU budget to invest in skills, education and vocational training, dynamising and supporting talent.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: That is why we have pushed for Erasmus Plus.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And that is why, later this autumn, we will make further proposals for an industrial policy fit for the 21st century.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Why we mobilize support for SMEs because we believe a strong dynamic industrial base is indispensable for a strong European economy.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And whilst fighting climate change, our 20-20-20 goals have set our economy on the path to green growth and resource efficiency, reducing costs and creating jobs.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: By the end of this year, we will come out with concrete proposals for our energy and climate framework up to 2030.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And we will continue to shape the international agenda by fleshing out a comprehensive, legally binding global climate agreement by 2015, with our partners.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Europe alone cannot do all the fight for climate change.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Frankly, we need the others also on board.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: At the same time, we will pursue our work on the impact of energy prices on competitiveness and on social cohesion.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: All these drivers for growth are part of our 'Europe 2020' agenda, and fully and swiftly implementing it is more urgent than ever.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: In certain cases, we need to go beyond the 2020 agenda.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This means we must also pursue our active and assertive trade agenda.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It is about linking us closer to growing third markets and guaranteeing our place in the global supply chain.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Contrary to perception, where most of our citizens think we are losing in global trade, we have a significant and increasing trade surplus of more than 300 billion euro a year, goods, services, and agriculture.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We need to build on that.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This too will demand our full attention in the months to come, notably with the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership with the US and the negotiations with Canada and Japan.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And last but not least, we need to step up our game in implementing the Multiannual Financial Framework, the European budget.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The EU budget is the most concrete lever we have at hand to boost investments.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: In some of our regions, the European Union budget is the only way to get public investment because they don't have the sources at national level.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Both the European Parliament and the Commission wanted more resources.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We have been in that fight together.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But even so, one single year's EU budget represents more money - in today's prices - than the whole Marshall plan in its time!

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Let us now make sure that the programmes can start on the 1st of January 2014.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: That the results are being felt on the ground.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And that we use the possibilities of innovative financing, from instruments that have already started, to EIB money, to project bonds.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We have to make good on the commitment we have made in July.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: From the Commission's side, we will deliver.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We will, for example, present the second amending budget for 2013 still this month.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: There is no time to waste, so I warn against holding it up.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: In particular, I urge member states not to delay.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I cannot emphasise this enough: citizens will not be convinced with rhetoric and promises only, but only with a concrete set of common achievements.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We have to show the many areas where Europe has solved problems for citizens.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Europe is not the cause of problems, Europe is part of the solution.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I address what we have to do still more extensively in today's letter to the President of the European Parliament, which you will also have received.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I will not go now in detail regarding the programme for next year.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: My point today is clear: together, there is a lot still to achieve before the elections.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It is not the time to thrown in the towel, it is time to roll up our sleeves.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
Honourable Members,

None of this is easy.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: These are challenging times, a real stress test for the EU.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The path of permanent and profound reform is as demanding as it is unavoidable.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Let's make no mistake: there is no way back to business as usual.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Some people believe that after this everything will come back as it was before.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: They are wrong, This crisis is different.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This is not a cyclical crisis, but a structural one.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We will not come back to the old normal.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We have to shape a new normal.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We are in a transformative period of history.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We have to understand that, and not just say it.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But we have to draw all the consequences from that, including in our state of mind, and how we react to the problems.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We see from the first results that it is possible.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And we all know from experience that it is necessary.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: At this point in time, with a fragile recovery, the biggest downside risk I see is political: lack of stability and lack of determination.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Over the last years we have seen that anything that casts doubt on governments' commitment to reform is instantly punished.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: On the positive side, strong and convincing decisions have an important and immediate impact.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: In this phase of the crisis, governments' job is to provide the certainty and predictability that markets still lack.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Surely, you all know Justus Lipsius.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Justus Lipsius is the name of the Council building in Brussels.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Justus Lipsius was a very influential 16th century humanist scholar, who wrote a very important book called De Constantia.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: He wrote, 'Constancy is a right and immovable strength of the mind, neither lifted up nor pressed down with external or casual accidents.'

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Only a 'strength of the mind', he argued, based on 'judgment and sound reason', can help you through confusing and alarming times.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I hope that in these times, these difficult times, all of us, including the governments' representatives that meet at the Justus Lipsius building, show that determination, that perseverance, when it comes to the implementation of the decisions taken.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Because one of the issues that we have is to be coherent, not just take decisions, but afterwards be able to implement them on the ground.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
Honourable members,

It is only natural that, over the last few years, our efforts to overcome the economic crisis have overshadowed everything else.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But our idea of Europe needs to go far beyond the economy.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We are much more than a market.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The European ideal touches the very foundations of European society.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It is about values, and I underline this word: values.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It is based on a firm belief in political, social and economic standards, grounded in our social market economy.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: In today's world, the EU level is indispensable to protect these values and standards and promote citizens' rights: from consumer protection to labour rights, from women's rights to respect for minorities, from environmental standards to data protection and privacy.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Whether defending our interests in international trade, securing our energy provision, or restoring people's sense of fairness by fighting tax fraud and tax evasion: only by acting as a Union do we pull our weight at the world stage.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Whether seeking impact for the development and humanitarian aid we give to developing countries, managing our common external borders or seeking to develop in Europe a strong security and defense policy: only by integrating more can we really reach our objectives.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: There is no doubt about it.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Our internal coherence and international relevance are inextricably linked.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Our economic attraction and political traction are fundamentally entwined.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Does anyone seriously believe that, if the euro had collapsed, we or our Member States would still have any credibility left internationally?

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Does everyone still realise how enlargement has been a success in terms of healing history's deep scars, establishing democracies where no one had thought it possible?

speaker: Barroso
sentence: How neighbourhood policy was and still is the best way to provide security and prosperity in regions of vital importance for Europe?

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Where would we be without all of this?

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Today, countries like Ukraine are more than ever seeking closer ties to the European Union, attracted by our economic and social model.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We cannot turn our back on them.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We cannot accept any attempts to limit these countries own sovereign choices.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Free will and free consent need to be respected.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: These are also the principles that lie at the basis of our Eastern Partnership, which we want to take forward at our summit in Vilnius.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And does everyone still remember just how much Europe has suffered from its wars during the last century, and how European integration was the valid answer?

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Next year, it will be one century after the start of the First World War.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: A war that tore Europe apart, from Sarajevo to the Somme.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We must never take peace for granted.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We need to recall that it is because of Europe that former enemies now sit around the same table and work together.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It is only because they were offered a European perspective that now even Serbia and Kosovo come to an agreement, under mediation of the EU.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Last year's Nobel Peace Prize reminded us of that historic achievement: that Europe is a project of peace.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We should be more aware of it ourselves.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Sometimes I think we should not be ashamed to be proud.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Not arrogant.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But more proud.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We should look towards the future, but with a wisdom we gained from the past.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Let me say this to all those who rejoice in Europe's difficulties and who want to roll back our integration and go back to isolation: the pre-integrated Europe of the divisions, the war, the trenches, is not what people desire and deserve.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The European continent has never in its history known such a long period of peace as since the creation of the European Community.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It is our duty to preserve it and deepen it.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
Honourable members,

It is precisely with our values that we address the unbearable situation in Syria, which has tested, over the last months, the world's conscience so severely.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The European Union has led the international aid response by mobilising close to 1.5 billion euros, of which €850 million comes directly from the EU budget.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The Commission will do its utmost to help the Syrian people and refugees in neighbouring countries.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We have recently witnessed events we thought had long been eradicated.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The use of chemical weapons is a horrendous act that deserves a clear condemnation and a strong answer.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The international community, with the UN at its centre, carries a collective responsibility to sanction these acts and to put an end to this conflict.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The proposal to put Syria's chemical weapons beyond use is potentially a positive development.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The Syrian regime must now demonstrate that it will implement this without any delay.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: In Europe, we believe that, ultimately, only a political solution stands a chance of delivering the lasting peace that the Syrian people deserve.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
Honourable members,

There are those who claim that a weaker Europe would make their country stronger, that Europe is a burden; that they would be better off without it.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: My reply is clear: we all need a Europe that is united, strong and open.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: In the debate that is ongoing all across Europe, the bottom-line question is: Do we want to improve Europe, or give it up?

speaker: Barroso
sentence: My answer is clear: let's engage!

speaker: Barroso
sentence: If you don't like Europe as it is: improve it!

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Find ways to make it stronger, internally and internationally, and you will have in me the firmest of supporters.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Find ways that allow for diversity without creating discriminations, and I will be with you all the way.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But don't turn away from it.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I recognize: as any human endeavor, the EU is not perfect.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: For example, controversies about the division of labour between the national and European levels will never be conclusively ended.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I value subsidiarity highly.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: For me, subsidiarity is not a technical concept.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It is a fundamental democratic principle.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: An ever closer union among the citizens of Europe demands that decisions are taken as openly as possible and as closely to the people as possible.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Not everything needs a solution at European level.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Europe must focus on where it can add most value.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Where this is not the case, it should not meddle.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The EU needs to be big on big things and smaller on smaller things - something we may occasionally have neglected in the past.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The EU needs to show it has the capacity to set both positive and negative priorities.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: As all governments, we need to take extra care of the quality and quantity of our regulation knowing that, as Montesquieu said, 'les lois inutiles affaiblissent les lois nécessaires'.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: ['Useless laws weaken the necessary ones'.]

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But there are, honourable members, areas of major importance where Europe must have more integration, more unity.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Where only a strong Europe can deliver results.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I believe a political union needs to be our political horizon, as I stressed in last year's State of the Union.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This is not just the demand of a passionate European.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This is the indispensable way forward to consolidate our progress and ensure the future.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Ultimately, the solidity of our policies, namely of the economic and monetary union, depend on the credibility of the political and institutional construct that supports it.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: So we have mapped out, in the Commission Blueprint for a deep and genuine Economic and Monetary Union, not only the economic and monetary features, but also the necessities, possibilities and limits of deepening our institutional set-up in the medium and long term.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The Commission will continue to work for the implementation of its Blueprint, step by step, one phase after the other.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And I confirm, as announced last year, the intention to present, before the European elections, further ideas on the future of our Union and how best to consolidate and deepen the community method and community approach in the longer term.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: That way, they can be subject to a real European debate.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: They will set out the principles and orientations that are necessary for a true political union.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
Honourable Members,

We can only meet the challenges of our time if we strengthen the consensus on fundamental objectives.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Politically, we must not be divided by differences between the euro area and those outside it, between the centre and the periphery, between the North and the South, between East and West.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The European Union must remain a project for all members, a community of equals.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Economically, Europe has always been a way to close gaps between countries, regions and people.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And that must remain so.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We cannot do member states' work for them.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The responsibility remains theirs.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But we can and must complement it with European responsibility and European solidarity.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: For that reason, strengthening the social dimension is a priority for the months to come, together with our social partners.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The Commission will come with its communication on the social dimension of the economic and monetary union on the 2nd of October.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Solidarity is a key element of what being part of Europe is all about, and something to take pride in.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Safeguarding its values, such as the rule of law, is what the European Union was made to do, from its inception to the latest chapters in enlargement.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: In last year's State of the Union speech, at a moment of challenges to the rule of law in our own member states, I addressed the need to make a bridge between political persuasion and targeted infringement procedures on the one hand, and what I call the nuclear option of Article 7 of the Treaty, namely suspension of a member states' rights.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Experience has confirmed the usefulness of the Commission role as an independent and objective referee.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We should consolidate this experience through a more general framework.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It should be based on the principle of equality between member states, activated only in situations where there is a serious, systemic risk to the rule of law, and triggered by pre-defined benchmarks.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The Commission will come forward with a communication on this.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I believe it is a debate that is key to our idea of Europe.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This does not mean that national sovereignty or democracy are constrained.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But we do need a robust European mechanism to influence the equation when basic common principles are at stake.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: There are certain non-negotiable values that the EU and its member states must and shall always defend.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
Honourable Members,

The polarisation that resulted from the crisis poses a risk to us all, to the project, to the European project.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We, legitimate political representatives of the European Union, can turn the tide.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: You, the democratic representatives of Europe, directly elected, will be at the forefront of the political debate.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The question I want to pose is: which picture of Europe will voters be presented with?

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The candid version, or the cartoon version?

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The myths or the facts?

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The honest, reasonable version, or the extremist, populist version?

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It's an important difference.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: I know some people out there will say Europe is to blame for the crisis and the hardship.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But we can remind people that Europe was not at the origin of this crisis.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It resulted from mismanagement of public finances by national governments and irresponsible behaviour in financial markets.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We can explain how Europe has worked to fix the crisis.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: What we would have lost if we hadn't succeeded in upholding the single market, because it was under threat, and the common currency, because some people predicted the end of the euro.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: If we hadn't coordinated recovery efforts and employment initiatives.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Some people will say that Europe is forcing governments to cut spending.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But we can remind voters that government debt got way out of hand even before the crisis, not because of but despite Europe.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We can add that the most vulnerable in our societies, and our children, would end up paying the price if we don't persevere now.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And the truth is that countries inside the euro or outside the euro, in Europe or outside Europe, they are making efforts to curb their very burdened public finances.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Some will campaign saying that we have given too much money to vulnerable countries.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Others will say we have given too little money to vulnerable countries.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But every one of us can explain what we did and why: there is a direct link between one country's loans and another country's banks, between one country's investments and another country's businesses, between one country's workers and another country's companies.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This kind of interdependence means only European solutions work.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: What I tell people is: when you are in the same boat, one cannot say: 'your end of the boat is sinking.'

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We were in the same boat when things went well, and we are in it together when things are difficult.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Some people might campaign saying: Europe has grabbed too much power.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Others will claim Europe always does too little, too late.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The interesting things is that sometimes we have the same people saying that Europe is not doing enough and at the same time that's not giving more means to Europe to do what Europe has to do.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: But we can explain that member states have entrusted Europe with tasks and competences.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The European Union is not a foreign power.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: It is the result of democratic decisions by the European institutions and by member states.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: At the same time we must acknowledge that, in some areas, Europe still lacks the power to do what is asked of it.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: A fact that is all too easily forgotten by those, and there are many out there, who always like to nationalise success and Europeanise failure.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Ultimately, what we have, and what we don't have, is the result of democratic decision-making.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: And I think we should remind people of that.

speaker: Barroso
sentence:
Ladies and gentlemen,

Mr President,

Honourable members,

I hope the European Parliament will take up this challenge with all the idealism it holds, with as much realism and determination as the times demand of us.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The arguments are there.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The facts are there.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: The agenda has been set out.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: In 8 months' time, voters will decide.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Now, it's up to us to make the case for Europe.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We can do so by using the next 8 months to conclude as much as we can.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: We have a lot to do still.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Adopt and implement the European budget, the MFF.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This is critical for investment in our regions all over Europe.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This is indispensable for the first priority we have: to fight against unemployment, notably youth unemployment.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: Advance and implement the banking union.

speaker: Barroso
sentence: This is critical to address the problem of financing for businesses and SMEs.

speaker: Barroso
