sentence: Only then will Europe be more than the sum of its parts.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And only then can Europe be stronger and better than it is today.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Only then will leaders of the EU institutions and national governments be able to regain the trust of Europe's citizens in our common project.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Because Europeans are tired of the endless disputes, quarrels and bickering.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Europeans want concrete solutions to the very pertinent problem that our Union is facing.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And they want more than promises, resolutions and summit conclusions.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: They have heard and seen these too often.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Europeans want common decisions followed by swift and efficient implementation.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Yes, we need a vision for the long term.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And the Commission will set out such a vision for the future in a White Paper in March 2017, in time for the 60th anniversary of the Treaties of Rome.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We will address how to strengthen and reform our Economic and Monetary Union.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And we will also take into account the political and democratic challenges our Union of 27 will be facing in the future.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And of course, the European Parliament will be closely involved in this process, as will national Parliaments.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: But a vision alone will not suffice.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: What our citizens need much more is that someone governs.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: That someone responds to the challenges of our time.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Europe is a cord of many strands – it only works when we are all pulling in the same direction: EU institutions, national governments and national Parliaments alike.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And we have to show again that this is possible, in a selected number of areas where common solutions are most urgent.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I am therefore proposing a positive agenda of concrete European actions for the next twelve months.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Because I believe the next twelve months are decisive if we want to reunite our Union.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: If we want to overcome the tragic divisions between East and West which have opened up in recent months.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: If we want to show that we can be fast and decisive on the things that really matter.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: If we want to show to the world that Europe is still a force capable of joint action.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We have to get to work.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I sent a letter with this message to President Schulz and Prime Minister Fico this morning.

speaker: Juncker
Juncker
sentence:
A EUROPE THAT PRESERVES OUR WAY OF LIFE

I am convinced the European way of life is something worth preserving.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I have the impression that many seem to have forgotten what being European means.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: What it means to be part of this Union of Europeans – what it is the farmer in Lithuania has in common with the single mother in Zagreb, the nurse in Valetta or the student in Maastricht.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: To remember why Europe's nations chose to work together.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: To remember why crowds celebrated solidarity in the streets of Warsaw on 1 May 2004.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: To remember why the European flag waved proudly in Puerta del Sol on 1 January 1986.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: To remember that Europe is a driving force that can help bring about the unification of Cyprus – something I am supporting the two leaders of Cyprus in.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Above all, Europe means peace.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: It is no coincidence that the longest period of peace in written history in Europe started with the formation of the European Communities.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: 70 years of lasting peace in Europe.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: In a world with 40 active armed conflicts, which claim the lives of 170,000 people every year.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Of course we still have our differences.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Yes, we often have controversy.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Sometimes we fight.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: But we fight with words.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And we settle our conflicts around the table, not in trenches.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: An integral part of our European way of life is our values.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The values of freedom, democracy, the rule of law.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Values fought for on battlefields and soapboxes over centuries.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We Europeans can never accept Polish workers being harassed, beaten up or even murdered on the streets of Harlow.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The free movement of workers is as much a common European value as our fight against discrimination and racism.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We Europeans stand firmly against the death penalty.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Because we believe in and respect the value of human life.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We Europeans also believe in independent, effective justice systems.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Independent courts keep governments, companies and people in check.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Effective justice systems support economic growth and defend fundamental rights.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: That is why Europe promotes and defends the rule of law.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Being European also means being open and trading with our neighbours, instead of going to war with them.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: It means being the world's biggest trading bloc, with trade agreements in place or under negotiation with over 140 partners across the globe.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And trade means jobs – for every €1 billion we get in exports, 14,000 extra jobs are created across the EU.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And more than 30 million jobs, 1 in 7 of all jobs in the EU, now depend on exports to the rest of the world.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: That is why Europe is working to open up markets with Canada – one of our closest partners and one which shares our interests, our values, our respect for the rule of law and our understanding of cultural diversity.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The EU-Canada trade agreement is the best and most progressive deal the EU has ever negotiated.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And I will work with you and with all Member States to see this agreement ratified as soon as possible.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Being European means the right to have your personal data protected by strong, European laws.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Because Europeans do not like drones overhead recording their every move, or companies stockpiling their every mouse click.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This is why Parliament, Council and Commission agreed in May this year a common European Data Protection Regulation.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This is a strong European law that applies to companies wherever they are based and whenever they are processing your data.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Because in Europe, privacy matters.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This is a question of human dignity.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Being European also means a fair playing field.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This means that workers should get the same pay for the same work in the same place.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This is a question of social justice.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And this is why the Commission stands behind our proposal on the Posting of Workers Directive.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The internal market is not a place where Eastern European workers can be exploited or subjected to lower social standards.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Europe is not the Wild West, but a social market economy.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: A fair playing field also means that in Europe, consumers are protected against cartels and abuses by powerful companies.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And that every company, no matter how big or small, has to pay its taxes where it makes its profits.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This goes for giants like Apple too, even if their market value is higher than the GDP of 165 countries in the world.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: In Europe we do not accept powerful companies getting illegal backroom deals on their taxes.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The level of taxation in a country like Ireland is not our issue.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Ireland has the sovereign right to set the tax level wherever it wants.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: But it is not right that one company can evade taxes that could have gone to Irish families and businesses, hospitals and schools.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The Commission watches over this fairness.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This is the social side of competition law.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And this is what Europe stands for.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Being European also means a culture that protects our workers and our industries in an increasingly globalised world.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Like the thousands who risk losing their jobs in Gosselies in Belgium – it is thanks to EU legislation that the company will now need to engage in a true social dialogue.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And workers and local authorities can count on European solidarity and the help of EU funds.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Being European also means standing up for our steel industry.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We already have 37 anti-dumping and anti-subsidy measures in place to protect our steel industry from unfair competition.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: But we need to do more, as overproduction in some parts of the world is putting European producers out of business.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This is why I was in China twice this year to address the issue of overcapacity.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This is also why the Commission has proposed to change the lesser duty rule.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The United States imposes a 265% import tariff on Chinese steel, but here in Europe, some governments have for years insisted we reduce tariffs on Chinese steel.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I call on all Member States and on this Parliament to support the Commission in strengthening our trade defence instruments.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We should not be naïve free traders, but be able to respond as forcefully to dumping as the United States.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: A strong part of our European way of life that I want to preserve is our agricultural sector.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The Commission will always stand by our farmers, particularly when they go through difficult moments as is the case today.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Last year, the dairy sector was hit with a ban imposed by Russia.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This is why the Commission mobilised €1 billion in support of milk farmers to help them get back on their feet.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Because I will not accept that milk is cheaper than water.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Being European, for most of us, also means the euro.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: During the global financial crisis, the euro stayed strong and protected us from even worse instability.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The euro is a leading world currency, and it brings huge, often invisible economic benefits.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Euro area countries saved €50 billion this year in interest payments, thanks to the European Central Bank's monetary policy.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: €50 billion extra that our finance ministers can and should invest into the economy.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Mario Draghi is preserving the stability of our currency.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And he is making a stronger contribution to jobs and growth than many of our Member States.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Yes, we Europeans suffered under a historic financial and debt crisis.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: But the truth is that while public deficits stood at 6.3% on average in the euro area in 2009, today they are below 2%.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Over the last three years, almost 8 million more people found a job.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: 1 million in Spain alone, a country which continues to show an impressive recovery from the crisis.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I wish all this was recalled more often – everywhere in Europe where elected politicians take the floor.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Because in our incomplete Union, there is no European leadership that can substitute national leadership.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: European nations have to defend the rationale for unity.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: No one can do it for them.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: They can.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We can be united even though we are diverse.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The great, democratic nations of Europe must not bend to the winds of populism.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Europe must not cower in the face of terrorism.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: No – Member States must build a Europe that protects.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And we, the European institutions, must help them deliver this promise.

speaker: Juncker
sentence:
A EUROPE THAT EMPOWERS

The European Union should not only preserve our European way of life but empower those living it.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We need to work for a Europe that empowers our citizens and our economy.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And today, both have gone digital.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Digital technologies and digital communications are permeating every aspect of life.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: All they require is access to high-speed internet.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We need to be connected.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Our economy needs it.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: People need it.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And we have to invest in that connectivity now.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: That is why today, the Commission is proposing a reform for our European telecommunications markets.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We want to create a new legal framework that attracts and enables investments in connectivity.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Businesses should be able to plan their investments in Europe for the next 20 years.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Because if we invest in new networks and services, that is at least 1.3 million new jobs over the next decade.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Connectivity should benefit everyone.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: That is why today the Commission is proposing to fully deploy 5G, the fifth generation of mobile communication systems, across the European Union by 2025.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This has the potential to create a further two million jobs in the EU.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Everyone benefiting from connectivity means that it should not matter where you live or how much you earn.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: So we propose today to equip every European village and every city with free wireless internet access around the main centres of public life by 2020.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: As the world goes digital, we also have to empower our artists and creators and protect their works.Artists and creators are our crown jewels.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The creation of content is not a hobby.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: It is a profession.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And it is part of our European culture.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I want journalists, publishers and authors to be paid fairly for their work, whether it is made in studios or living rooms, whether it is disseminated offline or online, whether it is published via a copying machine or hyperlinked on the web.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The overhaul of Europe's copyright rules we are proposing today does exactly that.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Empowering our economy means investing not just in connectivity, but in job creation.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: That is why Europe must invest strongly in its youth, in its jobseekers, in its start-ups.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The €315 billion Investment Plan for Europe, which we agreed together here in this House just twelve months ago, has already raised €116 billion in investments – from Latvia to Luxembourg – in its first year of operation.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Over 200,000 small firms and start-ups across Europe got loans.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And over 100,000 people got new jobs.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Thanks to the new European Fund for Strategic Investments I proposed, my Commission developed, and you here in the European Parliament supported and adopted in record time.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And now we will take it further.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Today, we propose to double the duration of the Fund and double its financial capacity.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: With your support, we will make sure that our European Investment Fund will provide a total of at least €500 billion – half a trillion – of investments by 2020.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And we will work beyond that to reach €630 billion by 2022.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Of course, with Member States contributing, we can get there even faster.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Alongside these efforts to attract private investment, we also need to create the right environment to invest in.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: European banks are in much better shape than two years ago, thanks to our joint European efforts.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Europe needs its banks.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: But an economy almost entirely dependent on bank credit is bad for financial stability.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: It is also bad for business, as we saw during the financial crisis.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: That is why it is now urgent we accelerate our work on the Capital Markets Union.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The Commission is putting a concrete roadmap for this on your table today.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: A Capital Markets Union will make our financial system more resilient.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: It will give companies easier and more diversified access to finance.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Imagine a Finnish start-up that cannot get a bank loan.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Right now, the options are very limited.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The Capital Markets Union will offer alternative, vital sources of funding to help start-ups get started – business angels, venture capital, market financing.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: To just mention one example – almost a year ago we put a proposal on the table that will make it easier for banks to provide loans.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: It has the potential of freeing up €100 billion of additional finance for EU businesses.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: So let us please speed up its adoption.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Our European Investment Plan worked better than anyone expected inside Europe, and now we are going to take it global.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Something many of you and many Member States have called for.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Today we are launching an ambitious Investment Plan for Africa and the Neighbourhood which has the potential to raise €44 billion in investments.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: It can go up to €88 billion if Member States pitch in.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The logic is the same that worked well for the internal Investment Plan: we will be using public funding as a guarantee to attract public and private investment to create real jobs.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This will complement our development aid and help address one of the root causes of migration.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: With economic growth in developing countries at its lowest level since 2003, this is crucial.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The new Plan will offer lifelines for those who would otherwise be pushed to take dangerous journeys in search of a better life.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: As much as we invest in improving conditions abroad, we also need to invest in responding to humanitarian crises back home.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And, more than anything, we need to invest in our young people.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I cannot and will not accept that Europe is and remains the continent of youth unemployment.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I cannot and will not accept that the millennials, Generation Y, might be the first generation in 70 years to be poorer than their parents.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Of course, this is mainly a task of national governments.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: But the European Union can support their efforts.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We are doing this with the EU Youth Guarantee that was launched three years ago.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: My Commission enhanced the effectiveness and sped up delivery of the Youth Guarantee.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: More than 9 million young people have already benefitted from this programme.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: That is 9 million young people who got a job, traineeship or apprenticeship because of the EU.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And we will continue to roll out the Youth Guarantee across Europe, improving the skillset of Europeans and reaching out to the regions and young people most in need.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The European Union can also contribute by helping create more opportunities for young people.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: There are many young, socially-minded people in Europe willing to make a meaningful contribution to society and help show solidarity.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Solidarity is the glue that keeps our Union together.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The word solidarity appears 16 times in the Treaties which all our Member States agreed and ratified.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Our European budget is living proof of financial solidarity.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: There is impressive solidarity when it comes to jointly applying European sanctions when Russia violates international law.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The euro is an expression of solidarity.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Our development policy is a strong external sign of solidarity.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And when it comes to managing the refugee crisis, we have started to see solidarity.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I am convinced much more solidarity is needed.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: But I also know that solidarity must be given voluntarily.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: It must come from the heart.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: It cannot be forced.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We often show solidarity most readily when faced with emergencies.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: When the Portuguese hills were burning, Italian planes doused the flames.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: When floods cut off the power in Romania, Swedish generators turned the lights back on.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: When thousands of refugees arrived on Greek shores, Slovakian tents provided shelter.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: In the same spirit, the Commission is proposing today to set up a European Solidarity Corps.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Young people across the EU will be able to volunteer their help where it is needed most, to respond to crisis situations, like the refugee crisis or the recent earthquakes in Italy.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I want this European Solidarity Corps up and running by the end of the year.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And by 2020, to see the first 100,000 young Europeans taking part.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: By voluntarily joining the European Solidarity Corps, these young people will be able to develop their skills and get not only work but also invaluable human experience.

speaker: Juncker
sentence:
A EUROPE THAT DEFENDS

A Europe that protects is a Europe that defends – at home and abroad.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We must defend ourselves against terrorism.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Since the Madrid bombing of 2004, there have been more than 30 terrorist attacks in Europe – 14 in the last year alone.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: More than 600 innocent people died in cities like Paris, Brussels, Nice, or Ansbach.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Just as we have stood shoulder to shoulder in grief, so must we stand united in our response.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The barbaric acts of the past year have shown us again what we are fighting for – the European way of life.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: In face of the worst of humanity we have to stay true to our values, to ourselves.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And what we are is democratic societies, plural societies, open and tolerant.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: But that tolerance cannot come at the price of our security.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: That is why my Commission has prioritised security from day one – we criminalised terrorism and foreign fighters across the EU, we cracked down on the use of firearms and on terrorist financing, we worked with internet companies to get terrorist propaganda offline and we fought radicalisation in Europe's schools and prisons.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: But there is more to be done.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We need to know who is crossing our borders.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: That is why we will defend our borders with the new European Border and Coast Guard, which is now being formalised by Parliament and Council, just nine months after the Commission proposed it.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Frontex already has over 600 agents on the ground at the borders with Turkey in Greece and over 100 in Bulgaria.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Now, the EU institutions and the Member States should work very closely together to quickly help set up the new Agency.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I want to see at least 200 extra border guards and 50 extra vehicles deployed at the Bulgarian external borders as of October.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We will defend our borders, as well, with strict controls, adopted by the end of the year, on everyone crossing them.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Every time someone enters or exits the EU, there will be a record of when, where and why.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: By November, we will propose a European Travel Information System – an automated system to determine who will be allowed to travel to Europe.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This way we will know who is travelling to Europe before they even get here.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And we all need that information.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: How many times have we heard stories over the last months that the information existed in one database in one country, but it never found its way to the authority in another that could have made the difference?

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Border security also means that information and intelligence exchange must be prioritised.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: For this, we will reinforce Europol – our European agency supporting national law enforcement – by giving it better access to databases and more resources.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: A counter terrorism unit that currently has a staff of 60 cannot provide the necessary 24/7 support.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: A Europe that protects also defends our interests beyond our borders.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The facts are plain: The world is getting bigger.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And we are getting smaller.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Today we Europeans make up 8% of the world population – we will only represent 5% in 2050.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: By then you would not see a single EU country among the top world economies.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: But the EU together?

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We would still be topping the charts.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Our enemies would like us to fragment.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Our competitors would benefit from our division.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Only together are we and will we remain a force to be reckoned with.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Still, even though Europe is proud to be a soft power of global importance, we must not be naïve.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Soft power is not enough in our increasingly dangerous neighbourhood.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Take the brutal fight over Syria.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Its consequences for Europe are immediate.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Attacks in our cities by terrorists trained in Daesh camps.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: But where is the Union, where are its Member States, in negotiations towards a settlement?

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Federica Mogherini, our High Representative and my Vice-President, is doing a fantastic job.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: But she needs to become our European Foreign Minister via whom all diplomatic services, of big and small countries alike, pool their forces to achieve leverage in international negotiations.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This is why I call today for a European Strategy for Syria.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Federica should have a seat at the table when the future of Syria is being discussed.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: So that Europe can help rebuild a peaceful Syrian nation and a pluralistic, tolerant civil society in Syria.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Europe needs to toughen up.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Nowhere is this truer than in our defence policy.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Europe can no longer afford to piggy-back on the military might of others or let France alone defend its honour in Mali.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We have to take responsibility for protecting our interests and the European way of life.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Over the last decade, we have engaged in over 30 civilian and military EU missions from Africa to Afghanistan.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: But without a permanent structure we cannot act effectively.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Urgent operations are delayed.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We have separate headquarters for parallel missions, even when they happen in the same country or city.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: It is time we had a single headquarters for these operations.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We should also move towards common military assets, in some cases owned by the EU.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And, of course, in full complementarity with NATO.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The business case is clear.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The lack of cooperation in defence matters costs Europe between €25 billion and €100 billion per year, depending on the areas concerned.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We could use that money for so much more.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: It can be done.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We are building a multinational fleet of air tankers.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Let's replicate this example.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: For European defence to be strong, the European defence industry needs to innovate.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: That is why we will propose before the end of the year a European Defence Fund, to turbo boost research and innovation.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The Lisbon Treaty enables those Member States who wish, to pool their defence capabilities in the form of a permanent structured cooperation.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I think the time to make use of this possibility is now.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And I hope that our meeting at 27 in Bratislava a few days from now will be the first, political step in that direction.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Because it is only by working together that Europe will be able to defend itself at home and abroad.

speaker: Juncker
sentence:
A EUROPE THAT TAKES RESPONSIBILITY

The last point I want to make is about responsibility.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: About taking responsibility for building this Europe that protects.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I call on all EU institutions and on all of our Member States to take responsibility.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We have to stop with the same old story that success is national, and failure European.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Or our common project will not survive.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We need to remember the sense of purpose of our Union.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I therefore call on each of the 27 leaders making their way to Bratislava to think of three reasons why we need the European Union.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Three things they are willing to take responsibility for defending.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And that they are willing to deliver swiftly afterwards.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Slow delivery on promises made is a phenomenon that more and more risks undermining the Union's credibility.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Take the Paris agreement.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We Europeans are the world leaders on climate action.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: It was Europe that brokered the first-ever legally binding, global climate deal.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: It was Europe that built the coalition of ambition that made agreement in Paris possible.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: But Europe is now struggling to show the way and be amongst the first to ratify our agreement.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Only France, Austria and Hungary have ratified it so far.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I call on all Member States and on this Parliament to do your part in the next weeks, not months.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We should be faster.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Let's get the Paris agreement ratified now.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: It can be done.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: It is a question of political will.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And it is about Europe's global influence.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The European institutions too, have to take responsibility.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I have asked each of my Commissioners to be ready to discuss, in the next two weeks, the State of our Union in the national Parliaments of the countries they each know best.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Since the beginning of my mandate, my Commissioners have made over 350 visits to national Parliaments.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And I want them to do this even more now.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Because Europe can only be built with the Member States, never against them.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We also have to take responsibility in recognising when some decisions are not for us to take.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: It is not right that when EU countries cannot decide among themselves whether or not to ban the use of glyphosate in herbicides, the Commission is forced by Parliament and Council to take a decision.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: So we will change those rules – because that is not democracy.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The Commission has to take responsibility by being political, and not technocratic.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: A political Commission is one that listens to the European Parliament, listens to all Member States, and listens to the people.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And it is us listening that motivated my Commission to withdraw 100 proposals in our first two years of office, to present 80% fewer initiatives than over the past 5 years and to launch a thorough review of all existing legislation.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Because only by focusing on where Europe can provide real added value and deliver results, we will be able to make Europe a better, more trusted place.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Being political also means correcting technocratic mistakes immediately when they happen.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The Commission, the Parliament and the Council have jointly decided to abolish mobile roaming charges.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This is a promise we will deliver.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Not just for business travellers who go abroad for two days.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Not only for the holiday maker who spends two weeks in the sun.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: But for our cross-border workers.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And for the millions of Erasmus students who spend their studies abroad for one or two semesters.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I have therefore withdrawn a draft that a well-meaning official designed over the summer.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The draft was not technically wrong.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: But it missed the point of what was promised.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And you will see a new, better draft as of next week.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: When you roam, it should be like at home.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Being political is also what allows us to implement the Stability and Growth Pact with common sense.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The Pact's creation was influenced by theory.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Its application has become a doctrine for many.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And today, the Pact is a dogma for some.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: In theory, a single decimal point over 60 percent in a country's debt should be punished.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: But in reality, you have to look at the reasons for debt.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We should try to support and not punish ongoing reform efforts.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: For this we need responsible politicians.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And we will continue to apply the Pact not in a dogmatic manner, but with common sense and with the flexibility that we wisely built into the rules.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Finally, taking responsibility also means holding ourselves accountable to voters.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: That is why we will propose to change the absurd rule that Commissioners have to step down from their functions when they want to run in European elections.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The German Chancellor, the Czech, Danish or Estonian, Prime Minister do not stop doing their jobs when they run for re-election.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Neither should Commissioners.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: If we want a Commission that responds to the needs of the real world, we should encourage Commissioners to seek the necessary rendez-vous with democracy.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And not prevent this.

speaker: Juncker
sentence:
CONCLUSION

Honourable Members,

I am as young as the European project that turns 60 next years in March 2017.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I have lived it, worked for it, my whole life.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: My father believed in Europe because he believed in stability, workers' rights and social progress.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Because he understood all too well that peace in Europe was precious – and fragile.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I believe in Europe because my father taught me those same values.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: But what are we teaching our children now?

speaker: Juncker
sentence: What will they inherit from us?

speaker: Juncker
sentence: A Union that unravels in disunity?

speaker: Juncker
sentence: A Union that has forgotten its past and has no vision for the future?

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Our children deserve better.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: They deserve a Europe that preserves their way of life.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: They deserve a Europe that empowers and defends them.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: They deserve a Europe that protects.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: It is time we – the institutions, the governments, the citizens – all took responsibility for building that Europe.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Together.

speaker: Juncker
sentence:
Mr President, Honourable Members of the European Parliament,

When I stood before you this time last year, I had a somewhat easier speech to give.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: It was plain for all to see that our Union was not in a good state.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Europe was battered and bruised by a year that shook our very foundation.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We only had two choices.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Either come together around a positive European agenda or each retreat into our own corners.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Faced with this choice, I argued for unity.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I proposed a positive agenda to help create – as I said last year – a Europe that protects, a Europe that empowers, a Europe that defends.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Over the past twelve months, the European Parliament has helped bring this agenda to life.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We continue to make progress with each passing day.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Just last night you worked to find an agreement on trade defence instruments and on doubling our European investment capacity.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And you succeeded.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Thank you for that.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I also want to thank the 27 leaders of our Member States.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Days after my speech last year, they welcomed my agenda at their summit in Bratislava.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: In doing so they chose unity.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: They chose to rally around our common ground.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Together, we showed that Europe can deliver for its citizens when and where it matters.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Ever since, we have been slowly but surely gathering momentum.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: It helped that the economic outlook swung in our favour.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We are now in the fifth year of an economic recovery that really reaches every single Member State.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Growth in the European Union has outstripped that of the United States over the last two years.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: It now stands above 2% for the Union as a whole and at 2.2% for the monetary area.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Unemployment is at a nine year low.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Almost 8 million jobs have been created during this mandate so far.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: With 235 million people at work, more people are in employment in the European Union than ever before.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The European Commission cannot take the credit for this alone.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Though I am sure that had 8 million jobs been lost, we would have taken the blame.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: But Europe's institutions played their part in helping the wind change.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We can take credit for our European Investment Plan which has triggered €225 billion worth of investment so far.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: It has granted loans to 450,000 small firms and more than 270 infrastructure projects.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We can take credit for the fact that, thanks to determined action, European banks once again have the capital firepower to lend to companies so that they can grow and create jobs.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And we can take credit for having brought public deficits down from 6.6% to 1.6%.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This is thanks to an intelligent application of the Stability and Growth Pact.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We ask for fiscal discipline but are careful not to kill growth.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This is in fact working very well across the Union – despite the criticism.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Ten years since crisis struck, Europe's economy is finally bouncing back.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And with it, our confidence.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Our 27 leaders, the Parliament and the Commission are putting the Europe back in our Union.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And together we are putting the Union back in our Union.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: In the last year, we saw all 27 leaders walk up the Capitoline Hill in Rome, one by one, to renew their vows to each other and to our Union.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: All of this leads me to believe: the wind is back in Europe's sails.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We now have a window of opportunity but it will not stay open forever.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Let us make the most of the momentum, catch the wind in our sails.

speaker: Juncker
sentence:
For this we must do two things:

First, we should stay the course set out last year.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We still have 16 months in which real progress can be made by Parliament, Council and Commission.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We must use this time to finish what we started in Bratislava and deliver on our own positive agenda.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Secondly, we should chart the direction for the future.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: As Mark Twain wrote – I am quoting – years from now we will be more disappointed by the things we did not do, than by those we did.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Now is the time to build a more united, a stronger, a more democratic Europe for 2025.

speaker: Juncker
sentence:
STAYING COURSE

Mr President, Honourable Members,

As we look to the future, we cannot let ourselves be blown off course.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We set out to complete an Energy Union, a Security Union, a Capital Markets Union, a Banking Union and a Digital Single Market.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Together, we have already come a long way.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: As the Parliament testified, 80% of the proposals promised at the start of the mandate have already been put forward by the Commission.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We must now work together to turn proposals into law, and law into practice.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: As ever, there will be a degree of give and take.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The Commission's proposals to reform our Common Asylum System and strengthen rules on the Posting of Workers have caused controversy, I know.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Achieving a good result will need all sides to do their part so they can move towards each other.

speaker: Juncker
sentence:
I want to say today: as long as the outcome is the right one for our Union and is fair to all its Member States, the Commission will be open to compromise

We are now ready to put the remaining 20% of initiatives on the table by May 2018.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This morning, I sent a Letter of Intent to the President of the European Parliament and to the Prime Minister of Estonia – whose strong work for Europe I would like to praise – outlining the priorities for the year ahead.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I will not and I cannot list all these proposals here, but let me mention five which are particularly important.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Firstly, I want us to strengthen our European trade agenda.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Yes, Europe is open for business.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: But there must be reciprocity.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We have to get what we give.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Trade is not something abstract.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Trade is about jobs, creating new opportunities for Europe's businesses big and small.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Every additional €1 billion in exports supports 14,000 extra jobs in Europe.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Trade is about exporting our standards, be they social or environmental standards, data protection or food safety requirements.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Europe has always been an attractive place to do business.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: But over the last year, partners across the globe are lining up at our door to conclude trade agreements with us.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: With the help of this Parliament, we have just secured a trade agreement with Canada that will provisionally apply as of next week.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We have a political agreement with Japan on a future economic partnership.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And by the end of the year, we have a good chance of doing the same with Mexico and South American countries.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Today, we are proposing to open trade negotiations with Australia and New Zealand.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I want all of these agreements to be finalised by the end of this mandate.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And I want them negotiated in the greatest transparency.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Open trade must go hand in hand with open policy making.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The European Parliament will have the final say on all trade agreements.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: So its Members, like members of national and regional parliaments, must be kept fully informed from day one of the negotiations.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The Commission will make sure of this.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: From now on, the Commission will publish in full all draft negotiating mandates we propose to the Council.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Citizens have the right to know what the Commission is proposing.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Gone are the days of no transparency.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Gone are the days of rumours, of incessantly questioning the Commission's motives.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I call on the Council to do the same when it adopts the final negotiating mandates.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Let me say once and for all: we are not naïve free traders.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Europe must always defend its strategic interests.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This is why today we are proposing a new EU framework for investment screening.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: If a foreign, state-owned, company wants to purchase a European harbour, part of our energy infrastructure or a defence technology firm, this should only happen in transparency, with scrutiny and debate.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: It is a political responsibility to know what is going on in our own backyard so that we can protect our collective security if needed.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Secondly, the Commission wants to make our industry stronger and more competitive.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This is particularly true for our manufacturing base and the 32 million workers that form its backbone.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: They make the world-class products that give us our edge, like our cars.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I am proud of our car industry.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: But I am shocked when consumers are knowingly and deliberately misled.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I call on the car industry to come clean and make it right.

speaker: Juncker
sentence:
Instead of looking for loopholes, they should be investing in the clean cars of tomorrow

Honourable Members, the new Industrial Policy Strategy we are presenting today will help our industries stay, or become, the number one in innovation, digitisation and decarbonisation.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Third: I want Europe to be the leader when it comes to the fight against climate change.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Last year, we set the global rules of the game with the Paris Agreement ratified here, in this very House.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Set against the collapse of ambition in the United States, Europe must ensure we make our planet great again.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: It is the shared heritage of all of humanity.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The Commission will shortly present proposals to reduce the carbon emissions of our transport sector.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Fourth priority for the year ahead: I want us to better protect Europeans in the digital age.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Over the past years, we have made marked progress in keeping Europeans safe online.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: New rules, put forward by the Commission, will protect our intellectual property, our cultural diversity and our personal data.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We have stepped up the fight against terrorist propaganda and radicalisation online.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: But Europe is still not well equipped when it comes to cyber-attacks.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Cyber-attacks can be more dangerous to the stability of democracies and economies than guns and tanks.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Last year alone there were more than 4,000 ransomware attacks per day and 80% of European companies experienced at least one cyber-security incident.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Cyber-attacks know no borders and no one is immune.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This is why, today, the Commission is proposing new tools, including a European Cybersecurity Agency, to help defend us against such attacks.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Fifth: migration must stay on our radar.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: In spite of the debate and controversy around this topic, we have managed to make solid progress – though admittedly insufficient in many areas.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We are now protecting Europe's external borders more effectively.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Over 1,700 officers from the new European Border and Coast Guard are now helping Member States' 100,000 national border guards patrol in places like Greece, Italy, Bulgaria and Spain.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We have common borders but Member States that by geography are the first in line cannot be left alone to protect them.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Common borders and common protection must go hand in hand.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We have managed to stem irregular flows of migrants, which were a cause of great anxiety for many.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We have reduced irregular arrivals in the Eastern Mediterranean by 97% thanks our agreement with Turkey.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And this summer, we managed to get more control over the Central Mediterranean route with arrivals in August down by 81% compared to the same month last year.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: In doing so, we have drastically reduced the loss of life in the Mediterranean.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I cannot talk about migration without paying strong tribute to Italy for their tireless and noble work.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Over the summer months, the Commission worked in perfect harmony with the Prime Minister of Italy, my friend Paolo Gentiloni, and his government to improve the situation.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We did so - and we will continue to do so - because Italy is saving Europe's honour in the Mediterranean.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We must also urgently improve migrants' living conditions in Libya.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I am appalled by the inhumane conditions in detention or reception centres.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Europe has a responsibility – a collective responsibility – and the Commission will work in concert with the United Nations to put an end to this scandalous situation that cannot be made to last.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Even if it saddens me to see that solidarity is not yet equally shared across all our Member States, Europe as a whole has continued to show solidarity.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Last year alone, our Member States resettled or granted asylum to over 720,000 refugees – three times as much as the United States, Canada and Australia combined.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Europe, contrary to what some say, is not a fortress and must never become one.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Europe is and must remain the continent of solidarity where those fleeing persecution can find refuge.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I am particularly proud of the young Europeans volunteering to give language courses to Syrian refugees or the thousands more young people who are serving in our new European Solidarity Corps.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: These young people are bringing life and colour to European solidarity.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: But we now need to redouble our efforts.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: At the end of the month, the Commission will present a new set of proposals with an emphasis on returns, solidarity with Africa and opening legal pathways.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: When it comes to returns, I would like to repeat that people who have no right to stay in Europe must be returned to their countries of origin.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: When only 36% of irregular migrants are returned, it is clear we need to significantly step up our work.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This is the only way Europe will be able to show solidarity with refugees in real need of protection.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Solidarity cannot be an exclusively intra-European affair.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We must also showsolidarity withAfrica.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Africa is a noble continent, a young continent, the cradle of humanity.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Our €2.7 billion EU-Africa Trust Fund is creating employment opportunities across the continent.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The EU budget fronted the bulk of the money, but all our Member States combined have still only contributed €150 million.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The Fund is currently reaching its limits.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We know – or we should know – the dangers of a lack of funding – in 2015 many migrants headed towards Europe when the UN's World Food Programme ran out of funds.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I call on all Member States to now match their actions with their words and ensure the Africa Trust Fund does not meet the same fate.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The risk is high.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We will also work on opening up legal pathways.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Irregular migration will only stop if there is a real alternative to perilous journeys.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We are close to having resettled 22,000 refugees from Turkey, Jordan and Lebanon and I support UN High Commissioner for Refugees' call to resettle a further 40,000 refugees from Libya and the surrounding countries.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: At the same time, legal migration is an absolute necessity for Europe as an ageing continent.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This is why the Commission made proposals to make it easier for skilled migrants to reach Europe with a Blue Card.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I would like to thank the Parliament for its support on this.

speaker: Juncker
sentence:
SETTING SAIL

Dear Mr President, Ladies and Gentlemen,

Honourable Members,

I have mentioned just a few of the initiatives we want and must deliver over the next 16 months.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: But this alone will not be enough to regain the hearts and minds of Europeans.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Now is the time to chart the direction for the future.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: In March, the Commission presented our White Paper on the future of Europe, with five scenarios for what Europe could look like by 2025.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: These scenarios have been discussed, sometimes superficially, sometimes violently.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: They have been scrutinised and partly ripped apart.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: That is good – they were conceived for exactly this purpose.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I wanted to launch a process in which Europeans determined their own path and their own future.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The future of Europe cannot be decided by decree.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: It has to be the result of democratic debate and, ultimately, broad consensus.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This House contributed actively, through the three ambitious resolutions on Europe's future which I would like to particularly thank the rapporteurs for.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And I want to thank all the colleagues that participated in the more than 2,000 public events across Europe that the Commission organised since March.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Now is the time to draw first conclusions from this debate.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Time to move from reflection to action.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: From debate to decision.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Today I would like to present you my view: my own 'sixth scenario', if you will.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This scenario is rooted in decades of first-hand experience.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I have lived, fought and worked for the European project my entire life.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I have seen and lived through good times and bad.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I have sat on many different sides of the table: as a Minister, as Prime Minister, as President of the Eurogroup, and now as President of the Commission.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I was there in Maastricht, Amsterdam, Nice and Lisbon as our Union evolved and enlarged.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I have always fought for Europe.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: At times I have suffered because of Europe.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And even despaired for Europe.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Through thick and thin, I have never lost my love of Europe.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: But there is, as we know, rarely love without pain.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Love for Europe because Europe and the European Union have achieved something unique in this fraying world: peace within and peace outside of Europe.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Prosperity for many if not yet for all.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This is something we have to remember during the European Year of Cultural Heritage.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: 2018 must be a celebration of cultural diversity.

speaker: Juncker
sentence:
A UNION OF VALUES

Our values are our compass.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: For me, Europe is more than just a single market.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: More than money, more than a currency, more than the euro.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: It was always about values.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: That is why, in my sixth scenario, there are three fundamentals, three unshakeable principles: freedom, equality and the rule of law.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Europe is first of all a Union of freedom.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Freedom from the kind of oppression and dictatorship our continent knows all too well – sadly none more than central and Eastern European countries.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Freedom to voice your opinion, as a citizen and as a journalist – a freedom we too often take for granted.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: It was on these freedoms that our Union was built.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: But freedom does not fall from the sky.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: It must be fought for.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: In Europe and throughout the world.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Second, Europe must be a Union of equality and a Union of equals.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Equality between its Members, big or small, East or West, North or South.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Make no mistake, Europe extends from Vigo to Varna.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: From Spain to Bulgaria.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: East to West: Europe must breathe with both lungs.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Otherwise our continent will struggle for air.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: In a Union of equals, there can be no second class citizens.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: It is unacceptable that in 2017 there are still children dying of diseases that should long have been eradicated in Europe.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Children in Romania or Italy must have the same access to measles vaccines as children in other European countries.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: No ifs, no buts.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This is why we are working with all Member States to support national vaccination efforts.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Avoidable deaths must not occur in Europe.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: In a Union of equals, there can be no second class workers.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Workers should earn the same pay for the same work in the same place.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This is why the Commission proposed new rules on posting of workers.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We should make sure that all EU rules on labour mobility are enforced in a fair, simple and effective way by a new European inspection and enforcement body.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: It is absurd to have a Banking Authority to police banking standards, but no common Labour Authority for ensuring fairness in our single market.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We will create such an Authority.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: In a Union of equals, there can be no second class consumers either.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I cannot accept that in some parts of Europe, in Central and Eastern Europe,people are sold food of lower quality than in other countries, despite the packaging and branding being identical.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Slovaks do not deserve less fish in their fish fingers.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Hungarians less meat in their meals.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Czechs less cacao in their chocolate.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: EU law outlaws such practices already.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And we must now equip national authorities with stronger powers to cut out these illegal practices wherever they exist.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Third, in Europe the strength of the law replaced the law of the strong.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The rule of law means that law and justice are upheld by an independent judiciary.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Accepting and respecting a final judgement is what it means to be part of a Union based on the rule of law.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Our Member States gave final jurisdiction to the European Court of Justice.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The judgements of the Court have to be respected by all.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: To undermine them, or to undermine the independence of national courts, is to strip citizens of their fundamental rights.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The rule of law is not optional in the European Union.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: It is a must.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Our Union is not a State but it must be a community of law.

speaker: Juncker
sentence:
A MORE UNITED UNION

These three principles – freedom, equality and the rule of law – must remain the foundations on which we build a more united, stronger and more democratic Union.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: When we talk about the future, experience tells me new Treaties and new institutions are not the answer people are looking for.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: They are merely a means to an end, nothing more, nothing less.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: They might mean something to us here in Strasbourg or in Brussels.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: They do not mean a lot to anyone else.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I am only interested in institutional reforms if they lead to more efficiency in our European Union.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Instead of hiding behind calls for Treaty change – which is in any case inevitable – we must first change the mind-set that for some to win others must lose.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Democracy is about compromise.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And the right compromise makes winners out of everyone in the long run.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: A more united Union should see compromise, not as something negative, but as the art of bridging differences.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Democracy cannot function without compromise.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Europe cannot function without compromise.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: A more united Union also needs to become more inclusive.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: If we want to protect our external borders and rightly so strengthen them even more, then we need to open the Schengen area of free movement to Bulgaria and Romania immediately.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We should also allow Croatia to become a full Schengen member once all the criteria are met.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: If we want the euro to unite rather than divide our continent, then it should be more than the currency of a select group of countries.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The euro is meant to be the single currency of the European Union as a whole.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: All but two of our Member States are required and entitled to join the euro once they fulfil the conditions.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Member States that want to join the euro must be able to do so.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This is why I am proposing to create a Euro-accession Instrument, offering technical and even financial assistance.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: If we want banks to operate under the same rules and under the same supervision across our continent, then we should encourage all Member States to join the Banking Union.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We need to reduce the remaining risks in the banking systems of some of our Member States.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Banking Union can only function if risk-reduction and risk-sharing go hand in hand.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: As everyone well knows, this can only be achieved if the conditions, as proposed by the Commission in November 2015, are met.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: There can only be a common deposit insurance scheme once everyone will have done their national homework.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And if we want to avoid social fragmentation and social dumping in Europe, then Member States should agree on the European Pillar of Social Rights as soon as possible and at the latest at the Gothenburg summit in November.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: National social systems will still remain diverse and separate for a long time.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: But at the very least, we should agree on a European Social Standards Union in which we have a common understanding of what is socially fair in our single market.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I remain convinced: Europe cannot work if it shuns workers.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Ladies and Gentlemen, if we want more stability in our neighbourhood, then we must also maintain a credible enlargement perspective for the Western Balkans.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: It is clear that there will be no further enlargement during the mandate of this Commission and this Parliament.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: No candidate is ready.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: But thereafter the European Union will be greater than 27 in number.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Accession candidates must give the rule of law, justice and fundamental rights utmost priority in the negotiations.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This rules out EU membership for Turkey for the foreseeable future.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Turkey has been taking giant strides away from the European Union for some time.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Journalists belong in newsrooms not in prisons.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: They belong where freedom of expression reigns.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The call I make to those in power in Turkey is this: Let our journalists go.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And not only ours.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Stop insulting our Member States by comparing their leaders to fascists and Nazis.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Europe is a continent of mature democracies.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: But deliberate insults create roadblocks.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Sometimes I get the feeling Turkey is deliberately placing these roadblocks so that it can blame Europe for any breakdown in accession talks.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: As for us, we will always keep our hands stretched out towards the great Turkish people and all those who are ready to work with us on the basis of our values.

speaker: Juncker
sentence:
A STRONGER UNION

Ladies and Gentlemen,

I want our Union to be stronger and for this we need a stronger single market.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: When it comes to important single market questions, I want decisions in the Council to be taken more often and more easily by qualified majority – with the equal involvement of the European Parliament.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We do not need to change the Treaties for this.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: There are so-called “passerelle clauses” in the current Treaties which allow us to move from unanimity to qualified majority voting in certain cases – provided the European Council decides unanimously to do so.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I am also strongly in favour of moving to qualified majority voting for decisions on the common consolidated corporate tax base, on VAT, on fair taxes for the digital industry and on the financial transaction tax.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Europe has to be able to act quicker and more decisively, and this also applies to theEconomic and Monetary Union.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The euro area is more resilient now than in years past.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We now have the European Stabilisation Mechanism (ESM).

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I believe the ESM should now progressively graduate into a European Monetary Fund which, however, must be firmly anchored in the European Union's rules and competences.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The Commission will make concrete proposals for this in December.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We need a European Minister of Economy and Finance: a European Minister that promotes and supports structural reforms in our Member States.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: He or she can build on the work the Commission has been doing since 2015 with our Structural Reform Support Service.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The new Minister should coordinate all EU financial instruments that can be deployed if a Member State is in a recession or hit by a fundamental crisis.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I am not calling for a new position just for the sake of it.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I am calling for efficiency.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The Commissioner for economic and financial affairs – ideally also a Vice-President – should assume the role of Economy and Finance Minister.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: He or she should also preside the Eurogroup.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The European Economy and Finance Minister must be accountable to the European Parliament.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We do not need parallel structures.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We do not need a budget for the Euro area but a strong Euro area budget line within the EU budget.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I am also not fond of the idea of having a separate euro area parliament.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The Parliament of the euro area is this European Parliament.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The European Union must also be stronger in fighting terrorism.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: In the past three years, we have made real progress.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: But we still lack the means to act quickly in case of cross-border terrorist threats.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This is why I call for setting up a European intelligence unit that ensures data concerning terrorists and foreign fighters are automatically shared among intelligence services and with the police.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I also see a strong case for tasking the new European Public Prosecutor with prosecuting cross-border terrorist crimes.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I want our Union to become a stronger global actor.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: In order to have more weight in the world, we must be able to take foreign policy decisions quicker.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This is why I want Member States to look at which foreign policy decisions could be moved from unanimity to qualified majority voting.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The Treaty already provides for this, if all Member States agree to do it.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We need qualified majority decisions in foreign policy if we are to work efficiently.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And I want us to dedicate further efforts to defence matters.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: A new European Defence Fund is in the offing.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: As is a Permanent Structured Cooperation in the area of defence.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: By 2025 we need a fully-fledged European Defence Union.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We need it.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And NATO wants it.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Last but not least, I want our Union to have a stronger focus on things that matter, building on the work this Commission has already undertaken.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We should not meddle in the everyday lives of European citizens by regulating every aspect.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We should be big on the big things.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We should not march in with a stream of new initiatives or seek ever growing competences.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We should give back competences to Member States where it makes sense.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This is why this Commission has sought to be big on big issues and small on the small ones and has done so, putting forward less than 25 new initiatives a year where previous Commissions proposed well over 100.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: To finish the work we started, I am setting up a Subsidiarity and Proportionality Task Force as of this month to take a very critical look at all policy areas to make sure we are only acting where the EU adds value.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The First Vice-President, my friend, Frans Timmermans, who has a proven track record on better regulation, will head this Task Force.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The Timmermans Task Force should include Members of this Parliament as well as Members of national Parliaments.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: It should report back in a years' time.

speaker: Juncker
sentence:
A MORE DEMOCRATIC UNION

Honourable Members,

Mr President,

Our Union needs to take a democratic leap forward.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I would like to see European political parties start campaigning for the next European elections much earlier than in the past.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Too often Europe-wide elections have been reduced to nothing more than the sum of national campaigns.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: European democracy deserves better.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Today, the Commission is proposing new rules on the financing of political parties and foundations.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We should not be filling the coffers of anti-European extremists.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We should be giving European parties the means to better organise themselves.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I also have sympathy for the idea of having transnational lists in European elections – though I am aware this is an idea more than a few of you disagree with.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I will seek to convince the President of my parliamentary Group to follow me in this ambition which will bring Europe democracy and clarity.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I also believe that, over the months to come, we should involve national Parliaments and civil society at national, regional and local level more in the work on the future of Europe.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Over the last three years, as we promised, Members of the Commission have visited national Parliaments more than 650 times.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: They also debated in more than 300 interactive Citizens' Dialogues in more than 80 cities and towns across 27 Member States.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This is why I support President Macron's idea of organising democratic conventions across Europe in 2018.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: As the debate gathers pace, I will personally pay particular attention to Estonia, to Latvia, to Lithuania and to Romania in 2018.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This is the year they will celebrate their 100th anniversary.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Those who want to shape the future of our continent should well understand and honour our common history.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This includes these four countries – the European Union would not be whole without them.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The need to strengthen democracy and transparency also has implications for the European Commission.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Today, I am sending the European Parliament a new Code of Conduct for Commissioners.

speaker: Juncker
