sentence: The new Code first of all makes clear that Commissioners can be candidates in European Parliament elections under the same conditions as everyone else.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The new Code will of course strengthen the integrity requirements for Commissioners both during and after their mandate.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: If you want to strengthen European democracy, then you cannot reverse the small democratic progress seen with the creation of lead candidates – 'Spitzenkandidaten'.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I would like the experience to be repeated.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: More democracy means more efficiency.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Europe would function better if we were to merge the Presidents of the European Council and the European Commission.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This is nothing against my good friend Donald, with whom I have worked intimately and seamlessly together since the beginning of my mandate.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This is nothing against Donald or against me.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Europe would be easier to understand if one captain was steering the ship.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Having a single President would simply better reflect the true nature of our European Union as both a Union of States and a Union of citizens.

speaker: Juncker
sentence:
OUR ROADMAP

My dear colleagues,

The vision of a more united, stronger and more democratic Europe I am outlining today combines elements from all of the scenarios I set out to you in March.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: But our future cannot remain a simple scenario, a sketch, an idea amongst others.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We have to prepare the Union of tomorrow, today.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This morning I sent a Roadmap to President Tajani, President Tusk as well as to the holders of the rotating Presidencies of the Council between now and March 2019, outlining where we should go from here.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: An important element will be the budgetary plans the Commission will present in May 2018.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Here again we have a choice: either we pursue the European Union's ambitions in the strict framework of the existing budget, or we increase the European Union's budgetary capacity so that it might better reach its ambitions.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I am for the second option.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: On 29 March 2019, the United Kingdom will leave the European Union.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This will be both a sad and tragic moment.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We will always regret it.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: But we have to respect the will of the British people.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We will advance, we must advance because Brexit is not everything.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Because Brexit is not the future of Europe.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: On 30 March 2019, we will be a Union of 27.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I suggest that we prepare for this moment well, amongst the 27 and within the EU institutions.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: European Parliament elections will take place just a few weeks later, in May 2019.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Europeans have a date with democracy.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: They need to go to the polls with a clear understanding of how the European Union will develop over the years to come.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This is why I call on President Tusk and Romania, the country holding the Presidency in the first half of 2019, to organise a Special Summit in Romania on 30 March 2019.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: My wish is that this summit be held in the beautiful city of Sibiu, also known as Hermannstadt.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This should be the moment we come together to take the decisions needed for a more united, stronger and democratic Europe.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: My hope is that on 30 March 2019, Europeans will wake up to a Union where we stand by all our values.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Where all Member States respect the rule of law without exception.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Where being a full member of the euro area, the Banking Union and the Schengen area has become the norm for all.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Where we have shored up the foundations of our Economic and Monetary Union so that we can defend our single currency in good times and bad, without having to call on external help.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Where our single market will be fairer towards workers from the East and from the West.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I want Europeans to wake up to a Europe where we have managed to agree on a strong pillar of social standards.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Where profits will be taxed where they were made.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Where terrorists have no loopholes to exploit.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Where we have agreed on a proper European Defence Union.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Where eventually a single President leads the work of the Commission and the European Council, having been elected after a democratic Europe-wide election campaign.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Mr President, if our citizens wake up to this Union on 30 March 2019, then the European Union will be a Union able to meet their legitimate expectations.

speaker: Juncker
sentence:
CONCLUSION

Honourable Members,

Europe was not made to stand still.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: It must never do so.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Helmut Kohl and Jacques Delors, whom I had the honour to know, taught me that Europe only moves forward when it is bold.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The single market, Schengen and the single currency: these were all ideas that were written off as pipe dreams before they happened.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And yet these three ambitious projects are now a part of our daily reality.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Now that Europe is doing better, people tell me I should not rock the boat.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: But now is not the time to err on the side of caution.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We started to fix the European roof.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: But today and tomorrow we must patiently, floor by floor, moment by moment, inspiration by inspiration, continue to add new floors to the European House.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We must complete the European House now that the sun is shining and whilst it still is.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Because when the next clouds appear on the horizon – and they will appear one day – it will be too late.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: So let's throw off the bowlines.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Sail away from the harbour.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And catch the trade winds in our sails.

speaker: Juncker
sentence:
INTRODUCTION: A PERPETUAL RESPONSIBILITY

 

Mr President,

Madam President of the Council,

Honourable Members of the European Parliament,

At times, history moves forward only haltingly but it is always quick to pass us by.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Such is the fate of a Commission with just a five-year mandate to make a real difference.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: In such a short space of time, it is not possible to change the course of things definitively.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This Commission – like those that have gone before – is merely a chapter, a brief moment in the long history of the European Union.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: But the time has not yet come to pass judgement on the Commission over which I preside.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This is why I will not today present you with an overview of the last four years' achievements.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Instead, I say to you that our efforts will continue unabated over the coming months to render this imperfect Union that little bit more perfect with each passing day.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: There is much still to be done.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And this is what I want to talk to you about this morning.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: No self-congratulating, no boasting.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Modesty and hard work: this is the attitude the Commission will continue to adopt.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This is what is on our agenda for the months to come.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: History - in the true sense of the term - can also show up, unannounced, in the life of nations and be slow to leave.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Such was the fate of Europe's nations during the Great War starting in 1914.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: A war which took the sunny, optimistic and peaceful continent of the time by surprise.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: In 1913, Europeans expected to live a lasting peace.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And yet, just a year later, a brutal war broke out amongst brothers, engulfing the continent.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I speak of these times not because I believe we are on the brink of another catastrophe in Europe.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: But because Europe is the guardian of peace.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We should be thankful we live on a peaceful continent, made possible by the European Union.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: So let us show the European Union a bit more respect.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Let us stop dragging its name through the mud and start defending our communal way of life more.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We should embrace the kind of patriotism that is used for good, and never against others.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We should reject the kind of exaggerated nationalism that projects hate and destroys all in its path.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The kind of nationalism that points the finger at others instead of searching for ways to better live together.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Living up to Europe's rallying cry – never again war – is our eternal duty, our perpetual responsibility.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We must all remain vigilant.

speaker: Juncker
sentence:
THE STATE OF OUR UNION IN 2018

EFFORTS THAT ARE BEARING FRUIT

Honourable Members of the European Parliament,

What is the State of the Union today, in 2018?

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Ten years after Lehman Brothers, Europe has largely turned the page on an economic and financial crisis which came from outside but which cut deep at home.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Europe's economy has now grown for 21 consecutive quarters.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Jobs have returned, with almost 12 million new jobs created since 2014.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: 12 million – that is more jobs than there are people in Belgium.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Never have so many men and women – 239 million people – been in work in Europe.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Youth unemployment is at 14.8 %.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This is still too high a figure but is the lowest it has been since the year 2000.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Investment is back, thanks notably to our European Fund for Strategic Investments, which some – less and less – still call the ‘Juncker Fund'.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: A Fund that has triggered 335 billion euro worth of public and private investment.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We are closing in on 400 billion.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And then there is Greece.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: After what can only be described as some very painful years, marked by unprecedented social hardship, Greece successfully exited its programme and is now back on its own two feet.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I once again applaud the people of Greece for their Herculean efforts.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Efforts which other Europeans continue to underestimate.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: As you know, I have always fought for Greece, its dignity, its role in Europe, and its place inside the euro area.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Of this I am proud.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Europe has also reaffirmed its position as a trade power.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Our global trading position is the living proof of the need to share sovereignty.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The European Union now has trade agreements with 70 countries around the world, covering 40 % of the world's GDP.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: These agreements – so often contested but often unjustly – help us export Europe's high standards for food safety, workers' rights, the environment and consumer rights far beyond our borders.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: When, amidst dangerous global tensions, I went to Beijing, Tokyo and Washington in the space of one week last July, I was able to speak, as President of the European Commission, on behalf of the world's biggest single market.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: On behalf of a Union accounting for a fifth of the world's economy.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: On behalf of a Union willing to stand up for its values and interests.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I showed Europe to be an open continent.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: But not a naïve one.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The strength of a united Europe, both in principle and in practice, gave me the clout I needed to get tangible results for citizens and businesses alike.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: United, as a Union, Europe is a force to be reckoned with.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: In Washington, I spoke in Europe's name.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: For some, the agreement I struck with President Trump came as a surprise.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: But it was no surprise – as whenever Europe speaks with one voice, there is never any surprise.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: When Europe speaks with one voice, it can prevail.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: When needed, Europe must act as one.

speaker: Juncker
sentence:
A GLOBAL RESPONSIBILITY

We proved this when relentlessly defending the Paris Agreement on climate change.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We did this because, as Europeans, we want to leave a healthier planet behind for those that follow.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I share our Energy Commissioner's conclusions when it comes to our targets for reducing CO2 emissions by 2030.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: They are both scientifically accurate and politically indispensable.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This summer's droughts are a stark reminder – not only for farmers – of just how important that work is to safeguard the future for generations of Europeans.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We obviously cannot turn a blind eye to the climate challenge.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We – Commission and Parliament – must look to the future.

speaker: Juncker
sentence:
Ladies and Gentlemen,

The world has not stopped turning.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: It is more volatile than ever.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The external challenges facing our continent are multiplying by the day.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: There can therefore be not a moment's respite in our efforts to build a stronger and more united Europe.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Europe can export stability, as we have done with the successive enlargements of our Union.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: For me, these are and will remain success stories – for we were able to reconcile Europe's history and geography.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: But there is more to be done.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We must find unity when it comes to the Western Balkans and their future membership.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Should we not, our immediate neighbourhood will be shaped by others.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Take a look around.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: What is happening in Syria, in Idlib, now must be of deep and direct concern to us all.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We cannot remain silent in face of this impending humanitarian disaster – which appears now all but inevitable.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The conflict in Syria is a case in point for how the international order that served Europeans so well after the Second World War is being increasingly called into question.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: In today's world, Europe can no longer be certain that words given yesterday can still be counted on today.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: That old alliances may not look the same tomorrow.

speaker: Juncker
sentence:
THE HOUR OF EUROPEAN SOVEREIGNTY

As I have said, the world today needs a strong and united Europe.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: A Europe that works for peace, trade agreements and stable currency relations, even as others become rather too prone to trade and currency wars.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I am not in favour of a selfish unilateralism that defies expectations and dashes hopes.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I will always firmly champion multilateralism.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: If Europe were better aware of the political, economic and military might of its nations, its role in the world could be strengthened.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We will always be a global payer but it is time we started being a global player too.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This is why – despite great resistance at the time – I reignited the Europe of Defence as early as 2014.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And this is why I will continue to work day and night over the next months to see the European Defence Fund and Permanent Structured Cooperation in Defence become fully operational.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Allow me to clarify one important point: we will not militarise the European Union.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: What we want is to become more autonomous and live up to our global responsibilities.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Only a strong and united Europe can protect our citizens against threats internal and external – from terrorism to climate change.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Only a strong and united Europe can protect jobs in an open, interconnected world.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Only a strong and united Europe can master the challenges of global digitisation.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: It is because of our single market – the largest in the world – that we can set standards for big data, artificial intelligence, and automation.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And that we are able to uphold Europeans' values, rights and identities in doing so.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: But we can only do so if we stand united.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: A strong and united Europe is what allows its Member States to reach for the stars.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: It is our Galileo programme that is today keeping Europe in the space race.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: No single Member State – none – could have put 26 satellites in orbit, for the benefit of 400 million users worldwide.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: No single Member State could have done this alone.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Galileo is a success – in great part, if not entirely, thanks to Europe.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: No Europe, no Galileo.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We should be proud.

speaker: Juncker
sentence:
Mr President,

The geopolitical situation makes this Europe's hour: the time for European sovereignty has come.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: It is time Europe took its destiny into its own hands.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: It is time Europe developed what I coined ‘Weltpolitikfähigkeit' – the capacity to play our role in shaping global affairs.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Europe has to become a more sovereign actor in international relations.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: European sovereignty is born of Member States' national sovereignty and does not replace it.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Sharing sovereignty – when and where needed – makes each of our States and nations stronger.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This belief that ‘united we stand taller' is the very essence of what it means to be part of the European Union.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: European sovereignty can never be to the detriment of others.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Europe is a continent of openness and tolerance.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And it will remain so.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Europe will never be a fortress, turning its back on the world or those suffering within it.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Europe is not an island.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: It must and will champion multilateralism.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Because the world we live in belongs to all and not a select few.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This is what is at stake when Europeans take to the polls in May next year.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We will use the 250 days before the European elections to prove to citizens that, acting as one, this Union is capable of delivering on expectations and on what we promised to achieve at the start of this mandate.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: By the elections, we must show that Europe can overcome differences between North and South, East and West.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The European Union – Europe – is too small to let itself be divided in halves or quarters.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We must show that together – East, West, South and North – we can plant the seeds of a more sovereign Europe.

speaker: Juncker
sentence:
DELIVERING ON OUR PROMISES

Mr President,

Ladies and Gentlemen,

Europeans taking to the polls in May 2019 will not care what the Commission has proposed.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: But they will care strongly about internet giants paying taxes where they make their profits.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: What the voters want – and a good many of you too; not all, I know – is for the Commission's proposal to become law quickly.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And they are quite right.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Europeans taking to the polls in May 2019 will not care about the Commission's good intention to crack down on single-use plastics to protect our oceans against marine litter.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: To get Europeans on our side and convince them that what we are doing is right, we need a European law that bans these plastics to be actually in force.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We all say – usually in soap-box speeches – that we want to be big on big things and small on small things.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: But there will be no applause in May 2019 when EU law dictates that Europeans have to continue to change their clocks twice a year.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Clock-changing must stop.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Member States should themselves decide whether their citizens live in summer or winter time.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: It is a question of subsidiarity.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I expect the Parliament and Council will share this view and will ensure that regional solutions are found that work for the internal market.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We are out of time.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This is why I am today calling on all to work closely together over the next months, so that we can jointly deliver on what we promised in 2014 – before the European Parliament elections.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: At the beginning of this mandate, we all collectively promised to deliver a more innovative Digital Single Market, a deeper Economic and Monetary Union, a Banking Union, a Capital Markets Union, a fairer Single Market, an Energy Union with a forward-looking climate policy, a comprehensive Migration Agenda, and a Security Union.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And we – or at least most of us – resolved that the social dimension of Europe should no longer be given Cinderella treatment, but should be geared towards the future.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The Commission has put all the proposals and initiatives we announced in 2014 on the table.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Half of them have been adopted by Parliament and the Council.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: 20 % are well on the way.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And 30 % are still under discussion – in some cases difficult discussion.

speaker: Juncker
sentence:
Ladies and Gentlemen,

I cannot accept that the blame for every failure – and of course there have been a few – is laid solely at the Commission's door.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Our proposals are there for all to see, in particular as regards refugees and migration.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: They need to be adopted and implemented.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Whatever happens, I will continue to resist all attempts to blame the Commission alone – and I already know this will happen.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: There are scapegoats to be found in all the institutions – with the fewest in Commission and Parliament.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Leadership on the broadest front is what is needed now.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This is notably the case when it comes to completing our Security Union.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Europeans rightly expect their Union to keep them safe.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This is why the Commission is today proposing new rules to get terrorist content off the web within one hour – the critical window in which the greatest damage can be done.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And we are proposing to extend the tasks of the newly established European Public Prosecutor's Office to include the fight against terrorist offences.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We need to be able to prosecute terrorists in a more coordinated way, across our Union.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Terrorists know no borders.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We cannot allow ourselves to become unwitting accomplices because of our inability to cooperate.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: In the same vein, we have also today proposed new measures to allow us to fight money laundering more effectively across our borders.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We must be equally committed to ensuring free and fair elections in Europe.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This is why the Commission is proposing new rules to better protect our democratic processes from manipulation by third countries and, as we have already seen, powerful private interests.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Leadership and a spirit of compromise are of course very much needed when it comes to migration.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We have made more progress on this than is often acknowledged.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Five of the seven Commission proposals to reform our Common European Asylum System have been agreed.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Our efforts to manage migration have borne fruit, with migrant numbers down by 97 % in the Eastern Mediterranean and by 80 % along the Central Mediterranean route.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: EU operations have helped rescue over 690,000 people at sea since 2015.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: However, Member States have not yet found the right balance between the responsibility each must assume on its own territory and the solidarity all must show if we are to preserve a Schengen area without internal borders.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I am and will remain strictly opposed to internal borders.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Where borders have been reinstated, they must be removed.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Failure to do so would amount to an unacceptable step back for the Europe of today and tomorrow.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The Commission and several Council presidencies have put numerous migration related proposals on the table.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I call on the Austrian presidency to now take the decisive step to broker a sustainable solution on a balanced migration reform.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I know that it will do so.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We cannot continue to squabble to find ad hoc solutions each time a new ship arrives.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Temporary solidarity is not good enough.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We need more, better organised, lasting solidarity – today and forever more.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We need more solidarity not for solidarity's sake but for the sake of efficiency.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This is true in the case of our civil protection mechanism.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: When fires rage in one European country, all of Europe burns.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The most striking images from this summer were not only those of the formidable fires, but also those of the Swedish people in danger applauding Polish firefighters coming to their aid – Europe at its best.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Turning back to migration: the Commission is today proposing to further strengthen the European Border and Coast Guard to better protect our external borders with an additional 10,000 European border guards funded by the EU budget by 2020.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We are also proposing to further develop the European Asylum Agency to make sure that Member States get more European support in processing asylum seekers in line with the Geneva Convention.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And we are proposing to accelerate the return of irregular migrants.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I would also like to remind Member States of the need to open legal pathways to the Union.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I renew my call.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We need skilled migrants.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Commission proposals addressing this issue have been on the table for some time and must now be taken up.

speaker: Juncker
sentence:
Mr President,

Honourable Members of the European Parliament,

To speak of the future, one must speak of Africa – Europe's twin continent.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: By 2050, Africa's population will number 2.5 billion.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: One in four people on earth will be African.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We need to invest more in our relationship with the nations of this great and noble continent.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And we have to stop seeing this relationship through the sole prism of development aid.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Such an approach is beyond inadequate, in fact it is humiliating.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Africa does not need charity, it needs true and fair partnerships.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And we in Europe need this partnership just as much.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: In preparing my speech today, I spoke to my African friends, notably Paul Kagame, the Chairperson of the African Union.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We agreed that reciprocal commitments are the way forward.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We want to build a new partnership with Africa.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Today, we are proposing a new Alliance for Sustainable Investment and Jobs between Europe and Africa.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This Alliance – as we envision it – would help create up to 10 million jobs in Africa in the next 5 years alone.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We want to create a framework that brings more private investment to Africa.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We are not starting from scratch: our External Investment Plan, launched here two years ago, will mobilise over €44 billion in both the public and private investment.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Alone the projects already that are in the pipeline or have already begun will unlock €24 billion.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We want to focus our investment where it matters the most.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: By 2020, the EU will have supported 35,000 African students and researchers with our strengthened Erasmus programme.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: By 2027, this figure will reach 105,000.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Trade between Europe and Africa is not insignificant.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: 36 % of Africa's trade is already with the European Union.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: But this is not enough.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I believe we should develop the numerous trade agreements between Europe and the countries of Africa into a continent-to-continent free trade agreement, as an economic partnership between equals.

speaker: Juncker
sentence:
Mr President,

Ladies and Gentlemen,

Another issue where I see a strong need for the Union for leadership is Brexit.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I will not enter into the details of the negotiations, which are being masterfully handled by my friend Michel Barnier.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: He works on the basis of a unanimous position confirmed time and again by the 27 Member States.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: However, allow me to recall three principles which should guide our work on Brexit in the months to come.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: First of all, we of course respect the British decision to leave our Union, but we regret it deeply.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: But we also ask the British government to understand that someone who leaves the Union cannot be in the same privileged position as a Member State.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: If you leave the Union, you are of course no longer part of our Single Market, and certainly not only in parts of it.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Secondly, the European Commission, this Parliament and all other Member States will always show loyalty and solidarity with Ireland when it comes to the Irish border.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This is why we want to find a creative solution that prevents a hard border in Northern Ireland.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And we will defend all the elements of the Good Friday Agreement.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: It is Brexit that risks making the border more visible in Northern Ireland.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: It is not the European Union.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Thirdly, after 29 March 2019, the United Kingdom will never be an ordinary third country for us.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The United Kingdom will always be a very close neighbour and partner, in political, economic and security terms.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: In the past months, when we needed unity in the Union, Britain was at our side, driven by the same values and principles of all other Europeans.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This is why I welcome Prime Minister May's proposal to develop an ambitious new partnership for the future, after Brexit.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We agree with the statement made in Chequers that the starting point for such a partnership should be a free trade area between the United Kingdom and the European Union.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: On the basis of these principles, the Commission's negotiators, mainly my good friend Michel Barnier, stand ready to work day and night to reach a deal.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We owe it to our citizens and our businesses to ensure the United Kingdom's withdrawal is orderly and that there is stability afterwards.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: It will not be the Commission that will stand in the way of this.

speaker: Juncker
sentence:
A STRONG PERSPECTIVE FOR THE FUTURE

Honourable Members of the European Parliament,

There is much work to be done before the European elections and before Europe's Leaders meet in Romania on 9 May 2019.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: In Sibiu, we will need to convince our fellow citizens that, on the essential points, we share the same ideas on the purpose of our Union.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Europeans deserve better than uncertainty and confused objectives.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: They deserve clarity of intent, not approximations or half-measures.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: So let us not give European citizens half-measures.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This is what is at stake on the road to Sibiu.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: By then we must have ratified the EU-Japan partnership agreement – for both economic and geopolitical reasons.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: By then, we should also have brokered an agreement in principle on the EU budget after 2020.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: If we want to give young Europeans the opportunity to make the most of our Erasmus programme – which we must – then we must decide on this, as well as other aspects of the budget.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: If we want to give our researchers and start-ups more opportunities, and prevent funding gaps costing research jobs, we have to decide before the elections.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: If we want – without militarising the European Union – to increase defence spending by a factor of 20, we will need to decide upon this before the European elections.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: If we want to increase our investment in Africa by 23 %, we must decide quickly.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I am always being told – by Heads of State, ministers, MEPs and national MPs – that decisions cannot be taken before elections, as if elections were some sort of crisis of democracy.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: No.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Elections are a natural part of democracy and it is natural – even urgent – to take decisions before elections to show the way to those voting for us.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: By next year, we should also address the international role of the euro.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The euro is 20 years young and has already come a long way – despite its critics.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: It is now the world's second currency, after the US dollar, with 60 countries linking their currencies to the euro in one way or another.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: But we must do more to allow our single currency to play its full role on the international scene.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Recent events have brought into sharp focus the need to deepen our Economic and Monetary Union and build deep and liquid capital markets.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The Commission has made a series of proposals to do just that – most of which now await adoption.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We can and must go further.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: It is absurd that Europe pays for 80 % of its energy import bill – worth 300 billion euro a year – in US dollars when only roughly 2 % of our energy imports come from the United States.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: It is absurd, ridiculous that European companies buy European planes in dollars instead of euro.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This all needs to be changed.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This is why, before the end of the year, the Commission will present initiatives to strengthen the international role of the euro.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The euro must become the face and the instrument of a new, more sovereign Europe.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: For this, we must first put our own house in order by strengthening and deepening our Economic and Monetary Union, as we have already started to do.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Without this, we will lack the means to strengthen the international of role of the euro.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We must complete our Economic and Monetary Union to make Europe and the euro stronger.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Last but not least, by Sibiu (Hermannstadt) I want to make visible progress in strengthening our foreign policy.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We must improve our ability to speak with one voice when it comes to our foreign policy.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: It is not right that Europe silenced itself at the United Nations Human Rights Council when it came to condemning human rights abuses by China because one Member State opposed it.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I give this one example – I could give many others.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This is why today the Commission is proposing to move to qualified majority voting in specific areas of our external relations.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I repeat the same message I gave last year.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We shall be making proposals to handle certain areas of foreign policy – not all – using qualified majority.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: This is possible on the basis of the current Treaties and I believe the time has come to make use of this ‘lost treasure' of the Lisbon Treaty.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I also think, for that matter, that we should be able to decide on certain tax matters by qualified majority.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I would like to say a few words, Mr President, about the increasingly worrying way in which we air our disagreements.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Heated exchanges amongst governments and sometimes institutions are becoming more and more common.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: But harsh or hurtful words will not get Europe anywhere.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: What worries me is not only the tone used in political discourse.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: It is also true of the way some seek to shut down debate altogether by targeting media and journalists.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Europe must always be a place where freedom of the press is sacrosanct.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Too many of our journalists are intimidated, attacked, murdered.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: There is no democracy without a free press.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: In general, ladies and gentlemen, we must do more to revive the lost art of compromise.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Compromise is not a weakness.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: It does not mean sacrificing our convictions or stifling free debate that respects others' points of view.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The Commission will resist all attacks on the rule of law.We continue to be very concerned by the developments in some of our Member States.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Article 7 must be applied whenever the rule of law is threatened.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: In this regard, I must say that First Vice-President Timmermans is doing a remarkable but often lonely – too often lonely – job of defending the rule of law.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The whole Commission, and I personally, support him fully.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We must be very clear on one point: judgements from the Court of Justice must be respected and implemented.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The European Union is a community of law.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Respecting the rule of law and abiding by Court decisions are not optional.

speaker: Juncker
sentence:
CONCLUSION

Mr President,

Ladies and Gentlemen, and for many of you: dear friends,

I started this speech – my last State of the Union though surely not my last speech – by talking about history.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I spoke of both the events that have marked this Commission's time in office and of history writ large, the History of Europe.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We are all responsible for the Europe of today.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And we must all take responsibility for the Europe of tomorrow.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Such is history: parliaments and Commissions come and go, Europe is here to stay.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: But for Europe to become what it must, we must keep several aspects in mind.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I want Europe to get off the side-lines of world affairs.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Europe can no longer be a spectator or a mere commentator of international events.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Europe must be an active player, an architect of tomorrow's world.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: There is strong demand for Europe throughout the world.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: To meet such high demand, Europe will have to speak with one voice on the world stage.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: In the concert of nations, Europe's voice must ring clear in order to be heard.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Federica Mogherini has made Europe's diplomacy more coherent than it has ever been before.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: But let us never slide back into the incoherence of competing and parallel national diplomacies.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Europe diplomacy must be conducted in the singular.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: And our solidarity must be all-embracing.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I want us to do more to bring together the East and West of Europe.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: It is time we put an end to the sorry spectacle of a divided Europe.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Our continent and those who brought an end to the Cold War deserve better.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I would like the European Union to take better care of its social dimension.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Those that ignore the legitimate concerns of workers and small businesses undermine European unity.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: It is time we turned the good intentions that we proclaimed at the Gothenburg Social Summit into law.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I would like next year's elections to be a landmark for European democracy.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I would like to see the Spitzenkandidaten (lead candidate) process – that small step forward for European democracy – repeated.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: For me, this process would be made all the more credible if we were to have transnational lists.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I think that this should be done by 2024.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: But above all, I would like us to reject unhealthy nationalism and embrace enlightened patriotism.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: We should never forget that the patriotism of the 21st Century is two-fold: both European and national, with one not excluding the other.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: As the French philosophe Blaise Pascal said: I like things that go together.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: In order to stand on its own two feet, Europe must move forward as one.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: To love Europe, is it love its nations.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: To love your country is to love Europe.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Patriotism is a virtue.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Unchecked nationalism is riddled with both poison and deceit.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: In short, we must remain true to ourselves.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: The trees we plant today must provide shade for our great grand-children whether they hail from North or South, from East or West.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: To give them all they need to grow and breathe easily.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: A few years ago, standing in this very same spot, I told you that Europe was the love of my life.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: I love Europe still and shall do so forever more.

speaker: Juncker
sentence: Thank for your attention.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Building the world we want to live in: A Union of vitality in a world of fragility

 

Dear President,

Honourable Members,

One of the most courageous minds of our times, Andrei Sakharov – a man so admired by this House - always spoke of his unshakeable belief in the hidden strength of the human spirit.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: In these last six months, Europeans have shown how strong that human spirit really is.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We saw it in the care workers who moved into nursing homes to look after the ill and the elderly.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: In the doctors and nurses who became family members for those in their last breath.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: In the front line workers who worked day after night, week after week, who took risks so most of us didn't have to.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We are inspired by their empathy, bravery and sense of duty – and I want to start this speech by paying tribute to them all.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Their stories also reveal a lot about the state of our world and the state of our Union.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: They show the power of humanity and the sense of mourning which will live long in our society.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And they expose to us the fragility all around us.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: A virus a thousand times smaller than a grain of sand exposed how delicate life can be.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It laid bare the strains on our health systems and the limits of a model that values wealth above wellbeing.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It brought into sharper focus the planetary fragility that we see every day through melting glaciers, burning forests and now through global pandemics.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It changed the very way we behave and communicate – keeping our arms at length, our faces behind masks.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It showed us just how fragile our community of values really is – and how quickly it can be called into question around the world and even here in our Union.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But people want to move out of this corona world, out of this fragility, out of uncertainty.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: They are ready for change and they are ready to move on.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And this is the moment for Europe.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The moment for Europe to lead the way from this fragility towards a new vitality.And this is what I want to talk about today.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Honourable Members,

I say this because in the last months we have rediscovered the value of what we hold in common.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: As individuals, we have all sacrificed a piece of our personal liberty for the safety of others.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And as a Union, we all shared a part of our sovereignty for the common good.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We turned fear and division between Member States into confidence in our Union.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We showed what is possible when we trust each other and trust our European institutions.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And with all of that, we choose to not only repair and recover for the here and now, but to shape a better way of living for the world of tomorrow.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is NextGenerationEU.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is our opportunity to make change happen by design – not by disaster or by diktat from others in the world.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: To emerge stronger by creating opportunities for the world of tomorrow and not just building contingencies for the world of yesterday.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We have everything we need to make this happen.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We have shaken off the old excuses and home comforts that have always held us back.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We have the vision, we have the plan, we have the investment.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It is now time to get to work.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This morning, I have sent a Letter of Intent to President Sassoli and Chancellor Merkel – on behalf of the German Presidency - outlining the Commission's plans for the year ahead.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: I will not present every initiative today but I want to touch on what our Union must focus on in the next twelve months.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
PULLING THROUGH TOGETHER: MAKING GOOD ON EUROPE'S PROMISE

Honourable members,

The people of Europe are still suffering.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It is a period of profound anxiety for millions who are concerned about the health of their families, the future of their jobs or simply just getting through until the end of the month.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The pandemic – and the uncertainty that goes with it – is not over.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And the recovery is still in its early stage.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: So our first priority is to pull each other through this.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: To be there for those that need it.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And thanks to our unique social market economy, Europe can do just that.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It is above all a human economy that protects us against the great risks of life - illness, ill-fortune, unemployment or poverty.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It offers stability and helps us better absorb shocks.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It creates opportunity and prosperity by promoting innovation, growth and fair competition.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Never before has that enduring promise of protection, stability and opportunity been more important than it is today.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Allow me to explain why.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: First, Europe must continue to protect lives and livelihoods.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is all the more important in the middle of a pandemic that shows no signs of running out of steam or intensity.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We know how quickly numbers can spiral out of control.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: So we must continue to handle this pandemic with extreme care, responsibility and unity.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: In the last six months, our health systems and workers have produced miracles.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Every country has worked to do its best for its citizens.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And Europe has done more together than ever before.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: When Member States closed borders, we created green lanes for goods.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: When more than 600,000 European citizens were stranded all over the world, the EU brought them home.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: When some countries introduced export bans for critical medical goods, we stopped that and ensured that critical medical supply could go where it was needed.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We worked with European industry to increase the production of masks, gloves, tests and ventilators.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Our Civil Protection Mechanism ensured that doctors from Romania could treat patients in Italy or that Latvia could send masks to its Baltic neighbours.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we achieved this without having full competences.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: For me, it is crystal clear – we need to build a stronger European Health Union.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And to start making this a reality, we must now draw the first lessons from the health crisis.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We need to make our new EU4Health programme future proof.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is why I had proposed to increase funding and I am grateful that this Parliament is ready to fight for more funding and remedy the cuts made by the European Council.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we need to strengthen our crisis preparedness and management of cross-border health threats.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: As a first step, we will propose to reinforce and empowerthe European Medicines Agencyand ECDC – our centre for disease prevention and control.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: As a second step, we will build a European BARDA – an agency for biomedical advanced research and development.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This new agency will support our capacity and readiness to respond to cross-border threats and emergencies – whether of natural or deliberate origin.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We need strategic stockpiling to address supply chain dependencies, notably for pharmaceutical products.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: As a third step, it is clearer than ever that we must discuss the question of health competences.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And I think this is a noble and urgent task for the Conference on the Future of Europe.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And because this was a global crisis we need to learn the global lessons.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is why, along with Prime Minister Conte and the Italian G20 Presidency, I will convene a Global Health Summit next year in Italy.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This will show Europeans that our Union is there to protect all.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And this is exactly what we have done when it comes to workers.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: When I took office, I vowed to create an instrument to protect workers and businesses from external shocks.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Because I knew from my experience as a Minister for Labour and Social Affairs that these schemes work.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: They keep people in jobs, skills in companies and SMEs in business.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: These SMEs are the motor of our economy and will be the engine of our recovery.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is why the Commission created the SURE programme.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And I want to thank this House for working on it in record time.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: If Europe has so far avoided mass unemployment seen elsewhere, it is thanks in large part to the fact that around 40 million people applied for short-time work schemes.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This speed and unity of purpose means that 16 countries will soon receive almost 90 billion euros from SURE to support workers and companies.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: From Lithuania to Spain, it will give peace of mind to families who need that income to put food on the table or to pay the rent.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And it will help protect millions of jobs, incomes and companies right across our Union.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is real European solidarity in action.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And it reflects the fact that in our Union the dignity of work must be sacred.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But the truth is that for too many people, work no longer pays.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Dumping wages destroys the dignity of work, penalises the entrepreneur who pays decent wages and distorts fair competition in the Single Market.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is why the Commission will put forward a legal proposal to support Member States to set up a framework for minimum wages.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Everyone must have access to minimum wages either through collective agreements or through statutory minimum wages.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: I am a strong advocate of collective bargaining and the proposal will fully respect national competencies and traditions.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We have seen in many Member States how a well-negotiated minimum wage secures jobs and creates fairness – both for workers and for the companies who really value them.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Minimum wages work – and it is time that work paid.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The second promise of the social market economy is that of stability.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The European Union and its Member States responded to an unprecedented crisis with an unprecedented response.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: By showing it was united and up to the task, Europe provided the stability our economies needed.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The Commission immediately triggered the general escape clause for the first time in our history.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We flexibilisedour European funds and State aid rules.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Authorising more than 3 trillion euro in support to companies and industry: From fishermen in Croatia and farmers in Greece, to SMEs in Italy and freelancers in Denmark.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The European Central Bank took decisive action through its PEPP programme.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The Commission proposed NextGenerationEU and a revamped budget in record time.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It combines investment with much needed reforms.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The Council endorsed it in record time.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This House is working towards voting on it with maximum speed.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: For the first time – and for exceptional times - Europe has put in place its own common tools to complement national fiscal stabilisers.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is a remarkable moment of unity for our Union.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is an achievement that we should take collective pride in.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Now is the time to hold our course.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We have all seen the forecasts.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We can expect our economies to start moving again after a 12% drop in GDP in the second quarter.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But as the virus lingers so does the uncertainty – here in Europe and around the world.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: So this is definitely not the time to withdraw support.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Our economies need continued policy support and a delicate balance will need to be struck between providing financial support and ensuring fiscal sustainability.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: In the longer-term there is no greater way to stability and competitiveness than through a stronger Economic and Monetary Union.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Confidence in the euro has never been stronger.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The historic agreement on NextGenerationEU shows the political backing that it has.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We must now use this opportunity to make structural reforms in our economies and complete the Capital Markets Union and the Banking Union.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Deep and liquid capital markets are essential to give businesses access to the finance they need to grow and invest in recovery and in the future.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And they are also a pre-requisite to further strengthen the international role of the euro.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: So let's get to work and finally complete this generational project.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Honourable Members, the third enduring promise is the promise of opportunity.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The pandemic reminded us of many things we may have forgotten or taken for granted.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We were reminded how linked our economies are and how crucial a fully functioning Single Market is to our prosperity and the way we do things.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The Single Market is all about opportunity - for a consumer to get value for money, a company to sell anywhere in Europe and for industry to drive its global competitiveness.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And for all of us, it is about the opportunity to make the most of the freedoms we cherish as Europeans.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It gives our companies the scale they need to prosper and is a safe haven for them in times of trouble.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We rely on it every day to make our lives easier – and it is critical for managing the crisis and recovering our strength.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Let's give it a boost.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We must tear down the barriers of the Single Market.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We must cut red tape.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We must step up implementation and enforcement.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we must restore the four freedoms – in full and as fast as possible.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The linchpin of this is a fully functioning Schengen area of free movement.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We will work with Parliament and Member States to bring this high up our political agenda and we will propose a new strategy for the future of Schengen.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Based on this strong internal market, the European industry has long powered our economy, providing a stable living for millions and creating the social hubs around which our communities are built.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We presented our new industry strategy in March to ensure industry could lead the twin green and digital transition.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The last six months have only accelerated that transformation – at a time when the global competitive landscape is fundamentally changing.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is why we will update our industry strategy in the first half of next year and adapt our competition framework which should also keep pace.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
PROPELLING EUROPE FORWARD: BUILDING THE WORLD WE WANT TO LIVE IN

Honourable Members,

All of this will ensure Europe gets back to its feet.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But as we pull through together, we must also propel ourselves forwards to the world of tomorrow.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: There is no more urgent need for acceleration than when it comes to the future of our fragile planet.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: While much of the world's activity froze during lockdowns and shutdowns, the planet continued to get dangerously hotter.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We see it all around us: from homes evacuated due to glacier collapse on the Mont Blanc, to fires burning through Oregon, to crops destroyed in Romania by the most severe drought in decades.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But we also saw nature come back into our lives.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We longed for green spaces and cleaner air for our mental health and our physical wellbeing.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We know change is needed – and we also know it is possible.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The European Green Deal is our blueprint to make that transformation.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: At the heart of it is our mission to become the first climate-neutral continent by 2050.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But we will not get there with the status quo – we need to go faster and do things better.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We looked in-depth at every sector to see how fast we could go and how to do it in a responsible, evidence-based way.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We held a wide public consultation and conducted an extensive impact assessment.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: On this basis, the European Commission is proposing to increase the 2030 target for emission reduction to at least 55%.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: I recognise that this increase from 40 to 55 is too much for some, and not enough for others.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
But our impact assessment clearly shows that our economy and industry can manage this

And they want it too.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Just yesterday, 170 business leaders and investors – from SME's to some of the world's biggest companies - wrote to me calling on Europe to set a target of at least 55%.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Our impact assessment clearly shows that meeting this target would put the EU firmly on track for climate neutrality by 2050 and for meeting our Paris Agreement obligations.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And if others follow our lead, the world will be able to keep warming below 1.5 degrees Celsius.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: I am fully aware that many of our partners are far away from that – and I will come back to the Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism later.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But for us, the 2030 target is ambitious, achievable, and beneficial for Europe.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We can do it.We have already shown we can do it.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: While emissions dropped 25% since 1990, our economy grew by more than 60%.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The difference is we now have more technology, more expertise and more investment.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we are already embarking towards a circular economy with carbon neutral production.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We have more young people pushing for change.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We have more proof that what is good for the climate is good for business and is good for us all.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we have a solemn promise to leave no one behind in this transformation.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: With our Just Transition Fund we will support the regions that have a bigger and more costly change to make.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We have it all.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Now it's our responsibility to implement it all and make it happen.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Honourable Members,

Meeting this new target will reduce our energy import dependency, create millions of extra jobs and more than halve air pollution.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: To get there, we must start now.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: By next summer, we will revise all of our climate and energy legislation to make it “fit for 55”.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We will enhance emission trading, boost renewable energy, improve energy efficiency, reform energy taxation.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But the mission of the European Green Deal involves much more than cutting emissions.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It is about making systemic modernisation across our economy, society and industry.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It is about building a stronger world to live in.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Our current levels of consumption of raw materials, energy, water, food and land use are not sustainable.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We need to change how we treat nature, how we produce and consume, live and work, eat and heat, travel and transport.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: So we will tackle everything from hazardous chemicals to deforestation to pollution.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is a plan for a true recovery.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It is an investment plan for Europe.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And this is where NextGenerationEU will make a real difference.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Firstly, 37% of NextGenerationEU will be spent directly on our European Green Deal objectives.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And I will ensure that it also takes green financing to the next level.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We are world leaders in green finance and the largest issuer of green bonds worldwide.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We are leading the way in developing a reliable EU Green Bond Standard.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And I can today announce that we will set a target of 30% of NextGenerationEU's 750 billion euro to be raised through green bonds.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Secondly, NextGenerationEU should invest in lighthouse European projects with the biggest impact: hydrogen, renovation and 1 million electric charging points.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Allow me to explain how this could work: 

Two weeks ago in Sweden, a unique fossil-free steel pilot began test operations.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It will replace coal with hydrogen to produce clean steel.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This shows the potential of hydrogen to support our industry with a new, clean, licence to operate.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: I want NextGenerationEU to create new European Hydrogen Valleys to modernise our industries, power our vehicles and bring new life to rural areas.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The second example are the buildings we live and work in.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Our buildings generate 40% of our emissions.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: They need to become less wasteful, less expensive and more sustainable.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we know that the construction sector can even be turned from a carbon source into a carbon sink, if organic building materials like wood and smart technologies like AI are applied.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: I want NextGenerationEU to kickstart a European renovation wave and make our Union a leader in the circular economy.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But this is not just an environmental or economic project: it needs to be a new cultural project for Europe.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Every movement has its own look and feel.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we need to give our systemic change its own distinct aesthetic – to match style with sustainability.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is why we will set up a new European Bauhaus – a co-creation space where architects, artists, students, engineers, designers work together to make that happen.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is NextGenerationEU.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is shaping the world we want to live in.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: A world served by an economy that cuts emissions, boosts competitiveness, reduces energy poverty, creates rewarding jobs and improves quality of life.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: A world where we use digital technologies to build a healthier, greener society.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This can only be achieved if we all do it together and I will insist that recovery plans don't just bring us out the crisis but also help us propel Europe forward to the world of tomorrow.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Honourable Members,

Imagine for a moment life in this pandemic without digital in our lives.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: From staying in quarantine – isolated from family and community and cut off from the world of work – to major supply problems.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It is in fact not so hard to imagine that this was the case 100 years ago during the last major pandemic.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: A century later, modern technology has allowed young people to learn remotely and millions to work from home.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: They enabled companies to sell their products, factories to keep running and government to deliver crucial public services from afar.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We saw years' worth of digital innovation and transformation in the space of a few weeks.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We are reaching the limits of the things we can do in an analogue way.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And this great acceleration is just beginning.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We must make this Europe's Digital Decade.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We need a common plan for digital Europe with clearly defined goals for 2030, such as for connectivity, skills and digital public services.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we need to follow clear principles: the right to privacy and connectivity, freedom of speech, free flow of data and cybersecurity.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But Europe must now lead the way on digital – or it will have to follow the way of others, who are setting these standards for us.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is why we must move fast.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: There are three areas on which I believe we need to focus.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: First, data.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: On personalized data - business to consumer -  Europe has been too slow and is now dependent on others.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This cannot happen with industrial data.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And here the good news is that Europe is in the lead - we have the technology, and crucially we have the industry.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But the race is not yet won.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The amount of industrial data in the world will quadruple in the next five years - and so will the opportunities that come with it.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We have to give our companies, SMEs, start-ups and researchers the opportunity to draw on their full potential.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And industrial data is worth its weight in gold when it comes to developing new products and services.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But the reality is that 80% of industrial data is still collected and never used.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is pure waste.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: A real data economy, on the other hand, would be a powerful engine for innovation and new jobs.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And this is why we need to secure this data for Europe and make it widely accessible.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We need common data spaces - for example, in the energy or healthcare sectors.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This will support innovation ecosystems in which universities, companies and researchers can access and collaborate on data.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And it is why we will build a European cloud as part of NextGenerationEU - based on GaiaX.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The second area we need to focus on is technology - and in particular artificial intelligence.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Whether it's precision farming in agriculture, more accurate medical diagnosis or safe autonomous driving - artificial intelligence will open up new worlds for us.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But this world also needs rules.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We want a set of rules that puts people at the centre.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Algorithms must not be a black box and there must be clear rules if something goes wrong.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The Commission will propose a law to this effect next year.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This includes control over our personal data which still have far too rarely today.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Every time an App or website asks us to create a new digital identity or to easily log on via a big platform, we have no idea what happens to our data in reality.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: That is why the Commission will soon propose a secure European e-identity.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: One that we trust and that any citizen can use anywhere in Europe to do anything from paying your taxes to renting a bicycle.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: A technology where we can control ourselves what data and how data is used.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The third point is the infrastructure.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Data connections must keep pace with the rapid speed of change.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: If we are striving for a Europe of equal opportunities, it is unacceptable that 40% of people in rural areas still do not have access to fast broadband connections.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: These connections are now the prerequisite for home working, home learning, online shopping and, increasingly by the day, for new important services.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Without broadband connections, it is now barely possible to build or run a business effectively.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is a huge opportunity and the prerequisite for revitalising rural areas.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Only then can they fully exploit their potential and attract more people and investment.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The investment boost through NextGenerationEU is a unique chance to drive expansion to every village.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is why we want to focus our investments on secure connectivity, on the expansion of 5G, 6G and fiber.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: NextGenerationEU is also a unique opportunity to develop a more coherent European approach to connectivity and digital infrastructure deployment.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: None of this is an end in itself - it is about Europe's digital sovereignty, on a small and large scale.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: In this spirit, I am pleased to announce an investment of 8 billion euros in the next generation of supercomputers - cutting-edge technology made in Europe.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we want the European industry to develop our own next-generation microprocessor that will allow us to use the increasing data volumes energy-efficient and securely.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is what Europe's Digital Decade is all about!

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Honourable Members,

If Europe is to move forward and move fast, we must let go of our hesitancies.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is about giving Europe more control over its future.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We have everything it takes to bring it to life.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And the private sector is desperately waiting for this too.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: There has never been a better time to invest in European tech companies with new digital hubs growing everywhere from Sofia to Lisbon to Katowice.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We have the people, the ideas and the strength as a Union to succeed.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And this is why we will invest 20% of NextGenerationEU on digital.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We want to lead the way, the European way, to the Digital Age: based on our values, our strength, our global ambitions.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
A VITAL EUROPE IN A FRAGILE WORLD

Honourable Members,

Europe is determined to use this transition to build the world we want to live in.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And that of course extends well beyond our borders.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The pandemic has simultaneously shown both the fragility of the global system and the importance of cooperation to tackle collective challenges.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: In the face of the crisis, some around the world choose to retreat into isolation.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Others actively destabilise the system.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Europe chooses to reach out.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Our leadership is not about self-serving propaganda.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It is not about Europe First.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It is about being the first to seriously answer the call when it matters.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: In the pandemic, European planes delivering thousands of tonnes of protective equipment landed everywhere from Sudan to Afghanistan, Somalia to Venezuela.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: None of us will be safe until all of us are safe – wherever we live, whatever we have.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: An accessible, affordable and safe vaccine is the world's most promising way to do that.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: At the beginning of the pandemic, there was no funding, no global framework for a COVID vaccine – just the rush to be the first to get one.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is the moment the EU stepped up to lead the global response.

speaker: Leyen
