sentence: With civil society, the G20, WHO and others we brought more than 40 countries together to raise 16 billion euro to finance research on vaccines, tests and treatments for the whole world.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is the EU's unmatched convening power in action.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But it is not enough to find a vaccine.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We need to make sure that European citizens and those around the world have access to it.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Just this month, the EU joined the COVAX global facility and contributed 400 million euro to help ensure that safe vaccines are available not only for those who can afford it – but for everyone who needs it.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Vaccine nationalism puts lives at risk.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Vaccine cooperation saves them.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Honourable Members,

We are firm believers in the strength and value of cooperating in international bodies

It is with a strong United Nations that we can find long-term solutions for crises like Libya or Syria.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It is with a strong World Health Organisation that we can better prepare and respond to global pandemics or local outbreaks – be it Corona or Ebola.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And it is with a strong World Trade Organisation that we can ensure fair competition for all.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But the truth is also that the need to revitalise and reform the multilateral system has never been so urgent.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Our global system has grown into a creeping paralysis.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Major powers are either pulling out of institutions or taking them hostage for their own interests.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Neither road will lead us anywhere.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Yes, we want change.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But change by design – not by destruction.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And this is why I want the EU to lead reforms of the WTO and WHO so they are fit for today's world.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But we know that multilateral reforms take time and in the meantime the world will not stop.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Without any doubt, there is a clear need for Europe to take clear positions and quick actions on global affairs.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Two days ago, the latest EU-China leaders meeting took place.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The relationship between the European Union and China is simultaneously one of the most strategically important and one of the most challenging we have.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: From the outset I have said China is a negotiating partner, an economic competitor and a systemic rival.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We have interests in common on issues such as climate change – and China has shown it is willing to engage through a high-level dialogue.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But we expect China to live up to its commitments in the Paris Agreement and lead by example.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: There is still hard work to do on fair market access for European companies, reciprocity and overcapacity.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We continue to have an unbalanced trade and investment partnership.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And there is no doubt that we promote very different systems of governance and society.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We believe in the universal value of democracy and the rights of the individual.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Europe is not without issues – think for example of anti-semitism.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But we discuss them publicly.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Criticism and opposition are not only accepted but are legally protected.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: So we must always call out human rights abuses whenever and wherever they occur – be it on Hong Kong or with the Uyghurs.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But what holds us back?

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Why are even simple statements on EU values delayed, watered down or held hostage for other motives?

speaker: Leyen
sentence: When Member States say Europe is too slow, I say to them be courageous and finally move to qualified majority voting – at least on human rights and sanctions implementation.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This House has called many times for a European Magnitsky Act – and I can announce that we will now come forward with a proposal.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We need to complete our toolbox.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Honourable Members,

Be it in Hong Kong, Moscow or Minsk: Europe must take a clear and swift position.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: I want to say it loud and clear: the European Union is on the side of the people of Belarus.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We have all been moved by the immense courage of those peacefully gathering in Independence Square or taking part in the fearless women's march.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The elections that brought them into the street were neither free nor fair.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And the brutal response by the government ever since has been shameful.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The people of Belarus must be free to decide their own future for themselves.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: They are not pieces on someone else's chess board.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: To those that advocate closer ties with Russia, I say that the poisoning of Alexei Navalny with an advanced chemical agent is not a one off.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We have seen the pattern in Georgia and Ukraine, Syria and Salisbury – and in election meddling around the world.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This pattern is not changing – and no pipeline will change that.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Turkey is and will always be an important neighbour.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But while we are close together on the map, the distance between us appears to be growing.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Yes, Turkey is in a troubled neighbourhood.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And yes, it is hosting millions of refugees, for which we support them with considerable funding.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But none of this is justification for attempts to intimidate its neighbours.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Our Member States, Cyprus and Greece, can always count on Europe's full solidarity on protecting their legitimate sovereignty rights.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: De-escalation in the Eastern Mediterranean is in our mutual interest.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The return of exploratory vessels to Turkish ports in the past few days is a positive step in this direction.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is necessary to create the much needed space for dialogue.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Refraining from unilateral actions and resuming talks in genuine good faith is the only path forward.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The only path to stability and lasting solutions.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Honourable Members,

As well as responding more assertively to global events, Europe must deepen and refine its partnerships with its friends and allies.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And this starts with revitalising our most enduring of partnerships.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We might not always agree with recent decisions by the White House.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But we will always cherish the transatlantic alliance – based on shared values and history, and an unbreakable bond between our people.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: So whatever may happen later this year, we are ready to build a new transatlantic agenda.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: To strengthen our bilateral partnership – be it on trade, tech or taxation.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we are ready to work together on reforming the international system we built together, jointly with like-minded partners.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: For our own interests and the interest of the common good.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We need new beginnings with old friends – on both of sides of the Atlantic and on both sides of the Channel.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The scenes in this very room when we held hands and said goodbye with Auld Lang Syne spoke a thousand words.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: They showed an affection for the British people that will never fade.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But with every day that passes the chances of a timely agreement do start to fade.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Negotiations are always difficult.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We are used to that.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And the Commission has the best and most experienced negotiator, Michel Barnier, to navigate us through.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But talks have not progressed as we would have wished.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And that leaves us very little time.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: As ever, this House will be the first to know and will have the last say.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And I can assure you we will continue to update you throughout, just as we did with the Withdrawal Agreement.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: That agreement took three years to negotiate and we worked relentlessly on it.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Line by line, word by word.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And together we succeeded.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The result guarantees our citizens' rights, financial interests, the integrity of the Single Market – and crucially the Good Friday Agreement.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The EU and the UK jointly agreed it was the best and only way for ensuring peace on the island of Ireland.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we will never backtrack on that.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This agreement has been ratified by this House and the House of Commons.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It cannot be unilaterally changed, disregarded or dis-applied.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This a matter of law, trust and good faith.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
And that is not just me saying it – I remind you of the words of Margaret Thatcher:

“Britain does not break Treaties.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It would be bad for Britain, bad for relations with the rest of the world, and bad for any future Treaty on trade”.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This was true then, and it is true today.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Trust is the foundation of any strong partnership.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And Europe will always be ready to build strong partnerships with our closest neighbours.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: That starts with the Western Balkans.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The decision six months ago to open accession negotiations with Albania and North Macedonia was truly historic.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Indeed, the future of the whole region lies in the EU.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We share the same history, we share the same destiny.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The Western Balkans are part of Europe - and not just a stopover on the Silk Road.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We will soon present an economic recovery package for the Western Balkans focusing on a number of regional investment initiatives.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we will also be there for the Eastern Partnership countries and our partners in the southern neighbourhood– to help create jobs and kickstart their economies.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: When I came into office, I chose for the very first trip outside the European Union, to visit the African Union, and it was a natural choice.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It was a natural choice and it was a clear message, because we are not just neighbours, we are natural partners.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Three months later, I returned with my entire College to set our priorities for our new strategy with Africa.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It is a partnership of equals, where both sides share opportunities and responsibilities.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Africa will be a key partner in building the world we want to live in – whether on climate, digital or trade.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Honourable Members,

We will continue to believe in open and fair trade across the world.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Not as an end in itself – but as a way to deliver prosperity at home and promote our values and standards.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: More than 600,000 jobs in Europe are tied to trade with Japan.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And our recent agreement with Vietnam alone helped secure historic labour rights for millions of workers in the country.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We will use our diplomatic strength and economic clout to broker agreements that make a difference – such as designating maritime protected areas in the Antarctica.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This would be one of the biggest acts of environmental protection in history.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We will form high ambition coalitions on issues such as digital ethics or fighting deforestation – and develop partnerships with all like-minded partners – from Asian democracies to Australia, Africa, the Americas and anyone else who wants to join.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We will work for just globalisation.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But we cannot take this for granted.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We must insist on fairness and a level playing field.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And Europe will move forward – alone or with partners that want to join.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We are for example working on a Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Carbon must have its price – because nature cannot pay the price anymore.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This Carbon Border Adjustment Mechanism should motivate foreign producers and EU importers to reduce their carbon emissions, while ensuring that we level the playing field in a WTO-compatible way.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The same principle applies to digital taxation.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We will spare no effort to reach agreement in the framework of OECD and G20.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But let there be no doubt: should an agreement fall short of a fair tax system that provides long-term sustainable revenues, Europe will come forward with a proposal early next year.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: I want Europe to be a global advocate for fairness.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
A NEW VITALITY FOR EUROPE

Honourable Members,

If Europe is to play this vital role in the world – it must also create a new vitality internally.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And to move forward we must now overcome the differences that have held us back.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The historic agreement on NextGenerationEU shows that it can be done.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The speed with which we took decisions on fiscal rules, state aid or for SURE – all this shows it can be done.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: So let's do it.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Migration is an issue that has been discussed long enough.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Migration has always been a fact for Europe – and it will always be.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Throughout centuries, it has defined our societies, enriched our cultures and shaped many of our lives.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And this will always be the case.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: As we all know, the 2015 migration crisis caused many deep divisions between Member States – with some of those scars still healing today.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: A lot has been done since.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But a lot is still missing.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: If we are all ready to make compromises – without compromising on our principles – we can find that solution.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Next week, the Commission will put forward its New Pact on Migration.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We will take a human and humane approach.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Saving lives at sea is not optional.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And those countries who fulfil their legal and moral duties or are more exposed than others, must be able to rely on the solidarity of our whole European Union.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We will ensure a closer link between asylum and return.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We have to make a clear distinction between those who have the right to stay and those who do not.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We will take action to fight smugglers, strengthen external borders, deepen external partnerships and create legal pathways.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we will make sure that people who have the right to stay are integrated and made to feel welcome.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: They have a future to build – and skills, energy and talent.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: I think of Suadd, the teenage Syrian refugee who arrived in Europe dreaming of being a doctor.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Within three years she was awarded a prestigious scholarship from the Royal College of Surgeons in Ireland.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: I think of the Libyan and Somalian refugee doctors who offered their medical skills the moment the pandemic struck in France.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Honourable Members, if we think about what they have overcome and what they have achieved, then we simply must be able to manage the question of migration together.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The images of the Moria camp are a painful reminder of the need for Europe to come together.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Everybody has to step up here and take responsibility – and the Commission will do just that.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The Commission is now working on a plan for a joint pilot with the Greek authorities for a new camp on Lesvos.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We can assist with asylum and return processes and significantly improve the conditions for the refugees.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But I want to be clear: if we step up, then I expect all Member States to step up too.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Migration is a European challenge and all of Europe must do its part.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We must rebuild the trust amongst us and move forward together.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And this trust is at the very heart of our Union and the way we do things together.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It is anchored in our founding values, our democracies and in our Community of Law – as Walter Hallstein used to call it.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is not an abstract term.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The rule of law helps protect people from the rule of the powerful.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It is the guarantor of our most basic of every day rights and freedoms.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It allows us to give our opinion and be informed by a free press.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Before the end of the month, the Commission will adopt the first annual rule of law report covering all Member States.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It is a preventive tool for early detection of challenges and for finding solutions.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: I want this to be a starting point for Commission, Parliament and Member States to ensure there is no backsliding.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The Commission attaches the highest importance to the rule of law.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is why we will ensure that money from our budget and NextGenerationEU is protected against any kind of fraud, corruption and conflict of interest.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is non-negotiable.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But the last months have also reminded us how fragile it can be.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We have a duty to always be vigilant to care and nurture for the rule of law.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Breaches of the rule of law cannot be tolerated.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: I will continue to defend it and the integrity of our European institutions.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Be it about the primacy of European law, the freedom of the press, the independence of the judiciary or the sale of golden passports.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: European values are not for sale.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Honourable Members,

These values are more important than ever.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: I say that because when I think about the state of our Union, I am reminded of the words of John Hume – one of the great Europeans who sadly passed away this year.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: If so many people live in peace today on the island of Ireland, it is in large part because of his unwavering belief in humanity and conflict resolution.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: He used to say that conflict was about difference and that peace was about respect for difference.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And as he so rightly reminded this House in 1998: “The European visionaries decided that difference is not a threat, difference is natural.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Difference is the essence of humanity”.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: These words are just as important today as they ever have been.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Because when we look around, we ask ourselves, where is the essence of humanity when three children in Wisconsin watch their father shot by police while they sit in the car?

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We ask where is the essence of humanity when anti-semitic carnival costumes openly parade on our streets?

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Where is the essence of humanity when every single day Roma people are excluded from society and others are held back simply because of the colour of their skin or their religious belief?

speaker: Leyen
sentence: I am proud to live in Europe, in this open society of values and diversity.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But even here in this Union – these stories are a daily reality for so many people.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And this reminds us that progress on fighting racism and hate is fragile – it is hard won but very easily lost.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: So now is the moment to make change.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: To build a truly anti-racist Union – that goes from condemnation to action.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And the Commission is putting forward an action plan to start making that happen.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: As part of this, we will propose to extend the list of EU crimes to all forms of hate crime and hate speech – whether because of race, religion, gender or sexuality.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Hate is hate – and no one should have to put up with it.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We will strengthen our racial equality laws where there are gaps.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We will use our budget to address discrimination in areas such as employment, housing or healthcare.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We will get tougher on enforcement when implementation lags behind.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Because in this Union, fighting racism will never be optional.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We will improve education and knowledge on the historical, cultural causes of racism.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We will tackle unconscious bias that exists in people, institutions and even in algorithms.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we will appoint the Commission's first-ever anti-racism coordinator to keep this at the top of our agenda and to work directly with people, civil society and institutions.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Honourable Members,

I will not rest when it comes to building a Union of equality.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: A Union where you can be who you are and love who you want – without fear of recrimination or discrimination.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Because being yourself is not your ideology.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It's your identity.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And no one can ever take it away.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: So I want to be crystal clear – LGBTQI-free zones are humanity free zones.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And they have no place in our Union.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And to make sure that we support the whole community, the Commission will soon put forward a strategy to strengthen LGBTQI rights.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: As part of this, I will also push for mutual recognition of family relations in the EU.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: If you are parent in one country, you are parent in every country.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
CONCLUSION

Honourable Members,

This is the world we want to live in.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Where we are united in diversity and adversity.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Where we work together to overcome our differences – and pull each other through when times are hard.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Where we build today the healthier, stronger and more respectful world we want our children to live in tomorrow.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But while we try to teach our children about life, our children are busy teaching us what life is about.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The last year has shown us just how true this really is.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We could speak of the millions of young people asking for change for a better planet.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Or of the hundreds of thousands of beautiful rainbows of solidarity posted in the windows of Europe by our children.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But there is one image that stuck in my mind from the last six difficult months.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: An image that captures the world through the eyes of our children.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It is the image of Carola and Vittoria.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The two young girls playing tennis between the rooftops of Liguria, Italy.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It is not just the courage and talent of the girls that sticks out.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It is the lesson behind it.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: About not allowing obstacles stand in your way, about not letting conventions hold you back, about seizing the moment.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is what Carola, Vittoria and all the young people of Europe teach us about life every day.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It is what Europe's next generation is all about.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is NextGenerationEU.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This year, Europe took a leaf out of their book and took a leap forward together.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: When we had to find a way forward for our future, we did not allow old conventions hold us back.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: When we felt fragility around us, we seized the moment to breathe new vitality into our Union.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: When we had a choice to go it alone like we have done in the past, we used the combined strength of the 27 to give all 27 a chance for the future.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We showed that we are in this together and we will get out of this together.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Honourable Members,

The future will be what we make it.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And Europe will be what we want it to be.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: So let's stop talking it down.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And let's get to work for it.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Let's make it strong.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And let's build the world we want to live in.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Long live Europe!

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
STRENGTHENING THE SOUL OF OUR UNION

 

Introduction

 

Mr President,
Honourable Members,

Many are the people who feel their lives have been on pause while the world has been on fast forward.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The speed of events and the enormity of the challenges are sometimes difficult to grasp.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This has also been a time of soul-searching.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: From people reassessing their own lives to wider debates on sharing vaccines and on shared values.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But as I look back on this past year, if I look at the state of the Union today, I see a strong soul in everything that we do.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It was Robert Schuman who said: Europe needs a soul, an ideal, and the political will to serve this ideal.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Europe has brought those words to life in the last twelve months.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: In the biggest global health crisis for a century, we chose to go it together so that every part of Europe got the same access to a life-saving vaccine.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: In the deepest global economic crisis for decades, we chose to go it together with NextGenerationEU.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And in the gravest planetary crisis of all time, again we chose to go it together with the European Green Deal.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We did that together as Commission, as Parliament, as 27 Member States.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: As one Europe.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we can be proud of it.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But corona times are not over.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: There is still much grief in our society as the pandemic lingers.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: There are hearts we can never mend, life stories we can never finish and time we can never give back to our young.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We face new and enduring challenges in a world recovering – and fracturing – unevenly.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: So there is no question: the next year will be yet another test of character.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But I believe that it is when you are tested that your spirit – your soul - truly shines through.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: As I look across our Union, I know that Europe will pass that test.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And what gives me that confidence is the inspiration we can draw from Europe's young people.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Because our youth put meaning into empathy and solidarity.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: They believe we have a responsibility towards the planet.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And while they are anxious about the future, they are determined to make it better.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Our Union will be stronger if it is more like our next generation: reflective, determined and caring.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Grounded in values and bold in action.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This spirit will be more important than ever over the next twelve months.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is the message in the Letter of Intent I sent this morning to President Sassoli and Prime Minister Janša to outline our priorities for the year ahead.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
A EUROPE UNITED THROUGH ADVERSITY AND RECOVERY

Honourable Members,

A year is a long time in a pandemic.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: When I stood in front of you 12 months ago, I did not know when – or even if – we would have a safe and effective vaccine against COVID-19.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But today, and against all critics, Europe is among the world leaders.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: More than 70 per cent of adults in the EU are fully vaccinated.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We were the only ones to share half of our vaccine production with the rest of the world.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We delivered more than 700 million doses to the European people, and we delivered more than another 700 million doses to the rest of the world, to more than 130 countries.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We are the only region in the world to achieve that.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: A pandemic is a marathon, not a sprint.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We followed the science.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We delivered to Europe.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We delivered to the world.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We did it the right way, because we did it the European way.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And it worked!

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But while we have every reason to be confident, we have no reason to be complacent.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Our first – and most urgent – priority is to speed up global vaccination.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: With less than 1% of global doses administered in low-income countries, the scale of injustice and the level of urgency are obvious.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is one of the great geopolitical issues of our time.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Team Europe is investing one billion Euro to ramp up mRNA production capacity in Africa.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We have already committed to share 250 million doses.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: I can announce today that the Commission will add a new donation of another 200 million doses by the middle of next year.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is an investment in solidarity – but also in global health.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The second priority is to continue our efforts here in Europe.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We see worrisome divergences in vaccination rates in our Union.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: So we need to keep up the momentum.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And Europe is ready.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We have 1.8 billion additional doses secured.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is enough for us and our neighbourhood when booster shots are needed.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Let's do everything possible to ensure that this does not turn into a pandemic of the unvaccinated.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The final priority is to strengthen our pandemic preparedness.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Last year, I said it was time to build a European Health Union.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Today we are delivering.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: With our proposal we get the HERA authority up and running.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This will be a huge asset to deal with future health threats earlier and better.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We have the innovation and scientific capacity, the private sector knowledge, we have competent national authorities.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And now we need to bring all of that together, including massive funding.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: So I am proposing a new health preparedness and resilience mission for the whole of the EU.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And it should be backed up by Team Europe investment of EUR 50 billion by 2027.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: To make sure that no virus will ever turn a local epidemic into a global pandemic.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: There is no better return on investment than that.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Honourable Members,

The work on the European Health Union is a big step forward.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And I want to thank this House for your support.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We have shown that when we act together, we are able to act fast.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Take the EU digital certificate:

Today more than 400 million certificates have been generated across Europe.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: 42 countries in 4 continents are plugged in.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We proposed it in March.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: You pushed it!

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Three months later it was up and running.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Thanks to this joint effort, while the rest of the world talked about it, Europe just did it.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We did a lot of things right.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We moved fast to create SURE.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This supported over 31 million workers and 2.5 million companies across Europe.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We learned the lessons from the past when we were too divided and too delayed.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And the difference is stark: last time it took 8 years for the Eurozone GDP to get back to pre-crisis levels.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This time we expect 19 countries to be at pre-pandemic levels this year with the rest following next.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Growth in the euro area outpaced both the US and China in the last quarter.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But this is only the beginning.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And the lessons from the financial crisis should serve as a cautionary tale.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: At that time, Europe declared victory too soon and we paid the price for that.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we will not repeat the same mistake.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The good news is that with NextGenerationEU we will now invest in both short-term recovery and long-term prosperity.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We will address structural issues in our economy: from labour market reforms in Spain, to pension reforms in Slovenia or tax reform in Austria.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: In an unprecedented manner, we will invest in 5G and fibre.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But equally important is the investment in digital skills.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This task needs leaders' attention and a structured dialogue at top-level.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Our response provides a clear direction to markets and investors alike.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But, as we look ahead, we also need to reflect on how the crisis has affected the shape of our economy – from increased debt, to uneven impact on different sectors, or new ways of working.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: To do that, the Commission will relaunch the discussion on the Economic Governance Review in the coming weeks.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The aim is to build a consensus on the way forward well in time for 2023.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Honourable Members,

We will soon celebrate 30 years of the Single Market.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: For 30 years it has been the great enabler of progress and prosperity in Europe.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: At the outset of the pandemic, we defended it against the pressures of erosion and fragmentation.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: For our recovery, the Single Market is the driver of good jobs and competitiveness.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: That is particularly important in the digital single market.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We have made ambitious proposals in the last year.

speaker: Leyen
Leyen
sentence: Digital is the make-or-break issue.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And Member States share that view.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Digital spending in NextGenerationEU will even overshoot the 20% target.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: That reflects the importance of investing in our European tech sovereignty.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We have to double down to shape our digital transformation according to our own rules and values.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Allow me to focus on semi-conductors, those tiny chips that make everything work: from smartphones and electric scooters to trains or entire smart factories.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: There is no digital without chips.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And while we speak, whole production lines are already working at reduced speed - despite growing demand - because of a shortage of semi-conductors.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But while global demand has exploded, Europe's share across the entire value chain, from design to manufacturing capacity has shrunk.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We depend on state-of-the-art chips manufactured in Asia.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: So this is not just a matter of our competitiveness.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is also a matter of tech sovereignty.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: So let's put all of our focus on it.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We will present a new European Chips Act.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We need to link together our world-class research, design and testing capacities.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We need to coordinate EU and national investment along the value chain.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The aim is to jointly create a state-of-the-art European chip ecosystem, including production.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: That ensures our security of supply and will develop new markets for ground-breaking European tech.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Yes, this is a daunting task.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And I know that some claim it cannot be done.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But they said the same thing about Galileo 20 years ago.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And look what happened.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We got our act together.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Today European satellites provide the navigation system for more than 2 billion smartphones worldwide.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We are world leaders.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: So let's be bold again, this time with semi-conductors.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Honourable Members,

The pandemic has left deep scars that have also left their mark on our social market economy.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: For nights on end, we all stood at our windows and doors to applaud critical workers.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We felt how much we relied on all those women and men who work for lower wages, fewer protections and less security.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The applause may have faded away but the strength of feeling cannot.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is why the implementation of the European Pillar of Social Rights is so important – to ensure decent jobs, fairer working conditions, better healthcare and better balance in people's lives.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: If the pandemic taught us one thing, it is that time is precious.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And caring for someone you love is the most precious time of all.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We will come forward with a new European Care Strategy to support men and women in finding the best care and the best life balance for them.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But social fairness is not just a question of time.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It is also a question of fair taxation.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: In our social market economy, it is good for companies to make profits.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And they make profits thanks to the quality of our infrastructure, social security and education systems.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: So the very least we can expect is that they pay their fair share.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is why we will continue to crack down on tax avoidance and evasion.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We will put forward a new initiative to address those hiding profits behind shell entities.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we will do everything in our power to seal the historic global deal on minimum taxation.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Asking big companies to pay the right amount of tax is not only a question of public finances, but above all a question of basic fairness.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Honourable Members,

We have all benefited from the principles of our European social market economy – and we must make sure that the next generation can do so to build their future.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is our most educated, talented and motivated generation.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And it has missed out on so much to keep others safe.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Being young is normally a time of discovery, of creating new experiences.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: A time to meet lifelong friends, to find your own path.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And what did we ask this generation to do?

speaker: Leyen
sentence: To keep their social distance, to stay locked down and to do school from home.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: For more than a year.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is why everything that we do – from the European Green Deal to NextGenerationEU – is about protecting their future.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: That is also why NextGenerationEU must be funded by the new own resources that we are working on.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But we must also caution against creating new divides.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Because Europe needs all of its youth.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We must step up our support to those who fall into the gaps – those not in any kind of employment, education or training.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: For them, we will put in place a new programme, ALMA.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: ALMA will help these young Europeans to find temporary work experience in another Member State.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Because they too deserve an experience like Erasmus.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: To gain skills, to create bonds and help forge their own European identity.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But if we are to shape our Union in their mould, young people must be able to shape Europe's future.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Our Union needs a soul and a vision they can connect to.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Or as Jacques Delors asked:  How can we ever build Europe if young people do not see it as a collective project and a vision of their own future?

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is why we will propose to make 2022 the Year of European Youth.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: A year dedicated to empowering those who have dedicated so much to others.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And it is why we will make sure that young people can help lead the debate in the Conference on the Future of Europe.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is their future and this must be their Conference too.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And as we said when we took office, the Commission will be ready to follow up on what is agreed by the Conference.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
A EUROPE UNITED IN RESPONSIBILITY

Honourable Members,

This is a generation with a conscience.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: They are pushing us to go further and faster to tackle the climate crisis.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And events of the summer only served to explain why.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We saw floods in Belgium and Germany.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And wildfires burning from the Greek islands to the hills in France.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And if we don't believe our own eyes, we only have to follow the science.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The UN recently published the IPCC report, the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It is the authority on the science of climate change.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The report leaves no doubt.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Climate change is man-made.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But since it is man-made, we can do something about it.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: As I heard it said recently:  It's warming.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It's us.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We're sure.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It's bad.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But we can fix it.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And change is already happening.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: More electric vehicles than diesel cars were registered in Germany in the first half of this year.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Poland is now the EU's largest exporter of car batteries and electric buses.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Or take the New European Bauhaus that led to an explosion of creativity of architects, designers, engineers across our Union.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: So clearly something is on the move.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And this is what the European Green Deal is all about.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: In my speech last year, I announced our target of at least 55% emission reduction by 2030.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Since then we have together turned our climate goals into legal obligations.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we are the first major economy to present comprehensive legislation in order to get it done.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: You have seen the complexity of the detail.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But the goal is simple.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We will put a price on pollution.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We will clean the energy we use.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We will have smarter cars and cleaner airplanes.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we will make sure that higher climate ambition comes with more social ambition.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This must be a fair green transition.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is why we proposed a new Social Climate Fund to tackle the energy poverty that already 34 million Europeans suffer from.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: I count on both Parliament and Member States to keep the package and to keep the ambition together.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: When it comes to climate change and the nature crisis, Europe can do a lot.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And it will support others.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: I am proud to announce today that the EU will double its external funding for biodiversity, in particular for the most vulnerable countries.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But Europe cannot do it alone.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The COP26 in Glasgow will be a moment of truth for the global community.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Major economies – from the US to Japan – have set ambitions for climate neutrality in 2050 or shortly after.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: These need now to be backed up by concrete plans in time for Glasgow.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Because current commitments for 2030 will not keep global warming to 1.5°C within reach.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Every country has a responsibility!

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The goals that President Xi has set for China are encouraging.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But we call for that same leadership on setting out how China will get there.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The world would be relieved if they showed they could peak emissions by mid-decade - and move away from coal at home and abroad.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But while every country has a responsibility, major economies do have a special duty to the least developed and most vulnerable countries.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Climate finance is essential for them - both for mitigation and adaptation.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: In Mexico and in Paris, the major economies committed to provide 100 billion dollars a year until 2025 to the least developed and most vulnerable countries.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We deliver on our commitment.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Team Europe contributes 25 billion dollars per year.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But others still leave a gaping hole towards reaching the global target.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Closing that gap will increase the chance of success at Glasgow.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: My message today is that Europe is ready to do more.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We will now propose an additional 4 billion euro for climate finance until 2027.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But we expect the United States and our partners to step up too.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Closing the climate finance gap together – the US and the EU – would be a strong signal for global climate leadership.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It is time to deliver.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Honourable Members,

This climate and economic leadership is central to Europe's global and security objectives.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It also reflects a wider shift in world affairs at a time of transition towards a new international order.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We are entering a new era of hyper-competitiveness.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: An era in which some stop at nothing to gain influence: from vaccine promises and high-interest loans, to missiles and misinformation.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: An era of regional rivalries and major powers refocusing their attention towards each other.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Recent events in Afghanistan are not the cause of this change – but they are a symptom of it.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And first and foremost, I want to be clear.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We stand by the Afghan people.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The women and children, prosecutors, journalists and human rights defenders.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: I think in particular of women judges who are now in hiding from the men they jailed.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: They have been put at risk for their contribution to justice and the rule of law.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We must support them and we will coordinate all efforts with Member States to bring them to safety.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we must continue supporting all Afghans in the country and in neighbouring countries.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We must do everything to avert the real risk of a major famine and humanitarian disaster.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we will do our part.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We will increase again humanitarian aid for Afghanistan by 100 million euro.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This will be part of a new, wider Afghan Support Package that we will present in the next weeks to combine all of our efforts.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Honourable Members,

Witnessing events unfold in Afghanistan was profoundly painful for all the families of fallen servicemen and servicewomen.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We bow to the sacrifice of those soldiers, diplomats and aid workers who laid down their lives.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: To make sure that their service will never be in vain, we have to reflect on how this mission could end so abruptly.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: There are deeply troubling questions that allies will have to tackle within NATO.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But there is simply no security and defence issue where less cooperation is the answer.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We need to invest in our joint partnership and to draw on each side's unique strength.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is why we are working with Secretary-General Jens Stoltenberg on a new EU-NATO Joint Declaration to be presented before the end of the year.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But this is only one part of the equation.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Europe can – and clearly should – be able and willing to do more on its own.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But if we are to do more, we first need to explain why.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: I see three broad categories.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: First, we need to provide stability in our neighbourhood and across different regions.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We are connected to the world by narrow straits, stormy seas and vast land borders.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Because of that geography, Europe knows better than anyone that if you don't deal in time with the crisis abroad, the crisis comes to you.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Secondly, the nature of the threats we face is evolving rapidly: from hybrid or cyber-attacks to the growing arms race in space.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Disruptive technology has been a great equaliser in the way power can be used today by rogue states or non-state groups.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: You no longer need armies and missiles to cause mass damage.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: You can paralyse industrial plants, city administrations and hospitals – all you need is your laptop.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: You can disrupt entire elections with a smartphone and an internet connection.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The third reason is that the European Union is a unique security provider.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: There will be missions where NATO or the UN will not be present, but where the EU should be.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: On the ground, our soldiers work side-by-side with police officers, lawyers and doctors, with humanitarian workers and human rights defenders, with teachers and engineers.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We can combine military and civilian, along with diplomacy and development – and we have a long history in building and protecting peace.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The good news is that over the past years, we have started to develop a European defence ecosystem.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But what we need is the European Defence Union.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: In the last weeks, there have been many discussions on expeditionary forces.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: On what type and how many we need: battlegroups or EU entry forces.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is no doubt part of the debate – and I believe it will be part of the solution.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But the more fundamental issue is why this has not worked in the past.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: You can have the most advanced forces in the world – but if you are never prepared to use them - of what use are they?

speaker: Leyen
sentence: What has held us back until now is not just a shortfall of capacity – it is the lack of political will.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And if we develop this political will, there is a lot that we can do at EU level.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Allow me to give you three concrete examples:

First, we need to build the foundation for collective decision-making – this is what I call situational awareness.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We fall short if Member States active in the same region, do not share their information on the European level.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It is vital that we improve intelligence cooperation.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But this is not just about intelligence in the narrow sense.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It is about bringing together the knowledge from all services and all sources.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: From space to police trainers, from open source to development agencies.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Their work gives us a unique scope and depth of knowledge.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It is out there!

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But we can only use that, to make informed decisions if we have the full picture.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And this is currently not the case.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We have the knowledge, but it is disjoined.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Information is fragmented.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is why the EU could consider its own Joint Situational Awareness Centre to fuse all the different pieces of information.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And to be better prepared, to be fully informed and to be able to decide.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Secondly, we need to improve interoperability.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is why we are already investing in common European platforms, from fighter jets, to drones and cyber.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But we have to keep thinking of new ways to use all possible synergies.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: One example could be to consider waiving VAT when buying defence equipment developed and produced in Europe.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This would not only increase our interoperability, but also decrease our dependencies of today.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Third, we cannot talk about defence without talking about cyber.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: If everything is connected, everything can be hacked.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Given that resources are scarce, we have to bundle our forces.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we should not just be satisfied to address the cyber threat, but also strive to become a leader in cyber security.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It should be here in Europe where cyber defence tools are developed.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is why we need a European Cyber Defence Policy, including legislation on common standards under a new European Cyber Resilience Act.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: So, we can do a lot at EU level.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But Member States need to do more too.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This starts with a common assessment of the threats we face and a common approach to dealing with them.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The upcoming Strategic Compass is a key process of this discussion.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we need to decide how we can use all of the possibilities that are already in the Treaty.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is why, under the French Presidency, President Macron and I will convene a Summit on European defence.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It is time for Europe to step up to the next level.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Honourable Members,

In a more contested world, protecting your interests is not only about defending yourself.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It is about forging strong and reliable partnerships.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is not a luxury – it is essential for our future stability, security and prosperity.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This work starts by deepening our partnership with our closest allies.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: With the US we will develop our new agenda for global change – from the new Trade and Technology Council to health security and sustainability.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The EU and the US will always be stronger – together.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The same is true of our neighbours in the Western Balkans.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Before the end of the month, I will travel to the region to send a strong signal of our commitment to the accession process.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We owe it to all those young people who believe in a European future.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is why we are ramping up our support through our new investment and economic plan, worth around a third of the region's GDP.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Because an investment in the future of the Western Balkans is an investment in the future of the EU.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we will also continue investing in our partnerships across our neighbourhood – from stepping up our engagement in the Eastern Partnership to implementing the new Agenda for the Mediterranean and continuing to work on the different aspects of our relationship with Turkey.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Honourable Members,

If Europe is to become a more active global player, it also needs to focus on the next generation of partnerships.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: In this spirit, today's new EU - Indo-Pacific strategy is a milestone.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It reflects the growing importance of the region to our prosperity and security.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But also the fact that autocratic regimes use it to try to expand their influence.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Europe needs to be more present and more active in the region.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: So we will work together to deepen trade links, strengthen global supply chains and develop new investment projects on green and digital technologies.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is a template for how Europe can redesign its model to connect the world.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We are good at financing roads.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But it does not make sense for Europe to build a perfect road between a Chinese-owned copper mine and a Chinese-owned harbour.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We have to get smarter when it comes to these kinds of investments.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is why we will soon present our new connectivity strategy called Global Gateway.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We will build Global Gateway partnerships with countries around the world.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We want investments in quality infrastructure, connecting goods, people and services around the world.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We will take a values-based approach, offering transparency and good governance to our partners.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We want to create links and not dependencies!

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we know how this can work.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Since the summer, a new underwater fibre optic cable has connected Brazil to Portugal.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We will invest with Africa to create a market for green hydrogen that connects the two shores of the Mediterranean.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We need a Team Europe approach to make Global Gateway happen.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We will connect institutions and investment, banks and the business community.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we will make this a priority for regional summits – starting with the next EU-Africa Summit in February.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We want to turn Global Gateway into a trusted brand around the world.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And let me be very clear: doing business around the world, global trade – all that is good and necessary.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But this can never be done at the expense of people's dignity and freedom.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: There are 25 million people out there, who are threatened or coerced into forced labour.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We can never accept that they are forced to make products – and that these products then end up for sale in shops here in Europe.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: So we will propose a ban on products in our market that have been made by forced labour.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Human rights are not for sale – at any price.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
A EUROPE UNITED IN FREEDOM AND DIVERSITY

 

And, Honourable Members, human beings are not bargaining chips.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Look at what happened at our borders with Belarus.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The regime in Minsk has instrumentalised human beings.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: They have put people on planes and literally pushed them towards Europe's borders.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This can never be tolerated.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And the quick European reaction shows that.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And rest assured, we will continue to stand together with Lithuania, Latvia and Poland.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And, let's call it what it is: this is a hybrid attack to destabilise Europe.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Honourable Members,

These are not isolated events.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We saw similar incidents at other borders.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we can expect to see it again.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is why, as part of our work on Schengen, we will set out new ways to respond to such aggression and ensure unity in protecting our external borders.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But as long as we do not find common ground on how to manage migration, our opponents will continue to target that.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Meanwhile, human traffickers continue to exploit people through deadly routes across the Mediterranean.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: These events show us that every country has a stake in building a European migration system.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The New Pact on Migration and Asylum gives us everything we need to manage the different types of situations we face.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: All the elements are there.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is a balanced and humane system that works for all Member States - in all circumstances.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We know that we can find common ground.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But in the year since the Commission presented the Pact, progress has been painfully slow.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: I think, this is the moment now for a European migration management policy.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: So I urge you, in this House and in Member States, to speed up the process.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This ultimately comes down to a question of trust.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Trust between Member States.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Trust for Europeans that migration can be managed.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Trust that Europe will always live up to its enduring duty to the most vulnerable and most in need.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: There are many strongly held views on migration in Europe but I believe the common ground is not so far away.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Because if you ask most Europeans, they would agree that we should act to curb irregular migration but also act to provide a refuge for those forced to flee.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: They would agree that we should return those who have no right to stay.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But that we should welcome those who come here legally and make such a vital contribution to our society and economy.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we should all agree that the topic of migration should never be used to divide.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: I am convinced that there is a way that Europe can build trust amongst us when it comes to migration.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Honourable Members,

Societies that build on democracy and common values stand on stable ground.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: They have trust in people.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is how new ideas are formed, how change happens, how injustices are overcome.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Trust in these common values brought our founders together, after World War Two.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And it is these same values that united the freedom fighters who tore down the Iron Curtain over 30 years ago.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: They wanted democracy.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: They wanted the freedom to choose their government.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: They wanted the rule of law and for everyone to be equal before the law.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: They wanted freedom of speech and independent media.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: To no longer be spied on by their governments.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: They wanted to combat corruption.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And the freedom to be different from the majority.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Or, as former Czech President Václav Havel put it, they wanted all those "great European values".

speaker: Leyen
sentence: These values come from the cultural, religious and humanist heritage of Europe.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: They are part of our soul, part of what defines us today.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: These values are now enshrined in our European treaties.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is what we all signed up to when we became part of this Union as free and sovereign countries.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We are determined to defend these values.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we will never waver in that determination.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Our values are guaranteed by our legal order and safeguarded by the judgments of the European Court of Justice.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: These judgments are binding.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We make sure that they are respected.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we do so in every Member State of our Union.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Because protecting the rule of law is not just a noble goal.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Protecting the rule of law is also hard work and a constant struggle for improvement.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Our Rule of Law reports are part of this process, with for example justice reforms in Malta or corruption inquiries in Slovakia.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And from 2022, our Rule of Law reports will come with specific recommendations to Member States.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Nevertheless, there are worrying developments in certain Member States.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Let me be clear: dialogue always comes first.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But dialogue is not an end in itself, it should lead to results.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is why we take a dual approach of dialogue and decisive action.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is what we did last week.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And this is what we will continue to do.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Because people must be able to rely on the right to an independent judiciary.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The right to be treated equally before the law.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Everywhere in Europe.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Whether you belong to a majority or a minority.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Honourable Members,

The European budget is the future of our Union cast in figures.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: That is why it must be protected.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We need to ensure that every euro and every cent is spent for its proper purpose and in line with rule of law principles.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Investments that enable our children to have a better future must not be allowed to seep away into dark channels.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Corruption is not just taxpayer money stolen.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It is investors scared off, big favours bought by big money and democracy undermined by the powerful.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: When it comes to protecting our budget, we will pursue every case, with everything in our power.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Honourable Members,

Defending our values is also defending freedom.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Freedom to be who you are, freedom to say what's on your mind, freedom to love whoever you want.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But freedom also means freedom from fear.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And during the pandemic, too many women were deprived of that freedom.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It was an acutely terrifying time for those with nowhere to hide, nowhere to escape from their abusers.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We need to shed light on this darkness, we need to show ways out of the pain.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Their abusers must be brought to justice.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And those women must have their freedom and their self-determination back.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is why by the end of year, we will propose a law to combat violence against women – from prevention to protection and effective prosecution, online and offline.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It is about defending the dignity of each individual.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It is about justice.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Because this is the soul of Europe.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we must make it even stronger.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Honourable members,

Allow me to finish with one of the freedoms that gives voice to all other freedoms – media freedom.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Journalists are being targeted simply for doing their job.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Some have been threatened, some beaten and, tragically, some murdered.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Right here, in our European Union.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Let me mention some of their names: Daphné Caruana Galizia.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Ján Kuciak.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Peter de Vries.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The details of their stories may be different but what they have in common is that they all fought and died for our right to be informed.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Information is a public good.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We must protect those who create transparency – the journalists.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: That is why today we have put forward a recommendation to give journalists better protection.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we need to stop those who threaten media freedom.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Media companies cannot be treated as just another business.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Their independence is essential.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Europe needs a law that safeguards this independence – and the Commission will deliver a Media Freedom Act in the next year.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Defending media freedom means defending our democracy.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Conclusion

Honourable Members,

Strengthening Schuman's European ideal that I invoked earlier is a continuous work.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we should not hide away from our inconsistencies and imperfections.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But imperfect as it might be, our Union is both beautifully unique and uniquely beautiful.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It is a Union where we strengthen our individual liberty through the strength of our community.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: A Union shaped as much by our shared history and values as by our different cultures and perspectives.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: A Union with a soul.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Trying to find the right words to capture the essence of this feeling is not easy.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But it is easier when you borrow them from someone who inspires you.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And this is why I have invited a guest of honour to be with us today.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Many of you might know her – a gold medallist from Italy who captured my heart this summer.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But what you might not know is that only in April, she was told her life was in peril.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: She went through surgery, she fought back, she recovered.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And only 119 days after she left the hospital, she won Paralympic gold.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Honourable Members, please join me in welcoming Beatrice Vio.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Bebe has overcome so much, so young.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Her story is one of rising against all odds.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Of succeeding thanks to talent, tenacity and unrelenting positivity.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: She is in the image of her generation: a leader and an advocate for the causes she believes in.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And she has managed to achieve all of that by living up to her belief that - if it seems impossible – then it can be done.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Se sembra impossibile, allora si può fare.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This was the spirit of Europe's founders and this is the spirit of Europe's next generation.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: So let's be inspired by Bebe and by all the young people who change our perception of the possible.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Who show us that you can be what you want to be.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And that you can achieve whatever you believe.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Honourable Members:

This is the soul of Europe.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is the future of Europe.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Let's make it stronger together.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Viva l'Europa.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
A UNION THAT STANDS STRONG TOGETHER

 

INTRODUCTION

Madam President,

Honourable Members,

My fellow Europeans,

Never before has this Parliament debated the State of our Union with war raging on European soil.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We all remember that fateful morning in late February.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Europeans from across our Union woke up dismayed by what they saw.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Shaken by the resurgent and ruthless face of evil.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Haunted by the sounds of sirens and the sheer brutality of war.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But from that very moment, a whole continent has risen in solidarity.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: At the border crossings where refugees found shelter.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: In our streets, filled with Ukrainian flags.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: In the classrooms, where Ukrainian children made new friends.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: From that very moment, Europeans neither hid nor hesitated.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: They found the courage to do the right thing.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And from that very moment, our Union as a whole has risen to the occasion.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Fifteen years ago, during the financial crisis, it took us years to find lasting solutions.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: A decade later, when the global pandemic hit, it took us only weeks.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But this year, as soon as Russian troops crossed the border into Ukraine, our response was united, determined and immediate.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we should be proud of that.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We have brought Europe's inner strength back to the surface.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we will need all of this strength.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The months ahead of us will not be easy.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Be it for families who are struggling to make ends meet, or businesses, who are facing tough choices about their future.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Let us be very clear: much is at stake here.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Not just for Ukraine – but for all of Europe and the world at large.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we will be tested.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Tested by those who want to exploit any kind of divisions between us.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is not only a war unleashed by Russia against Ukraine.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is a war on our energy, a war on our economy, a war on our values and a war on our future.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is about autocracy against democracy.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And I stand here with the conviction that with courage and solidarity, Putin will fail and Europe will prevail.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
THE COURAGE TO STAND WITH OUR HEROES

Honourable Members,

Today - courage has a name, and that name is Ukraine.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Courage has a face, the face of Ukrainian men and women who are standing up to Russian aggression.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: I remember a moment in the early weeks of the invasion.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: When the First Lady of Ukraine, Olena Zelenska, gathered the parents of Ukrainian children killed by the invader.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Hundreds of families for whom the war will never end, and for whom life will never go back to what it was before.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We saw the first Lady leading a silent crowd of heartbroken mothers and fathers, and hang small bells in the trees, one for every fallen child.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And now the bells will ring forever in the wind, and forever, the innocent victims of this war will live in our memory.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And she is here with us today!

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Dear Olena, it took immense courage to resist Putin's cruelty.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But you found that courage.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And a nation of heroes has risen.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Today, Ukraine stands strong because an entire country has fought street by street, home by home.
