speaker: Leyen
sentence: Ukraine stands strong because people like your husband, President Zelenskyy, have stayed in Kyiv to lead the resistance – together with you and your children, dear First Lady.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: You have given courage to the whole nation.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we have seen in the last days the bravery of Ukrainians paying off.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: You have given voice to your people on the global stage.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And you have given hope to all of us.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: So today we want to thank you and all Ukrainians.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Glory to a country of European heroes.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Slava Ukraini!

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Europe's solidarity with Ukraine will remain unshakeable.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: From day one, Europe has stood at Ukraine's side.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: With weapons.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: With funds.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: With hospitality for refugees.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And with the toughest sanctions the world has ever seen.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Russia's financial sector is on life-support.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We have cut off three quarters of Russia's banking sector from international markets.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Nearly one thousand international companies have left the country.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The production of cars fell by three-quarters compared to last year.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Aeroflot is grounding planes because there are no more spare parts.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The Russian military is taking chips from dishwashers and refrigerators to fix their military hardware, because they ran out of semiconductors.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Russia's industry is in tatters.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It is the Kremlin that has put Russia's economy on the path to oblivion.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is the price for Putin's trail of death and destruction.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And I want to make it very clear, the sanctions are here to stay.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is the time for us to show resolve, not appeasement.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The same is true for our financial support to Ukraine.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: So far Team Europe have provided more than 19 billion euros in financial assistance.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And this is without counting our military support.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we are in it for the long haul.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Ukraine's reconstruction will require massive resources.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: For instance, Russian strikes have damaged or destroyed more than 70 schools.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Half a million Ukrainian children have started their school year in the European Union.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But many others inside Ukraine simply don't have a classroom to go to.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: So today I am announcing that we will work with the First Lady to support the rehabilitation of damaged Ukrainian schools.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And that is why we will provide 100 million euros.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Because the future of Ukraine begins in its schools.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We will not only support with finance – but also empower Ukraine to make the most of its potential.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Ukraine is already a rising tech hub and home to many innovative young companies.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: So I want us to mobilise the full power of our Single Market to help accelerate growth and create opportunities.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: In March, we connected successfully Ukraine to our electricity grid.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It was initially planned for 2024.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But we did it within two weeks.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And today, Ukraine is exporting electricity to us.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: I want to significantly expand this mutually beneficial trade.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We have already suspended import duties on Ukrainian exports to the EU.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We will bring Ukraine into our European free roaming area.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Our solidarity lanes are a big success.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And building on all that, the Commission will work with Ukraine to ensure seamless access to the Single Market.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And vice-versa.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Our Single Market is one of Europe's greatest success stories.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Now it's time to make it a success story for our Ukrainian friends, too.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And this is why I am going to Kyiv today, to discuss this in detail with President Zelenskyy.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Honourable Members,

One lesson from this war is we should have listened to those who know Putin.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: To Anna Politkovskaya and all the Russian journalists who exposed the crimes, and paid the ultimate price.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: To our friends in Ukraine, Moldova, Georgia, and to the opposition in Belarus.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We should have listened to the voices inside our Union – in Poland, in the Baltics, and all across Central and Eastern Europe.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: They have been telling us for years that Putin would not stop.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And they acted accordingly.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Our friends in the Baltics have worked hard to end their dependency on Russia.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: They have invested in renewable energy, in LNG terminals, and in interconnectors.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This costs a lot.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But dependency on Russian fossil fuels comes at a much higher price.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We have to get rid of this dependency all over Europe.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Therefore we agreed on joint storage.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We are at 84% now: we are overshooting our target.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But unfortunately that will not be enough.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We have diversified away from Russia to reliable suppliers.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: US, Norway, Algeria and others.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Last year, Russian gas accounted for 40% of our gas imports.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Today it's down to 9% pipeline gas.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But Russia keeps on actively manipulating our energy market.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: They prefer to flare the gas than to deliver it.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This market is not functioning anymore.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: In addition the climate crisis is heavily weighing on our bills.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Heat waves have boosted electricity demand.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Droughts shut down hydro and nuclear plants.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: As a result, gas prices have risen by more than 10 times compared to before the pandemic.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Making ends meet is becoming a source of anxiety for millions of businesses and households.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But Europeans are also coping courageously with this.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Workers in ceramics factories in central Italy, have decided to move their shifts to early morning, to benefit from lower energy prices.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Just imagine the parents among them, having to leave home early, when the kids are still sleeping, because of a war they haven't chosen.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is one example in a million of Europeans adapting to this new reality.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: I want our Union to take example from its people.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Reducing demand during peak hours will make supply last longer, and it will bring prices down.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is why we are putting forward measures for Member States to reduce their overall electricity consumption.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But more targeted supported is needed.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: For industries, like glass makers who have to turn off their ovens.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Or for single parents facing one daunting bill after another.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Millions of Europeans need support.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: EU Member States have already invested billions of euros to assist vulnerable households.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But we know this will not be enough.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is why we are proposing a cap on the revenues of companies that produce electricity at a low cost.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: These companies are making revenues they never accounted for, they never even dreamt of.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: In our social market economy, profits are good.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But in these times it is wrong to receive extraordinary record profits benefitting from war and on the back of consumers.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: In these times, profits must be shared and channelled to those who need it the most.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Our proposal will raise more than 140 billion euros for Member States to cushion the blow directly.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And because we are in a fossil fuel crisis, the fossil fuel industry has a special duty, too.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Major oil, gas and coal companies are also making huge profits.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: So they have to pay a fair share – they have to give a crisis contribution.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: These are all emergency and temporary measures we are working on, including our discussions on price caps.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We need to keep working to lower gas prices.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We have to ensure our security of supply and, at the same time, ensure our global competitiveness.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: So we will develop with the Member States a set of measures that take into account the specific nature of our relationship with suppliers – ranging from unreliable suppliers such as Russia to reliable friends such as Norway.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: I have agreed with Prime Minister Store to set up a task force.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Teams have started their work.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Another important topic is on the agenda.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Today our gas market has changed dramatically: from pipeline mainly to increasing amounts of LNG.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But the benchmark used in the gas market – the TTF – has not adapted.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is why the Commission will work on establishing a more representative benchmark.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: At the same time we also know that energy companies are facing severe problems with liquidity in electricity futures markets, risking the functioning of our energy system.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We will work with market regulators to ease these problems by amending the rules on collateral - and by taking measures to limit intra-day price volatility.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we will amend the temporary state aid framework in October to allow for the provision of state guarantees, while preserving a level playing field.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: These are all first steps.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But as we deal with this immediate crisis, we must also look forward.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The current electricity market design – based on merit order – is not doing justice to consumers anymore.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: They should reap the benefits of low-cost renewables.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: So, we have to decouple the dominant influence of gas on the price of electricity.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is why we will do a deep and comprehensive reform of the electricity market.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Now - here is an important point.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Half a century ago, in the 1970s, the world faced another fossil fuel crisis.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Some of us remember the car-free weekends to save energy.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Yet we kept driving on the same road.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We did not get rid of our dependency on oil.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And worse, fossil fuels were even massively subsidised.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This was wrong, not just for the climate, but also for our public finances, and our independence.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we are still paying for this today.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Only a few visionaries understood that the real problem was fossil fuels themselves, not just their price.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Among them were our Danish friends.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: When the oil crisis hit, Denmark started to invest heavily into harnessing the power of the wind.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: They laid the foundations for its global leadership in the sector and created tens of thousands of new jobs.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is the way to go!

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Not just a quick fix, but a change of paradigm, a leap into the future.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
STAYING THE COURSE AND PREPARING FOR THE FUTURE

Honourable Members,

The good news is: this necessary transformation has started.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It is happening in the North Sea and the Baltic Sea, where our Member States agreed to invest massively into off-shore wind generation.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It is happening in Sicily, where Europe's largest solar factory will soon manufacture the newest generation of panels.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And it is happening in Northern Germany, where local trains now run on green hydrogen.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And hydrogen can be a game changer for Europe.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We need to move our hydrogen economy from niche to scale.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: With REPowerEU, we have doubled our 2030 target to produce ten million tons of renewable hydrogen in the EU, each year.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: To achieve this, we must create a market maker for hydrogen, in order to bridge the investment gap and connect future supply and demand.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: That is why I can today announce that we will create a new European Hydrogen Bank.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It will help guarantee the purchase of hydrogen, notably by using resources from the Innovation Fund.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It will be able to invest 3 billion euros to help building the future market for hydrogen.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is how we power the economy of the future.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is the European Green Deal.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we have all seen in the last months just how important the European Green Deal is.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The summer of 2022 will be remembered as a turning point.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We all saw the dry rivers, the burning forests, the impact of the extreme heat.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And under the surface, the situation is far starker.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: So far the glaciers in the Alps helped as an emergency reserve for rivers like the Rhine or Rhone.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But with Europe's glaciers melting faster than ever, future droughts will be felt far more acutely.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We must work relentlessly to adapt to our climate – making nature our first ally.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is why our Union will push for an ambitious global deal for nature at the UN Biodiversity conference in Montreal later this year.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we will do the same at COP27 in Sharm el-Sheikh.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But in the short term, we also need to be better equipped to handle our changing climate.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The destructive power of extreme weather is too big for any country to fight on its own.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This summer, we sent planes from Greece, Sweden and Italy to fight fires in France and Germany.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But as disasters become more frequent and more intense, Europe will need more capacity.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is why I can today announce that we will double our firefighting capacity over the next year.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The EU will buy another 10 light amphibious aircrafts and three helicopters to add to the fleet.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is European solidarity in action.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Honourable Members,

The last years have shown how much Europe can achieve when it is united.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: After an unprecedented pandemic, our economic output overtook pre-crisis levels in record time.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We went from having no vaccine to securing over 4 billion doses for Europeans and for the world.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And in record time, we came up with SURE – so that people could stay in their jobs even if their companies had run out of work.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We were in the deepest recession since World War 2.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
We achieved the fastest recovery since the post-war boom

And that was possible because we all rallied behind a common recovery plan.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: NextGenerationEU has been a boost of confidence for our economy.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And its journey has only just begun.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: So far, 100 billion euros have been disbursed to Member States.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This means: 700 billion euros still haven't flown into our economy.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: NextGenerationEU will guarantee a constant stream of investment to sustain jobs and growth.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It means relief for our economy.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But most importantly, it means renewal.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It is financing new wind turbines and solar parks, high-speed trains and energy-saving renovations.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We conceived NextGenerationEU almost two years ago, and yet it is exactly what Europe needs today.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: So let's stick to the plan.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Let's get the money on the ground.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Honourable Members,

The future of our children needs both that we invest in sustainability and that we invest sustainably.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We must finance the transition to a digital and net-zero economy.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And yet we also have to acknowledge a new reality of higher public debt.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We need fiscal rules that allow for strategic investment, while safeguarding fiscal sustainability.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Rules that are fit for the challenges of this decade.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: In October, we will come forward with new ideas for our economic governance.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But let me share a few basic principles with you.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Member States should have more flexibility on their debt reduction paths.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But there should be more accountability on the delivery of what we have agreed on.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: There should be simpler rules that all can follow.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: To open the space for strategic investment and to give financial markets the confidence they need.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Let us chart once again a joint way forward.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: With more freedom to invest.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And more scrutiny on progress.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: More ownership by Member States.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And better results for citizens.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Let us rediscover the Maastricht spirit – stability and growth can only go hand in hand.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Honourable Members,

As we embark on this transition in our economy, we must rely on the enduring values of our social market economy.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It's the simple idea that Europe's greatest strength lies in each and every one of us.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Our social market economy encourages everyone to excel, but it also takes care of our fragility as human beings.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It rewards performance and guarantees protection.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It opens opportunities but also set limits.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We need this even more today.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Because the strength of our social market economy will drive the green and digital transition.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We need an enabling business environment, a workforce with the right skills and access to raw materials our industry needs.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Our future competitiveness depends on it.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We must remove the obstacles that still hold our small companies back.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: They must be at the centre of this transformation – because they are the backbone of Europe's long history of industrial prowess.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And they have always put their employees first – even and especially in times of crisis.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But inflation and uncertainty are weighing especially hard on them.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is why we will put forward an SME Relief Package.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It will include a proposal for a single set of tax rules for doing business in Europe – we call it BEFIT.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This will make it easier to do business in our Union.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Less red tape means better access to the dynamism of a continental market.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we will revise the Late Payment Directive – because it is simply not fair that 1 in 4 bankruptcies are due to invoices not being paid on time.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: For millions of family businesses, this will be a lifeline in troubled waters.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But European companies are also grappling with a shortage of staff.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Unemployment is at a record low, and this is great.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: At the same time, job vacancies are at a record high.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Europe lacks truck drivers, waiters and airport workers,

as well as nurses, engineers and IT technicians.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Both low-end and high-end.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We need everyone on board.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We need much more focus in our investment on professional education and upskilling.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We need better cooperation with the companies, because they know best what they need.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we need to match these needs with people's aspirations.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But we also have to attract the right skills to our continent, skills that help companies and strengthen Europe's growth.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: As a first important step, we need to speed up and facilitate the recognition of qualifications also of third country nationals.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This will make Europe more attractive for skilled workers.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is why I am proposing to make 2023 the European Year of Skills.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Honourable Members,

My third point for our SMEs and our industry.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Whether we talk about chips for virtual reality or cells for solar panels, the twin transitions will be fuelled by raw materials

Lithium and rare earths are already replacing gas and oil at the heart of our economy.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: By 2030, our demand for those rare earth metals will increase fivefold.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And this is a good sign, because it shows that our European Green Deal is moving fast.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The not so good news is – one country dominates the market.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: So we have to avoid falling into the same dependency as with oil and gas.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is where our trade policy comes into play.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: New partnerships will advance not only our vital interests – but also our values.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Trade that embraces workers' rights and the highest environmental standards is possible with like-minded partners.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We need to update our links to reliable countries and key growth regions.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And for this reason, I intend to put forward for ratification the agreements with Chile, Mexico and New Zealand.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And advance negotiations with key partners like Australia and India.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But securing supplies is only a first step.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The processing of these metals is just as critical.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Today, China controls the global processing industry.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Almost 90 % of rare earths and 60 % of lithium are processed in China.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We will identify strategic projects all along the supply chain, from extraction to refining, from processing to recycling.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we will build up strategic reserves where supply is at risk.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is why today I am announcing a European Critical Raw Materials Act.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We know this approach can work.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Five years ago, Europe launched the Battery Alliance.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And soon, two third of the batteries we need will be produced in Europe.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Last year I announced the European Chips Act.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And the first chips gigafactory will break ground in the coming months.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We now need to replicate this success.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is also why we will increase our financial participation to Important Projects of Common European Interest.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And for the future, I will push to create a new European Sovereignty Fund.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Let's make sure that the future of industry is made in Europe.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
STANDING UP FOR OUR DEMOCRACY

Honourable Members,

As we look around at the state of the world today, it can often feel like there is a fading away of what once seemed so permanent.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And in some way, the passing of Queen Elizabeth II last week reminded us of this.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: She is a legend!

speaker: Leyen
sentence: She was a constant throughout the turbulent and transforming events in the last 70 years.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Stoic and steadfast in her service.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But more than anything, she always found the right words for every moment in time.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: From the calls she made to war evacuees in 1940 to her historic address during the pandemic.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: She spoke not only to the heart of her nation but to the soul of the world.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And when I think of the situation we are in today, her words at the height of the pandemic still resonate with me.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: She said: “We will succeed – and that success will belong to every one of us”.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: She always reminded us that our future is built on new ideas and founded in our oldest values.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Since the end of World War 2, we have pursued the promise of democracy and the rule of law.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And the nations of the world have built together an international system promoting peace and security, justice and economic progress.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Today this is the very target of Russian missiles.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: What we saw in the streets of Bucha, in the scorched fields of grain, and now at the gates of Ukraine's largest nuclear plant – is not only a violation of international rules.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It's a deliberate attempt to discard them.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This watershed moment in global politics calls for a rethink of our foreign policy agenda.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is the time to invest in the power of democracies.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This work begins with the core group of our like-minded partners: our friends in every single democratic nation on this globe.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We see the world with the same eyes.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we should mobilise our collective power to shape global goods.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We should strive to expand this core of democracies.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The most immediate way to do so is to deepen our ties and strengthen democracies on our continent.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This starts with those countries that are already on the path to our Union.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We must be at their side every step of the way.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Because the path towards strong democracies and the path towards our Union are one and the same.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
So I want the people of the Western Balkans, of Ukraine, Moldova and Georgia to know:

You are part of our family, your future is in our Union, and our Union is not complete without you!

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We have also seen that there is a need to reach out to the countries of Europe – beyond the accession process.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is why I support the call for a European Political Community – and we will set out our ideas to the European Council.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But our future also depends on our ability to engage beyond the core of our democratic partners.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Countries near and far, share an interest in working with us on the great challenges of this century, such as climate change and digitalisation.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is the main idea behind Global Gateway, the investment plan I announced right here one year ago.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It is already delivering on the ground.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Together with our African partners we are building two factories in Rwanda and Senegal to manufacture mRNA vaccines.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: They will be made in Africa, for Africa, with world-class technology.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we are now replicating this approach across Latin America as part of a larger engagement strategy.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This requires investment on a global scale.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: So we will team up with our friends in the US and with other G7 partners to make this happen.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: In this spirit, President Biden and I will convene a leaders' meeting to review and announce implementation projects.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Honourable Members,

This is part of our work of strengthening our democracies.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But we should not lose sight of the way foreign autocrats are targeting our own countries.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Foreign entities are funding institutes that undermine our values.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Their disinformation is spreading from the internet to the halls of our universities.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Earlier this year, a university in Amsterdam shut down an allegedly independent research centre, which was actually funded by Chinese entities.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This centre was publishing so-called research on human rights, dismissing the evidence of forced labour camps for Uyghurs as “rumours”.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: These lies are toxic for our democracies.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Think about this: We introduced legislation to screen foreign direct investment in our companies for security concerns.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: If we do that for our economy, shouldn't we do the same for our values?

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We need to better shield ourselves from malign interference.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is why we will present a Defence of Democracy package.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It will bring covert foreign influence and shady funding to light.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We will not allow any autocracy's Trojan horses to attack our democracies from within.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: For more than 70 years, our continent has marched towards democracy.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But the gains of our long journey are not assured.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Many of us have taken democracy for granted for too long.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Especially those, like me, who have never experienced what it means to live under the fist of an authoritarian regime.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Today we all see that we must fight for our democracies.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Every single day.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We must protect them both from the external threats they face, and from the vices that corrode them from within.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It is my Commission's duty and most noble role to protect the rule of law.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: So let me assure you: we will keep insisting on judicial independence.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we will also protect our budget through the conditionality mechanism.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And today I would like to focus on corruption, with all its faces.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The face of foreign agents trying to influence our political system.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The face of shady companies or foundations abusing public money.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: If we want to be credible when we ask candidate countries to strengthen their democracies, we must also eradicate corruption at home.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: That is why in the coming year the Commission will present measures to update our legislative framework for fighting corruption.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We will raise standards on offences such as illicit enrichment, trafficking in influence and abuse of power, beyond the more classic offences such as bribery.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we will also propose to include corruption in our human rights sanction regime, our new tool to protect our values abroad.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Corruption erodes trust in our institutions.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: So we must fight back with the full force of the law.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Honourable Members,

Our founders only meant to lay the first stone of this democracy.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: They always thought that future generations would complete their work.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
“Democracy has not gone out of fashion, but it must update itself in order to keep improving people's lives.”

These are the words of David Sassoli – a great European, who we all pay tribute to today.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: David Sassoli thought that Europe should always look for new horizons.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And through the adversities of these times, we have started to see what our new horizon might be.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: A braver Union.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Closer to its people in times of need.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Bolder in responding to historic challenges and daily concerns of Europeans.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And to walk at their side when they deal with the big trials of life.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is why the Conference on the Future of Europe was so important.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It was a sneak peek of a different kind of citizens' engagement, well beyond election day.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And after Europe listened to its citizens' voice, we now need to deliver.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The Citizens' Panels that were central to the Conference will now become a regular feature of our democratic life.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And in the Letter of Intent that I have sent today to President Metsola and Prime Minister Fiala, I have outlined a number of proposals for the year ahead that stem from the Conference conclusions.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: They include for example a new initiative on mental health.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We should take better care of each other.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And for many who feel anxious and lost, appropriate, accessible and affordable support can make all the difference.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Honourable Members,

Democratic institutions must constantly gain and regain the citizens' trust.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We must live up to the new challenges that history always puts before us.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Just like Europeans did when millions of Ukrainians came knocking on their door.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is Europe at its best.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: A Union of determination and solidarity.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But this determination and drive for solidarity is still missing in our migration debate.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Our actions towards Ukrainian refugees must not be an exception.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: They can be our blueprint for going forward.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We need fair and quick procedures, a system that is crisis proof and quick to deploy, and a permanent and legally binding mechanism that ensures solidarity.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And at the same time, we need effective control of our external borders, in line with the respect of fundamental rights.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: I want a Europe that manages migration with dignity and respect.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: I want a Europe where all Member States take responsibility for challenges we all share.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And I want a Europe that shows solidarity to all Member States.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We have progress on the Pact, we now have the Roadmap.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we now need the political will to match.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Honourable Members,

Three weeks ago, I had the incredible opportunity of joining 1,500 young people from all over Europe and the world, who gathered in Taizé.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: They have different views, they come from different countries, they have different backgrounds, they speak different languages.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And yet, there is something that connects them.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: They share a set of values and ideals.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: They believe in these values.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: They are all passionate about something larger than themselves.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This generation is a generation of dreamers but also of makers.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: In my last State of the Union address, I told you that I would like Europe to look more like these young people.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We should put their aspirations at the heart of everything we do.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And the place for this is in our founding Treaties.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Every action that our Union takes should be inspired by a simple principle.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: That we should do no harm to our children's future.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: That we should leave the world a better place for the next generation.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And therefore, Honourable Members, I believe that it is time to enshrine solidarity between generations in our Treaties.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It is time to renew the European promise.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we also need to improve the way we do things and the way we decide things.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Some might say this is not the right time.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But if we are serious about preparing for the world of tomorrow we must be able to act on the things that matter the most to people.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And as we are serious about a larger union, we also have to be serious about reform.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: So as this Parliament has called for, I believe the moment has arrived for a European Convention.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
CONCLUSION

Honourable Members,

They say that light shines brightest in the dark.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And that was certainly true for the women and the children fleeing Russia's bombs.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: They fled a country at war, filled with sadness for what they had left behind, and fear for what may lie ahead.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But they were received with open arms.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: By many citizens like Magdalena and Agnieszka.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Two selfless young women from Poland.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: As soon as they heard about trains full of refugees, they rushed to the Warsaw Central Station.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: They started to organise.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: They set up a tent to assist as many people as possible.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: They reached out to supermarket chains for food, and to local authorities to organise buses to hospitality centres.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: In a matter of days, they gathered 3000 volunteers, to welcome refugees 24/7.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Honourable Members,

Magdalena and Agnieszka are here with us today.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Please join me in applauding them and each and every European who opened their hearts and their homes.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Their story is about everything our Union stands and strives for.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It is a story of heart, character and solidarity.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: They showed everyone what Europeans can achieve when we rally around a common mission.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is Europe's spirit.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: A Union that stands strong together.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: A Union that prevails together.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Long live Europe.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
ANSWERING THE CALL OF HISTORY

 

INTRODUCTION – DELIVER TODAY, PREPARE FOR TOMORROW

Honourable Members,

In just under 300 days, Europeans will take to the polls in our unique and remarkable democracy.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: As with any election, it will be a time for people to reflect on the State of our Union and the work done by those that represent them.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But it will also be a time to decide on what kind of future and what kind of Europe they want.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Among them will be millions of first-time voters, the youngest of whom were born in 2008.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: As they stand in that polling booth, they will think about what matters to them.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: They will think about the war that rages at our borders.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Or the impact of destructive climate change.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: About how artificial intelligence will influence their lives.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Or of their chances of getting a house or a job in the years ahead.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Our Union today reflects the vision of those who dreamt of a better future after World War II.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: A future in which a Union of nations, democracies and people would work together to share peace and prosperity.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: They believed that Europe was the answer to the call of history.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: When I speak to the new generation of young people, I see that same vision for a better future.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: That same burning desire to build something better.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: That same belief that in a world of uncertainty, Europe once again must answer the call of history.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And that is what we must do together.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Honourable Members,

This starts with earning the trust of Europeans to deal with their aspirations and anxieties.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And in the next 300 days we must finish the job that they entrusted us with.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: I want to thank this House for its leading role in delivering on one of the most ambitious transformations this Union has ever embarked on.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: When I stood in front of you in 2019 with my programme for a green, digital and geopolitical Europe I know that some had doubts.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And that was before the world turned upside down with a global pandemic and a brutal war on European soil.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But look at where Europe is today.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We have seen the birth of a geopolitical Union – supporting Ukraine, standing up to Russia's aggression, responding to an assertive China and investing in partnerships.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We now have a European Green Deal as the centrepiece of our economy and unmatched in ambition.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We have set the path for the digital transition and become global pioneers in online rights.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We have the historic NextGenerationEU – combining 800 billion euros of investment and reform – and creating decent jobs for today and tomorrow.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We have set the building blocks for a Health Union, helping to vaccinate an entire continent – and large parts of the world.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We have started making ourselves more independent in critical sectors, like energy, chips or raw materials.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: I would also like to thank you for the ground-breaking and pioneering work we did on gender equality.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: As a woman, this means a lot to me.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We have concluded files that many thought would be blocked forever, like the Women on Boards Directive and the historic accession of the EU to the Istanbul Convention.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: With the Directive on pay transparency we have cast into law the basic principle that equal work deserves equal pay.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: There is not a single argument why – for the same type of work – a woman should be paid less than a man.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But our work is far from over and we must continue pushing for progress together.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: I know this house supports our proposal on combating violence against women.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Here too, I would like that we cast into law another basic principle: No, means no.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: There can be no true equality without freedom from violence.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And thanks to this Parliament, to Member States and to my team of Commissioners, we have delivered over 90% of the Political Guidelines I presented in 2019.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Together, we have shown that when Europe is bold, it gets things done.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And our work is far from over - so let's stand together.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Let's deliver today and prepare for tomorrow.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
EUROPEAN GREEN DEAL

Honourable Members,

Four years ago, the European Green Deal was our answer to the call of history.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And this summer – the hottest ever on record in Europe – was a stark reminder of that.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Greece and Spain were struck by ravaging wildfires – and were hit again only a few weeks later by devastating floods.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we saw the chaos and carnage of extreme weather – from Slovenia to Bulgaria and right across our Union.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is the reality of a boiling planet.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The European Green Deal was born out of this necessity to protect our planet.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But it was also designed as an opportunity to preserve our future prosperity.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We started this mandate by setting a long-term perspective with the climate law and the 2050 target.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We shifted the climate agenda to being an economic one.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This has given a clear sense of direction for investment and innovation.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we have already seen this growth strategy deliveringin the short-term.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Europe's industry is showing every day that it is ready to power this transition.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Proving that modernisation and decarbonisation can go hand in hand.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: In the last five years, the number of clean steel factories in the EU has grown from zero to 38.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We are now attracting more investment in clean hydrogenthan the US and China combined.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And tomorrow I will be in Denmark with Prime Minister Mette Frederiksen to see that innovation first hand.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We will mark the launch of the first container ship, powered by clean methanol made with solar energy.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is the strength of Europe's response to climate change.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The European Green Deal provides the necessary frame, incentives, and investment – but it is the people, the inventors, the engineers who develop the solutions.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
And this is why, Honourable Members,

as we enter the next phase of the European Green Deal, one thing will never change.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We will keep supporting European industry throughout this transition.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We started with a package of measures – from the Net-Zero Industry Act to the Critical Raw Materials Act.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: With our Industry Strategy, we are looking at the risks and needs of each ecosystem in this transition.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We need to finish this work.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And with this, we need to develop an approach for each industrial ecosystem.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Therefore, starting from this month, we will hold a series of Clean Transition Dialogues with industry.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The core aim will be to support every sector in building its business model for the decarbonisation of industry.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Because we believe that this transition is essential for our future competitiveness in Europe.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But this is just as much about the people and their jobs of today.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Our wind industry, for instance, is a European success story.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But it is currently facing a unique mix of challenges.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is why we will put forward a European Wind Power package – working closely with industry and Member States.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We will fast-track permitting even more.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We will improve the auction systems across the EU.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We will focus on skills, access to finance and stable supply chains.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
But this is broader than one sector:

From wind to steel, from batteries to electric vehicles, our ambition is crystal clear: The future of our clean tech industry has to be made in Europe.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Honourable Members, 

This shows that when it comes to the European Green Deal: 

We stay the course.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We stay ambitious.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We stick to our growth strategy.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we will always strive for a fair and just transition!

speaker: Leyen
sentence: That means a fair outcome for future generations – to live on healthy planet.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And a fair journey for all those impacted – with decent jobs and a solemn promise to leave no one behind.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Just think about manufacturing jobs and competitiveness: a topic we are discussing a lot these days.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Our industry and tech companies like competition.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: They know that global competition is good for business.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And that it creates and protects good jobs here in Europe.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But competition is only true as long as it is fair.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Too often, our companies are excluded from foreign markets or are victims of predatory practices.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: They are often undercut by competitors benefitting from huge state subsidies.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We have not forgotten how China's unfair trade practicesaffected our solar industry.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Many young businesses were pushed out by heavily subsidised Chinese competitors.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Pioneering companies had to file for bankruptcy.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Promising talents went searching for fortune abroad.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is why fairness in the global economy is so important – because it affects lives and livelihoods.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Entire industries and communities depend on it.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: So, we have be to be clear-eyed about the risks we face.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Take the electric vehicles sector.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It is a crucial industry for the clean economy, with a huge potential for Europe.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But global markets are now flooded with cheaper Chinese electric cars.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And their price is kept artificially low by huge state subsidies.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is distorting our market.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And as we do not accept this from the inside, we do not accept this from the outside.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: So I can announce today that the Commission is launching an anti-subsidy investigation into electric vehicles coming from China.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Europe is open for competition.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Not for a race to the bottom.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We must defend ourselves against unfair practices.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But equally, it is vital to keep open lines of communication and dialogue with China.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Because there also are topics, where we can and have to cooperate.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: De-risk, not decouple – this will be my approach with the Chinese leadership at the EU-China Summit later this year.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Honourable Members,

In the European Union, we are proud of our cultural diversity.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We are a ‘Europe of the Regions' with a unique blend of languages, music, art, traditions, crafts and cuisines.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We are also a continent of unique biological diversity.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Some 6 500 species are found only in Europe.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: In northern Europe, we find the Wadden Sea, a world natural heritage site and unique habitat offering a home to rare species of flora and fauna and a vital resource for millions of migratory birds.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And with the Baltic Sea we have the largest area of brackish sea in the world.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: South of that is the European Plain, characterised by vast tracts of moorland and wetland.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: These regions are important allies against ongoing climate change.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Protected moors and wetlands absorb enormous volumes of greenhouse gases, secure regional water cycles and are home to unique biodiversity.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And Europe is a continent of forests.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: From the mighty coniferous forests of the North and East, via the last remnants of virgin oak and beech forest in central Europe to the cork oak forests of southern Europe: all these forests are an irreplaceable source of goods and services.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: They absorb carbon dioxide, supply wood and other products, generate fertile soils, and filter the air and the water.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Biodiversity and ecosystem services are vital for all of us in Europe.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Loss of nature destroys not only the foundations of our life, but also our feeling of what constitutes home.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We must protect it.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: At the same time, food security, in harmony with nature, remains an essential task.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: I would like to take this opportunity to express my appreciation to our farmers, to thank them for providing us with food day after day.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: For us in Europe, this task of agriculture – producing healthy food – is the foundation of our agricultural policy.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And self-sufficiency in food is also important for us.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: That is what our farmers provide.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It is not always an easy task, as the consequences of Russia's aggression against Ukraine, climate change bringing droughts, forest fires and flooding, and new obligations are all having a growing impact on farmers' work and incomes.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We must bear that in mind.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Many are already working towards a more sustainable form of agriculture.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We must work together with the men and women in farming to tackle these new challenges.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: That is the only way to secure the supply of food for the future.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We need more dialogue and less polarisation.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: That is why we want to launch a strategic dialogue on the future of agriculture in the EU.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: I am and remain convinced that agriculture and protection of the natural world can go hand in hand.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We need both.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
ECONOMY, SOCIAL AND COMPETITIVENESS

Honourable Members,

A fair transition for farmers, families and industry.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is the hallmark of this Mandate.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And it is all the more important as we face strong economic headwinds.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: I see three major economic challenges for our industry in the year ahead: labour and skills shortages, inflation, and making business easier for our companies.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The first has to do with our labour market.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We have not forgotten the early days of the global pandemic.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: When everyone predicted a new wave of 1930-style mass unemployment.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But we defied this prediction.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: With SURE – the first-ever European short-time work initiative – we saved 40 million jobs.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is Europe's social market economy in action.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we can be proud of it!

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We then immediately restarted our economic engine thanks to NextGenerationEU.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And today we see the results.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Europe is close to full employment.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Instead of millions of people looking for jobs, millions of jobs are looking for people.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Labour and skills shortages are reaching record levels – both here and across all major economies.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: 74% of SMEs are saying they are facing skill shortages.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: In the peak of the tourist season, restaurants and bars in Europe are running reduced hours because they cannot find staff.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Hospitals are postponing treatment because of lack of nurses.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And two thirds of European companies are looking for IT specialists.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: At the same time millions of parents – mostly mothers – are struggling to reconcile work and family, because there is no childcare.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And 8 million young people are neither in employment, education or training.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Their dreams put on hold, their lives on stand-by.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is not only the cause of so much personal distress.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It is also one of the most significant bottlenecks for our competitiveness.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Because labour shortages hamper the capacity for innovation, growth and prosperity.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: So we need to improve access to the labour market.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Most importantly for young people, for women.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we need qualified migration.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: In addition, we need to respond to the deep-rooted shifts in technology, society and demography.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And for that, we should rely on the expertise of businesses and trade unions, our collective bargaining partners.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It is almost forty years since Jacques Delors convened the Val Duchesse meeting that saw the birth of European social dialogue.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Since then, social partners have shaped the Union of today – ensuring progress and prosperity for millions.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And as the world around us changes faster than ever, social partners must again be at the heart of our future.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Together we must focus on the challenges facing the labour market – from skills and labour shortages, to new challenges stemming from AI.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is why together with the Belgian Presidency next year, we will convene a new Social Partner Summit once again at Val Duchesse.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The future of Europe will be built with and by our social partners.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The second major economic challenge: persistent high inflation.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Christine Lagarde and the European Central Bank are working hard to keep inflation under control.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We know that returning to the ECB's medium-term target will take some time.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The good news is that Europe has started bringing energy prices down.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We have not forgotten, Putin's deliberate use of gas as a weapon and how it triggered fears of blackout and an energy crisis like in the 70s.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Many thought, we would not have enough energy to get through the winter.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But we made it.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Because we stayed united – pooling our demand and buying energy together.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And at the same time, different to the 70s, we used the crisis to massively invest in renewables and fast-track the clean transition.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We used Europe's critical mass to bring prices down and secure our supply.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The price for gas in Europe was over 300 euros per MWh one year ago.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It is now around 35.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: So we need to look at how we can replicate this model of success in other fields like critical raw materials or clean hydrogen.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The third challenge for European companies is about making it easier to do business.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Small companies do not have the capacity to cope with complex administration.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Or they are held back by lengthy processes.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This often means they do less with the time they have – and that they miss out on opportunities to grow.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is why – before the end of the year – we will appoint an EU SME envoy reporting directly to me.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We want to hear directly from small and medium sized businesses, about their everyday challenges.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: For every new piece of legislation we conduct a competitiveness check by an independent board.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And next month, we will make the first legislative proposalstowards reducing reporting obligations at the European level by 25%.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Honourable Members,

Let's be frank – this will not be easy.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we will need your support.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Because this is a common endeavour for all European institutions.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: So we also have to work with Member States, to match the 25% at national level.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It is time to make business easier in Europe!

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But European companies also need access to key technologies to innovate, develop and manufacture.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is a question of European sovereignty as the Leaders underlined in Versailles.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It is an economic and national security imperative to preserve a European edge on critical and emerging technologies.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This European industrial policy also requires common European funding.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is why – as part of our proposal for a review of our budget – we proposed the STEP platform.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: With STEP we can boost, leverage and steer EU funds to invest in everything from microelectronics to quantum computing and AI.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: From biotech to clean tech.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Our companies need this support now – so I urge for a quick agreement on our budget proposal.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And I know I can count on this House.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And there is more when it comes to competitiveness.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We have seen real bottlenecks along global supply chains, including because of the deliberate policies of other countries.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Just think about China's export restrictions on gallium and germanium – which are essential for goods like semiconductors and solar panels.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This shows why it is so important for Europe to step up on economic security.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: By de-risking and not decoupling.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And I am very proud that this concept has found broad support from key partners.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: From Australia to Japan and the United States.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And many other countries around the world want to work together.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Many are overly dependent on a single supplier for critical minerals.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Others – from Latin America to Africa – want to develop local industries for processing and refining, instead of just shipping their resources abroad.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is why later this year we will convene the first meeting of our new Critical Raw Materials Club.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: At the same time, we will continue to drive open and fair trade.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: So far, we have concluded new free trade agreements with Chile, New Zealand and Kenya.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We should aim to complete deals with Australia, Mexico and Mercosur by the end of this year.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And soon thereafter with India and Indonesia.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Smart trade delivers good jobs and prosperity.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Honourable Members,

These three challenges – labour, inflation and business environment – come at a time when we are also asking industry to lead on the clean transition.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: So we need to look further ahead and set out how we remain competitive as we do that.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is why I have asked Mario Draghi – one of Europe's great economic minds – to prepare a report on the future of European competitiveness.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Because Europe will do “whatever it takes” to keep its competitive edge.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
DIGITAL & AI

Honourable Members, 

When it comes to making business and life easier, we have seen how important digital technology is.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It is telling that we have far overshot the 20% investment target in digital projects of NextGenerationEU.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Member States have used that investment to digitise their healthcare, justice system or transport network.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: At the same time, Europe has led on managing the risks of the digital world.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The internet was born as an instrument for sharing knowledge, opening minds and connecting people.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But it has also given rise to serious challenges.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Disinformation, spread of harmful content, risks to the privacy of our data.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: All of this led to a lack of trust and a breach of fundamental rights of people.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: In response, Europe has become the global pioneer of citizen's rights in the digital world.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The DSA and DMA are creating a safer digital space where fundamental rights are protected.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And they are ensuring fairness with clear responsibilities for big tech.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is a historic achievement – and we should be proud of it.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The same should be true for artificial intelligence.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It will improve healthcare, boost productivity, address climate change.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But we also should not underestimate the very real threats.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Hundreds of leading AI developers, academics and experts warned us recently with the following words:

“Mitigating the risk of extinction from AI should be a global priority alongside other societal-scale risks such as pandemics and nuclear war.”

AI is a general technology that is accessible, powerful and adaptable for a vast range of uses - both civilian andmilitary.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And it is moving faster than even its developers anticipated.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: So we have a narrowing window of opportunity to guide this technology responsibly.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: I believe Europe, together with partners, should lead the way on a new global framework for AI, built on three pillars: guardrails, governance and guiding innovation.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Firstly, guardrails.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Our number one priority is to ensure AI develops in a human-centric, transparent and responsible way.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is why in my Political Guidelines, I committed to setting out a legislative approach in the first 100 days.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We put forward the AI Act – the world's first comprehensive pro-innovation AI law.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And I want to thank this House and the Council for the tireless work on this groundbreaking law.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Our AI Act is already a blueprint for the whole world.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We must now focus on adopting the rules as soon as possible and turn to implementation.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The second pillar is governance.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We are now laying the foundations for a single governance system in Europe.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But we should also join forces with our partners to ensure a global approach to understanding the impact of AI in our societies.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Think about the invaluable contribution of the IPCC for climate, a global panel that provides the latest science to policymakers.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: I believe we need a similar body for AI – on the risks and its benefits for humanity.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: With scientists, tech companies and independent experts all around the table.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This will allow us to develop a fast and globally coordinated response – building on the work done by the Hiroshima Process and others.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The third pillar is guiding innovation in a responsible way.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Thanks to our investment in the last years, Europe has now become a leader in supercomputing – with 3 of the 5 most powerful supercomputers in the world.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We need to capitalise on this.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is why I can announce today a new initiative to open up our high-performance computers to AI start-ups to train their models.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But this will only be part of our work to guide innovation.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We need an open dialogue with those that develop and deploy AI.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It happens in the United States, where seven major tech companies have already agreed to voluntary rules around safety, security and trust.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It happens here, where we will work with AI companies, so that they voluntarily commit to the principles of the AI Actbefore it comes into force.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Now we should bring all of this work together towards minimum global standards for safe and ethical use of AI.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
GLOBAL, MIGRATION AND SECURITY

Honourable Members,

When I stood here four years ago, I said that if we are united on the inside, nobody will divide us from the outside.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And this was the thinking behind the Geopolitical Commission.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Our Team Europe approach has enabled us to be more strategic, more assertive and more united.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And that is more important than ever.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Our heart bleeds when we see the devastating loss of life in Libya and Morocco after the violent floods and earthquake.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Europe will always stand ready to support in any way we can.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Or think about the Sahel region, one of the poorest yet fastest growing demographically.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The succession of military coups will make the region more unstable for years ahead.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Russia is both influencing and benefiting from the chaos.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And the region has become fertile ground for the rise in terrorism.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is of direct concern for Europe – for our security and prosperity.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: So we need to show the same unity of purpose towards Africa as we have shown for Ukraine.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We need to focus on cooperation with legitimate governments and regional organisations.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we need to develop a mutually beneficial partnership which focuses on common issues for Europe and Africa.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is why, together with High Representative Borrell, we will work on a new strategic approach to take forward at the next EU-AU Summit.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Honourable Members,

History is on the move.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Russia is waging a full-scale war against the founding principles of the UN Charter.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This has raised immense concerns in countries from Central Asia to the Indo-Pacific.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: They are worried that in a lawless world, they might face the same fate as Ukraine.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We see a clear attempt by some to return to bloc thinking – trying to isolate and influence countries in between.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And it comes at a time when there is a deeper unease by many emerging economies about the way institutions and globalisation work for them.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Those concerns are legitimate.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: These emerging economies – with their people and natural assets – are essential allies in building a cleaner, safer and more prosperous world.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Europe will always work with them to reform and improve the international system.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We want to lead efforts to make the rules-based order fairer and make distribution more equal.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This will also mean working with new and old partners to deepen our connections.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And Europe's offer with Global Gateway is truly unique.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Global Gateway is more transparent, more sustainable, and more economically attractive.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Just last week I was in New Delhi to sign the most ambitious project of our generation.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The India-Middle East-Europe Economic Corridor.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It will be the most direct connection to date between India, the Arabian Gulf and Europe: With a rail link, that will make trade between India and Europe 40% faster.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: With an electricity cable and a clean hydrogen pipeline – to foster clean energy trade between Asia, the Middle East and Europe.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: With a high-speed data cable, to link some of the most innovative digital ecosystems in the world, and create business opportunities all along the way.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: These are state-of-the-art connections for the world of tomorrow.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Faster, shorter, cleaner.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And Global Gateway is making the real difference.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: I have seen it in Latin America, South-East Asia and across Africa – from building a local hydrogen economy with Namibia and Kenya to a digital economy with the Philippines.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: These are investments in our partners' economy.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And they are investments in Europe's prosperity and security in a fast-changing world.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Honourable Members,

Every day, we see that conflict, climate change and instability are pushing people to seek refuge elsewhere.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: I have always had a steadfast conviction that migration needs to be managed.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It needs endurance and patient work with key partners.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And it needs unity within our Union.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is the spirit of the New Pact on Migration and Asylum.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: When we took office, there seemed to be no possible compromise in sight.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But with the Pact, we are striking a new balance.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Between protecting borders and protecting people.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Between sovereignty and solidarity.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Between security and humanity.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We listened to all Member States and focused on all routes.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we have translated the spirit of the Pact into practical solutions.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We were fast and united in responding to the hybrid attack that Belarus launched against us.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We worked closely with our Western Balkan partners and reduced irregular flows.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We have signed a partnership with Tunisia that brings mutual benefits beyond migration – from energy and education, to skills and security.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we now want to work on similar agreements with other countries.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We stepped up border protection.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: European Agencies deepened their cooperation with Member States.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Allow me to thank in particular Bulgaria and Romania for leading the way – showcasing best practices on both asylum and returns.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: They have proved it: Bulgaria and Romania are part of our Schengen area.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: So let us finally bring them in – without any further delay.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Ladies and Gentlemen,

Our work on migration is based on the conviction that unity is within our reach.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: An agreement on the pact has never been so close.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Parliament and the Council have a historic opportunity to get it over the line.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Let us show that Europe can manage migration effectively and with compassion.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Let's get this done!

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Honourable members,

We know that migration requires constant work.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And nowhere is that more vital than in the fight against human smugglers.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: They attract desperate people with their lies.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And put them on deadly routes across the desert, or on boats that are unfit for the sea.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The way these smugglers operate is continuously evolving.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But our legislation is over twenty years old and needs an urgent update.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: So we need new legislation and a new governance structure.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We need stronger law enforcement, prosecution and a more prominent role for our agencies – Europol, Eurojust and Frontex.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we need to work with our partners to tackle this global plague of human trafficking.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is why the Commission will organise an International Conference on fighting people smuggling.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It is time to put an end to this callous and criminal business!

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
UKRAINE

Honourable Members,

On the day when Russian tanks crossed the border into Ukraine, a young Ukrainian mother set off for Prague to bring her child to safety.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: When the Czech border official stamped her passport, she started crying.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Her son didn't understand.
