speaker: Leyen
sentence: And he asked his mother why she was crying.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
She answered: “Because we are home.”

“But this is not Ukraine,” he argued.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
So she explained: “This is Europe.”

On that day, that Ukrainian mother, felt that Europe was her home.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Because “home is where we trust each other”.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And the people of Ukraine could trust their fellow Europeans.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Her name was Victoria Amelina.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: She was one of the great young writers of her generation and a tireless activist for justice.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Once her son was safe, Victoria returned to Ukraine to document Russia's war crimes.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: One year later she was killed by a Russian ballistic missile, while having dinner with colleagues.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The victim of a Russian war crime, one of countless attacks against innocent civilians.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Amelina was with three friends that day – including Héctor Abad Faciolince, a fellow writer from Colombia.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: He is part of a campaign called “Aguanta, Ucrania” – “Resist, Ukraine”, created to tell Latin Americans of Russia's war of aggression and attacks on civilians.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But Héctor could never imagine becoming the target himself.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Afterwards, he said he didn't know why he lived and she died.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But now he is telling the world about Victoria.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: To save her memory and to end this war.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And I am honoured that Héctor is here with us today.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And I want you to know that we will keep the memory of Victoria – and all other victims – alive.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Aguanta, Ucrania.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Slava Ukraini!

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Honourable Members,

We will be at Ukraine's side every step of the way.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: For as long as it takes.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Since the start of the war, four million Ukrainians have found refuge in our Union.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And I want to say to them that they are as welcome now as they were in those fateful first weeks.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We have ensured that they have access to housing, healthcare, the job market and much more.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Honourable Members,

this was Europe answering the call of history.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And so I am proud to announce that the Commission will propose to extend our temporary protection to Ukrainians in the EU.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Our support to Ukraine will endure.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We have provided 12 billion euros this year alone to help pay wages and pensions.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: To help keep hospitals, schools and other services running.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And through our ASAP proposal we are ramping up ammunition production to help match Ukraine's immediate needs.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But we are also looking further ahead.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is why we have proposed an additional 50 billion euros over four years for investment and reforms.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This will help build Ukraine's future to rebuild a modern and prosperous country.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And that future is clear to see.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This House has said it out loud: The future of Ukraine is in our Union.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The future of the Western Balkans is in our Union.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The future of Moldova is in our Union.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And I know just how important the EU perspective is for so many people in Georgia.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Honourable Members,

I started by speaking of Europe responding to the call of history.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And history is now calling us to work on completing our Union.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: In a world where some are trying to pick off countries one by one, we cannot afford to leave our fellow Europeans behind.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: In a world where size and weight matters, it is clearly in Europe's strategic and security interests to complete our Union.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But beyond the politics and geopolitics of it, we need to picture what is at stake.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We need to set out a vision for a successful enlargement.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: A Union complete with over 500 million people living in a free, democratic and prosperous Union.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: A Union complete with young people who can live, study and work in freedom.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: A Union complete with vibrant democracies in which judiciaries are independent, oppositions are respected, and journalists are protected.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Because the rule of law and fundamental rights will always be the foundation of our Union – in current and in future Member States.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is why the Commission has made the Rule of Law Reports a key priority.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We now work closely with Member States to identify progress and concerns – and make recommendations for the year ahead.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This has ensured accountability in front of this House and national parliaments.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It has allowed for dialogue between Member States.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And it is delivering results.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: I believe that it can do the same for future Member States.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is why I am very happy to announce that we will open the Rule of Law Reports to those accession countries who get up to speed even faster.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This will place them on an equal footing with Member States.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And support them in their reform efforts.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And it will help ensure that our future is a Union of freedom, rights and values for all.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Honourable Members,

This is in our shared interest.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Think about the great enlargement of 20 years ago.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We called it the European Day of Welcomes.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And it was a triumph of determination and hope over the burdens of the past.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And in the 20 years since we have seen an economic success story which has improved the lives of millions.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: I want us to look forward to the next European Day of Welcomes and the next economic success stories.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We know this is not an easy road.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Accession is merit-based – and the Commission will always defend this principle.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It takes hard work and leadership.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But there is already a lot of progress.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We have seen the great strides Ukraine has already made since we granted them candidate status.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we have seen the determination of other candidate countries to reform.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Honourable Members,

it is now time for us to match that determination.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And that means thinking about how we get ready for a completed Union.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We need to move past old, binary debates about enlargement.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is not a question of deepening integration or widening the Union.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We can and we must do both.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: To give us the geopolitical weight and the capacity to act.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is what our Union has always done.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Each wave of enlargement came with a political deepening.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We went from coal and steel towards full economic integration.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And after the fall of the Iron Curtain, we turned an economic project into a true Union of people and states.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: I believe that the next enlargement must also be a catalyst for progress.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We have started to build a Health Union at 27.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And I believe we can finish it at 30+.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We have started to build European Defence Union at 27.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And I believe we can finish it at 30+.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We have proven that we can be a Geopolitical Union andshowed we can move fast when we are united.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And I believe that Team Europe also works at 30+.

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
Honourable Members,

I know this House believes the same.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And the European Parliament has always been one of the main drivers of European integration.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It has been so throughout the decades.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And it is once again today.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And I will always support this House – and all of those who want to reform the EU to make it work better for citizens.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And, yes, that means including through a European Convention and Treaty change if and where it is needed!

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But we cannot – and we should not – wait for Treaty change to move ahead with enlargement.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: A Union fit for enlargement can be achieved faster.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: That means answering practical questions about how a Union of over 30 countries will work in practice.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And in particular about our capacity to act.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The good news is that with every enlargement those who said it would make us less efficient were proven wrong.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Take the last few years.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We agreed on NextGenerationEU at 27.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We agreed to buy vaccines at 27.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We agreed on sanctions in record time – also at 27.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We agreed to purchase natural gas – not only at 27 but including Ukraine, Moldova and Serbia.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: So it can be done.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But we need to look closer at each policy and see how they would be affected by a larger Union.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is why the Commission will start working on a series of pre-enlargement policy reviews to see how each area may need to be adapted to a larger Union.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We will need to think about how our institutions would work – how the Parliament and the Commission would look.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We need to discuss the future of our budget – in terms of what it finances, how it finances it, and how it is financed.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we need to understand how to ensure credible security commitments in a world where deterrence matters more than ever.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: These are questions we must address today if we want to be ready for tomorrow.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And the Commission will play its part.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is why we will put forward our ideas to the Leaders' discussion under the Belgian Presidency.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: We will be driven by the belief that completing our Union is the best investment in peace, security and prosperity for our Continent.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: So it is time for Europe to once again think big and write our own destiny!

speaker: Leyen
sentence:
CONCLUSION

Honourable Members,

Victoria Amelina believed that it is our collective duty to write a new story for Europe.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: This is where Europe stands today.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: At a time and place where history is written.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The future of our continent depends on the choices we make today.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: On the steps we take to complete our Union.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: The people of Europe want a Union that stands up for them in a time of great power competition.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: But also one that protects and stands close to them, as a partner and ally in their daily battles.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: And we will listen to their voice.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: If it matters to Europeans, it matters to Europe.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Think again about the vision and imagination of the young generation I started my speech with.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: It is the moment to show them that we can build a continent where you can be who you are, love who you want, and aim as high as you want.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: A continent reconciled with nature and leading the way on new technologies.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: A continent that is united in freedom and peace.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Once again – this is Europe's moment to answer the call of history.

speaker: Leyen
sentence: Long live Europe.
